column7: Now that the buzz has died down at this once impossible-to-get-into watering hole, it’s finally a place worth visiting. The vaguely rock & roll–themed spot, with its craggy exposed-brick walls and dumpy vintage sofas, draws musicians and rock-star wanna-bes. Shove your way through the narrow, often jam-packed front room, and settle into a seat in the spacious, high-ceilinged lounge in the back. This Musical Box doesn’t actually have live bands, but feel free to rock the pool table.

column7: Many locals don’t even know this nook exists, but a quick peek inside reveals that plenty of others have discovered its divey charms. A bar in the front offers ample room for downing one of five beers on tap. Choice offerings include McSorley’s Black & Tan and All State Amber Ale. There’s more space among the tables in the back, where regulars eat pub standards like steak with mashed potatoes and carve their names into the wooden tabletops. During happy hour, weekdays from 4:30 to 6:30pm, get $1 off drinks.

column7: The perfect bookstore has Shuggie Otis on the dial, a selection of beer and wine at a counter in the corner and the best possible reason to spend money here: Every dollar earned helps house people living with AIDS. The bookshelves ooze academia, but the Works cuts loose monthly with intimate concerts featuring the likes of Fountains of Wayne and Lyle Lovett. It’s a good first-date place, because, as a volunteer clerk says, “if the conversation dulls, you can just grab a book.”

column7: Imagine that your favorite gourmet-deli lunch spot turned into a bar at night, and you’d have a handle on Printon 56. The long, narrow storefront, one doorway over from the deli portion of the business, serves coffee and hosts a juice bar. At 4pm, it morphs into a font of alcohol (seven beers on tap, full liquor bar) with two active plasma TVs above the bar—and at 8pm, it closes for the night, though the lounge is available for private rental. Patrons are not just indigenous after-work suits; young couples and downtown types are just as much in evidence.

column7: Getting past the front door can be exasperating, but it’s worth the drama. The decor and atmosphere carry you back to a time when it was easy to get lost inside a club. That’s no illusion: This New York outpost of the nightlife chain is massive. A stellar sound system—and the beats of such crowd-rocking DJs as Deep Dish, Timo Maas and Victor Calderone—keeps the dance floor packed. Skybox-style VIP booths offer perfect people-watching perches; smaller, tucked-away lounge areas allow for intimate private moments. Hedonism reigns, even if it’s only for a few hours.

column7: Perhaps bar owner Michael Momm, a.k.a. DJ Foosh, wanted a place where he could spin to his heart’s content. Maybe he missed the biergartens of his youth in Cologne, Germany. Whatever. Just rejoice that he opened Loreley. Twelve drafts and 8 bottled varieties of Germany’s finest brews are available, along with wines from the country’s Loreley region and a full roster of spirits. Avoid drinking battery-acid–like schnapps straight and try it in the Black German instead, a combination of blackberry schnapps, vodka and champagne served in a martini glass.

column7: Don’t arrive thirsty. It takes at least ten minutes to choose from roughly 150 quaffs, a list that impresses even microbrew mavens.Most selections are middle-European regionals, and bartenders are eager to explain the differences among them. The cozy interior is chock-full of flea market finds, most of which are for sale. There’s also a tasty bar menu of smoked meats, pâtés, cheeses and terrines.

column7: We didn’t know what to expect when we got past the iron curtain—oops, we mean velvet rope—at the clubby lounge. Inside are two spacious rooms that fill up quickly as the night goes on. The Rat Pack–influenced VIP Room is almost always empty, but the industrial front room is jammed with spiky-haired guys in their mid-20s and tall, thin white girls listening to disco-y R&B tunes, doing their best to get to the bar. Something tells us the door policy is liable to loosen up soon.

column7: Hemant Phul spent the first 14 years of his life in Bombay before moving to New York. Now he and his wife, Bhavana, put an Indian spin on every dish, cocktail, table and chair at Earth NYC. They brought in Bollywood fashion designer Manish Malhotra to style the servers’ uniforms and the bi-level interior, which features 132 candles mounted on a 30-foot wall on one side and a long, elegant staircase on the other. The menu includes a drink called the vodka Pani Puri, which combines spirit-infused water and tiny hollow, fried balls of crispy dough.

column163: Tapas may be the ideal cuisine for sharing amongst a large group, but it’s just not practical at ñ, the romantic Crosby Street hideaway that’s not much bigger than a hole in the wall, though, arguably a lot more charming and seductively lit. It’s the perfect place to get a little closer to your dining companion, literally. If you can’t lay claim on a table (there are only three) or a bar stool, you’ll likely be crushed together on the very narrow floor space. But it’s worth it when the food is this good—and this cheap. Aceitunas caseras, a heaping assortment of marinated and spiced Spanish olives, couldn’t be a better deal at $2.75. Flaky empanadas are filled to bursting with leeks, peppers and a different meat or fish each day (the moist cod is an especially inspired choice). Spicy chorizo al jerez is tempered by a dry sherry sauté, while the gamba ajillo features shrimp flavorfully doused with garlic, olive oil and spicy red pepper. Flan, a light caramel custard, closes out the meal and is best paired with a slightly dry after-dinner sherry to undercut the dessert’s sweetness. During the week, _ draws a slightly smaller, local crowd, but the live flamenco band on Wednesday nights really packs them in.

column7: The old Soho hasn’t disappeared completely; you just have to know where to look. An unassuming storefront on Prince Street hides a popular French bistro where, since 1975, celebrities have packed in with regular folk to enjoy the superb meat and fish dishes. Grab a barstool if you can, chat up the well-trained bartenders, and sip a glass of cabernet. An astrologer holds court every night, but if you’re here, we already know your future looks bright.

column163: Eight-year old Il Bagatto sits on restaurant-speckled 2nd Street, seemingly unruffled by the recent slew of trendy Italian joints (Supper, East Post) that have sprung up around its firmly planted roots. For almost a decade, the pint-size kitchen has been sending out big, robust flavors for a nightly packed restaurant. While crowded, Il Bagatto's inevitable wait for a table lasts about as long as it takes you to sip a Chianti (or any of the other 35 by-the-glass wines) from the boastful basement bar-a perfect prelude to what promises to be a dining experience filled with more treats than a Roberto Benigni film. Opening acts include the basics: Calamari alla griglia are grilled, tender tubes doused in lemon, olive oil, and more lemon, leaving a clean and sprightly finish; while the fagioli alla paolona is a pasta-less version of a Tuscan classic. Entrées take center stage; come Sunday for standout specials. Beef roulade is a carb-phobe's answer to croque monsieur; an egg fricassée of meaty beef envelopes layers of mortadella, scamorza, and garlicky arugula and is rolled and sliced into two perfectly round coils. But if you order one thing on the menu, make it the "too good to be legal" gnocchetti verdi e blu-plump little purses of spinach gnocchi lay in a generous pool of mint-green gorgonzola sauce (the parmesan garnish is almost overkill). If you have it in you, order the tartufo for dessert-a pecan-studded chocolate ice cream ball dusted with chocolate-truffle powder. Two words: pleasure bomb.Ê*Notes: Chef is Beatrice Tosti

column163: Asia de Cuba owner Ian Schrager has an uncanny ability to dazzle patrons simply by word of mouth. Like his infamous Studio 54 nightclub, this Latin-Asian fusion restaurant in the Morgans hotel is known for attracting models, celebrities and other types more beautiful than you. Flowing white curtains ensconce the two-level Philippe Starck dining room, creating an understated backdrop for a huge, glass table with communal seating for 36. Kick things off with the hearty, bowling-ball size Asia de Cuba salad, which makes an early appearance at most tables. Sweet banana slices and crushed cashews balance a tart vinaigrette and crispy, still-warm fried calamari. The fusion is at its best with the many seafood entrees. The avocado macadamia nut-crusted tilefish soaks a crunchy layer of Chinese broccoli and sweet roasted corn and pepper ,salsa in a salty fermented black bean sauce, then ,crowns the plate with a thick chunk of tilefish (sort of a cross between bass and monkfish). Another success ,is the tender half duck, served medium rare with a ,light Asian pear coleslaw and an intense orange ,Tamarind sauce. Believe the servers when they warn you that most dishes are big enough for two to share -- be ,sure to leave room for dessert. The giant, tear-shaped ,dark chocolate cake will get your endorphins pumping, ,but youíre even better off taking a dip in the pools ,of hot fudge and caramel that bookend the mammoth, five scoop-and-a-brownie banana split.

column7: The concrete-steel postindustrial look is more Milan than Bangkok, but the folks at the bar are definitely scruffy Brooklynites, and they’ve turned an inexpensive Thai restaurant into one of the Northside’s longer-running hits. There’s also a smaller satellite bar around the corner at the Berry Street entrance—either place is a pleasant spot to pass the time with a Thai Singha or the borough’s own Brooklyner Dunkel-Weisse. The fountain (a leaky rowboat suspended from the ceiling) is soothing, as are the smooth deejayed sounds.

column163: Years ago, Planet Thailand was one of the first eateries to break through theNorthside's pizza/pierogi culinary barrier. Since then, the devotion ofgrateful Williamsburgers has allowed the Planet to expand to a scale more inkeeping with it's name. There's even room for instillation art like a leakyrowboat to be suspended from the soaring ceiling, while cider block walls andpolished concrete floors stylishly refer to the current space's former>industrial life. Along with expansion, sushi chefs and a full-blow Japanesesteakhouse (<) operation have materialized.No cause for alarm, both (Thai and Japanese) cuisines are wisely allowed toshine on their own without giving birth to any unsettling offspring. Be it asimple tuna roll to the showpiece 'Williamsburg Bridge' groaning with handrolls (2), sushi (7 pieces) and sashimi (9 pieces), the Japanese choices aremore than adequate to satisfy the contrary in any group. The best news isthat the Thai standards retain the freshness (and low prices) that madePlanet Thailand so indispensable to the neighborhood in the first place.Curries, like the vegetables with coconut, are bracing, the green papayasalad is tangy and the <<pad thai>> is still one of the best around, steeringclear of that insidious sweetness that's creeped into the dish at many of NewYork's Thai kitchens. And just when you think your taste buds are totallysatiated, here comes a snazzy ginger <<creme brulee>> to shake up them up.

column7: Times Square has provided a theme-park attraction for tipplers whose taste in drinking venues runs to the bizarre. From the moment you hop aboard the “interplanetary transporter” that takes you to the bar, you know this place is going to be a trip. The drinks are way beyond the Cosmos: Blast off with a frozen Mars-tini, perhaps a Meteor Shower (Berentzen Apple Liqueur and Absolut, garnished with a Granny Smith apple slice). Then slide into one of the grotto-like booths to zone out on videos being beamed in, ostensibly from the red planet. If the attractive aliens working the kiddie parties down in the restaurant would start taking their breaks in the bar, 2112 would be out of this world.

column7: If wine is your drink, then this is your bar. One of the city’s largest and most thoughtfully chosen wine lists includes plenty of offerings by the glass. “Whatever it is,” says wine director Tim Kopec, “we have more of it, we have better, and we have the most vintages.” Happy oenophiles often end up swapping tastes. While the restaurant is usually booked solid, the brick-walled bar area remains open to walk-ins. And only bar tipplers can get chef Scott Bryan’s chic, creative offerings à la carte.

column163: Named after the island that comprises Haiti and the Dominican Republic, Hispaniola serves exemplary West Indian food fused with Asian flavors. Chef David Nunez (small n needs a thing/tilda above it) has devised a menu with plenty of seafood: tuna tartar with avocado mousse and yucca chips and sea bass with plantain are among the appetizers, and salmon, tuna, whole snapper and an excellent steamed sea bass on garlicky mashed plantains with coconut and mango sauce are entree choices. Meat-lovers can select from rack of lamb, pork and beef dishes: highly recommended is the Argentinean skirt steak with chimichurri sauce. The portions are ample, but not too overwhelming, so you may have room for the pastry chef James Evangelosâs guava tart with vanilla ice-cream, or napoleon (chocolate, coconut cream, fresh bananas and caramel sauce between layers of pastry). The wine list is moderate-sized, but very good and wine by the (very generous) glass starts at $6. The atmosphere is refined and stylish without being stuffy. The service is perfectly pitched. One piece of advice: to secure an upstairs table with a view of the illuminated George Washington Bridge you should make a reservation.

column163: The retro '60s glass-and-metal façade, neon coffee-shop sign, and ludicrously unnecessary velvet-rope policy of the Coffee Shop in Union Square have become a New York institution. When the almost-twenty-four-hour haute diner opened over a decade ago, it was a perennial hot spot for model sightings and endlessly swarmed with sexed-up youngsters just on the verge of getting signed. But like any It-club, the luster starts to wear and hot young things begin to get replaced by cheesy bridge-and-tunnel renditions. The Coffee Shop still has its famous oh-so-comely wait staff and long lines for a table in either the large mirror-and-chrome front room or in the more private over-decorated World Room in back (complete with a roaring fireplace and a second bar). It also still has a very active people-watching scene at its snaking S-bar in the center. But for all its dark, broody fanfare, the menu remains just on the acceptable side of mediocre. The cuisine—like last season's models—is American with a Brazilian flair. But dishes that seem exotic in description, are rarely so inspired. The appetizer dumplings are more ravioli-like pockets stuffed with deliciously soft shrimp and caked in coconut. Unfortunately the dish gets drenched in a hopelessly watered-down mango puree. The hard-to-mess-up selections from the raw bar, like the oyster platter, and a range of basic salads are safer alternatives. The Brazilian-themed paella offers some more eclectic fish flavors, and entrees like the grilled salmon (alas, submerged in more mango) and a surprisingly generous rib-eye topped with a mushroom gravy are adequate eats. Thankfully, the Coffee Shop does do right by its various flavored caipirinhas, which can easily become both the main course and the main reason for staying late into the night. Crowded weekend brunches, the Union Square Lounge in the basement, and, in summer, outdoor tables set out along the sidewalk make Coffee Shop at least an all-access hangout—even if the high-fashion atmosphere has gone a little too department store.

column7: If a Las Vegas casino were to host a Day of the Dead celebration, it might look something like El Rey del Sol. A basement lair is festooned with color—bowls of fruit, strings of multicolored holiday bulbs, plaster Virgin Marys, wooden skeleton dolls and papier-mâché chili peppers. The young and thirsty convene around slightly sticky tables for platters of nachos and pitchers of El Rey’s famous fresh-squeezed fruit margaritas, which come in cantaloupe, orange, grapefruit and—the crowd favorite—watermelon. When the weather allows, take your drink to the pretty patio out back.

Dining rooms across the way offer views of the Hudson River, and the food is entirely worth staying for.

column7: All of the microbrews served at Heartland come from a Fort Greene brewery, so there’s a little touch of Brooklyn at the four Manhattan locations. Each franchise offers the Classic Voyage, a quintet of five-ounce brews that includes the award-winning Farmer Jon’s Oatmeal Stout, a dark-roasted malt with hints of chocolate and coffee. This Times Square behemoth is part of a full-menu chophouse, and offers an even wider selection of brews.

column7: This town is flush with creative happy-hour deals, but Five Points—a restaurant with a lengthy bar—is among the city’s most generous. Five-buck martinis and $2 oysters beckon discriminating skinflints between 5 and 6pm daily. Sip, slurp and take in the earthy decor, including fresh flowers and a trickling fountain. A couple of hours here could make even the crankiest New Yorker a little more Zen.

column7: Homey but chic, Savoy is a perfect fit on its quiet cobblestoned corner, just steps from the mad consumer superhighway of Broadway. The country-modern bar area at street level is dominated by giant picture windows and a horseshoe-shaped slab of black stone, surrounded by a dozen saddlelike stools. Savoy takes house-made to a delightful extreme: It marinates the olives, fries the free potato and yuca chips, and even cures its own sour cherries for Manhattans.

column7: An massive octagonal bar set smack in the middle of the warehouselike room encourages people-watching, and the tall stools give a bird’s-eye view of the exposed brick, hanging Art Deco–style lamps and framed paintings that make the space feel airy and calm. The all-star investors, principally Robert De Niro, make only rare cameo appearances these days, but their names guarantee a smattering of tourists among the Wall Streeters and locals. The always buzzing Tribeca Film Center is right next door.

column163: This Tribeca cornerstone needed a makeover, so it got one ñ starting with new chef Stephen Lewandowski. Although no oneís touching the interior ñ a mostly dignified menagerie of exposed brick, mod Tiffany-like chandeliers and paintings by co-owner Robert De Niroís father ñ there are brand new food and drink menus. This is riskier than it sounds: since the restaurantís 1990 opening, the massive space has reeled in a loyal mix of locals, bankers from across the street, and De Niro buddies and lackies from the adjacent screening room and production house, and nearby Miramax. (The place is a major party venue ñ officially and unofficially ñ for the Tribeca Film Festival.) In addition to the new dishes, such as a delicious gargenelli with a braised short rib Bolognese and a thin, sweetness-packed corn chowder, there are still a few perennial favorites, like arugula salad and seared tuna wrapped in nori. One need go no further for proof of the idiom that change almost always equals consistency.Ê

column7: Cajoling sugar daddies, burgundy curtains, slanted mirrors and candles add up to that brothel-cum-bistro look. Owner Cecelia Pineida Feret says that with “lots of reds, oranges, stained glass, wood—it’s very homey. It’s not a meat market.” DJs spin on Thursday nights, and a jazz duo plays on weekend nights (reservations are recommended). Tuesdays from 6 to 9pm, ladies get complimentary drafts and wine, and everybody snacks for free.

column7: Tourists love drag queens almost as much as the Statue of Liberty (who looks a little manly herself). At seedy Lucky Cheng’s, they can gawk to their heart’s content at the nightly shows, as karaoke addicts sip cocktails like the Pink Pussy (don’t even ask). Join in on a Liza, Babs or Diana tune. The bartender can be a bit snippy, the Madama Butterfly motif heavy-handed, and the music too loud, but proof of the formula’s success lies in its longevity: ten years and the shtick still sticks.

column7: Not many spaces recall the elegance of yesteryear as vividly as this hotel bar, a midtown fixture since 1936. A recent face-lift restored the famous simian murals, saving the Art Deco stunner from decay. Though expense-accounting executives have replaced the soigné celebs that once haunted the place (Tallulah Bankhead and Tennessee Williams were reportedly regulars), a glam sentiment still prevails. Sip a Capuchin Julep (bourbon infused with orange spiced tea, muddled cherries and oranges) and size up the moneyed crowd.

column7: A wait is almost guaranteed for a seat at this small Japanese bar with a 100-strong sake selection. You won’t get much in the way of guidance from the staff, most of whom speak little to no English. Look to your neighbors for suggestions—we like the smooth, dry urakasumi paired with snacks like pickled squid and rice crackers. Those who choose to forgo the rice wine for more Western tipples might have better luck: Sex on the Beach in Japan is the same as it is anywhere else.

column163: P. Diddy not only invented the remix, he invented the overpriced soul food restaurant. The rap mogul's Flatiron eatery wouldn't last four weeks if his name wasn't attached to it. The cuisine, a curious mix of Southern and Caribbean food that seems to have little organizing principle outside of "Puffy likes it," never measures up to the serious bling-bling prices. Nearly $25 for fried shrimp and french fries? Nearly $20 for blackened chicken with rice and beans? Nonetheless, Justin's evidently has many, many fans, and almost every night of the week the restaurant and bar are packed (starting late around 9pm) with a crowd that drinks, socializes or enjoys a meal at one of the beige leather banquettes as loud hip-hop and R&B music fill the room. It's an energetic scene to be sure, though you have about as much chance of spotting Diddy himself as you would stocking the Sean John racks at Bloomingdales.

column163: Cafe Luxembourg200 W 70th St between Amsterdam and West End Aves (212-873-7411). Subway: 1, 2, 3, 9 to 72nd St. Mon–Sun 9am–midnight. Average main course: $24. Prix fixe: $38.50. Amex, DC, MC, V.Cafe Luxembourg is nowhere near as storied an eatery as its sibling Odeon. Instead, it quietly proffers French brasserie classics not easily matched for the money. Chef Jay Lippin ably balances the flavorful sting of his horseradish crusted salmon with its softer flavors, including a beet sauce that draws jealous looks from diners nearby for its raspberry coulis redness. The frog's legs appetizer deftly allowed room for the meat's subtle flavors to come through amid brown butter, garlic and parsley, while the Luxembourg cassoulet of duck confit, garlic sausage, pork butts, lamb stew and white beans provides a hearty, rustic meat option. The tables are clustered closely together in traditional brasserie style, creating a bustling energy as the waiters shuffle through the tight walking lanes. Despite the clamor around them, respectful patrons in their 30s through 60s are mainly engaged in subdued private conversations. Seats beneath the large fresh flower arrangement add an enveloping bouquet to the meals.

column7: Storied and stately, Café des Artistes began life in 1917 as a commissary for creative types inhabiting the Hotel des Artistes, and it evolved into a clubhouse of celebrity and romance. Although the luminaries and eccentrics have been replaced by big-spending poseurs, Howard Chandler Christy’s famous wood-nymph murals still line the walls. At the intimate horseshoe-shaped bar in back, try the Simon, a rum cocktail named for the youngest child of owners George and Jenifer Lang.

column7: P.J. Clarke’s has been a beloved saloon since 1884, but the hard-drinking hacks, pols, molls and palookas of yore have been supplanted by Prada-briefcased execs, cashmere-clad couples and baseball-capped buddies. Restored to vintage perfection by a partnership that includes George Steinbrenner and actor Timothy Hutton, Clarke’s draws the likes of Johnny Depp and Bill Murray. Bartenders are polite, pours are generous and the chow is good Must-peeks: the Tiffany stained glass in the men’s room and the cozy dining alcove, where Renée Zellweger, Ashley Judd and Salma Hayek order steak to amp up their real-girl cred.

column163: At once a bar, restaurant, and Sunday-night jazz club, Walker's is Tribeca's living room. On weekends, it swarms with downtowners creating a happy, not hypey, buzz within its 19th-century brick walls. Rarified brews and creative salads appeal to loft-sharing MBA's and D-girls, flavorful steak and salmon beckon bedheaded couples, killer fries and pecan pie please young tastes and budgets. Tribeca may be Hollywood on the Hudson, but good chow, warm service and gentle tabs keep it real at Walker's.PLS. column163: Douglas Rodriguez's influence could be felt throughout the late ‘90s explosion of pan-Latino restaurants. From his early innovators Patria and Chicama sprang disciples who helmed their own kitchens, including both the original chef at Calle Ocho, Cuban Alex Garcia, and its current maestro, Peruvian Jorge Adriazola. In succession they’ve fueled the supernova and continued post-hype popularity of the Upper West Side's nuevo Latino giant. And giant it is. The dining room, which is nearly hidden from view from the tropical mod lounge in the front room, was originally the courtyard of a U-shaped hotel. Now, enclosed by a skylight, it's an atrium made less cavernous by a false ceiling of wooden slats that frames the room to look smaller than it is. Oversized, wavy lampshades and large-scale wall decorations also cut the room down to size for a mix of middle-aged cronies, families and couples in their 20s and 30s. The oft-praised lobster ceviche with mango-grapefruit mojo remains a must-try, or order the crispy snapper with malanga mash or sliced hanger steak over gallo pinto and fig sauce.

Sunday brunch features minipitchers of the usual accompanying cocktails.

column7: Not only can you participate in just about every sport imaginable at Chelsea Piers, you can rehydrate afterward at the city’s largest microbrewery. The cavernous Chelsea Brewing Company provides an insider’s view of the beer-making process (glass windows show the brewers at work) and a ringside seat on the Hudson River. Malty Sunset Red Ale is always on offer, or sample a seasonal brew like the refreshing, bubbly April Showers Spring Wheat.

column7: What inspires loyalty to a bar? At Dick’s, a semiseedy gay haunt that’s seemingly been around forever, the secret to its longevity is simple: This dark, unpretentious place is a reliable spot for grabbing a drink, shooting some pool, and chatting up strangers and regulars alike. You can show up alone or with pals, and women and straight folks are more than welcome. It’s also age-inclusive—you’ll find everyone from thirsty 21-year-olds to grizzled ancients with stories that would make you blush.

column7: When it opened in 1830, the historic Ear Inn was popular with colorful characters ambling in from the docks of the Hudson. The basic decor (dark-wood bar, wobbly tables and chairs, lots of retro ephemera) hasn’t changed much since, but locals continue to pack the place thanks to its relaxed vibe and historical charm. Free snacks such as fried chicken and sausages can be had weeknights from 4 to 7pm, mitigating any wallet damage wreaked by a few $6 pints of Guinness.

column144: Subway: C, E to Spring St; 1 to Houston St
column163: AmEx, MC, V.The Ear Inn is nothing if not enduring: itâs survived at the bottom of Spring St for almost two centuries. While the trendy bars that are opening around it favor recessed lighting and suede banquettes, The Ear Innâs wooden walls and floors are old and worn, the furnishings and bathrooms purely utilitarian. The food is simple too, as it should be in such a relaxed, neighborhood place. Appetizers include shrimp cocktail, smoked trout, and country pate, all for around $4. Most of the entrees change daily and are listed on a blackboard, but thereâs always a fish dish, a burger, and a roast. For dessert you can choose from three pies sitting on the counter between the dining room and the bar. Itâs all well-prepared, tasty and very reasonably priced, as are the dozen or so wines available by the glass. Best of all, you can sit there all night (perhaps doodling on the paper tablecloths with the complimentary crayons) and feel under no pressure to eat and run, thanks to the gracious staff. On Sundays the restaurant serves brunch for $8.50.

column7: The airy look of this vino destination brings to mind a winery tasting room, but it’s so much more. The 100 selections in stock cover the full spectrum of Italian producers, and 14 different flights allow for sampling by region or by varietal. The bar snacks prepared in the adjacent restaurant are a cut above—cheeses, salumi and olives are available on their own or combined in minicalzones. If you like what you’ve tasted, all bottles are for sale at Vino, the affiliated store across the street.

column7: This grand hotel saloon, whose centerpiece is a grandiose Maxfield Parrish mural of Old King Cole, is steeped in legend. The lounge’s best-known invention is the Bloody Mary—née the Red Snapper, right here in 1934. But these days, the drink leaves something to be desired: When we ordered the classic nip, the bartender sloshed a prebatched mix over vodka and ice chips, and give it an apathetic stir. The same indifference plagued a Manhattan, made with a sloppy gurgle of sweet vermouth, Michter’s rye and a standard-issue maraschino cherry. At $18 a pop, a little precision is in order.

column7: Twenty-five years ago, junkies and squeegee guys who worked the corner of Houston and Second Avenue were pretty much the only people who ventured inside. Even the CBGB punks from around the corner were afraid. And this survivor of New York’s down-and-out heyday is one of the last places left in the city where genuine outcasts and alcoholics still fit in. Have a “shot” of whiskey—it comes in a jumbo rocks glass, filled nearly three fingers high. That and a bottle of Bud will set you back $6.25. Destroying your liver was never so cheap—or so fun.

column7: Because real drinkers don’t take holidays, this place is open 365 days a year. The dark oak-and-mahogany bar, with 12 beers on tap, reels neighborhood and after-work crowds. Other pubs along Third Avenue seduce the frat pack with video games and pool tables, but McCormack’s is strictly old-school, with faux-Tiffany lamps, dusty knickknacks and free finger food at happy hour. And when the TVs are tuned to a rugby or soccer game, this is the rowdiest spot around.

column7: Ladies should probably leave the Blahniks at home. In traditional Irish-pub fashion, McSorley’s floor has been thoroughly scattered with sawdust to take care of the spills and other messes that often accompany large quantities of cheap beer. Established in 1854, McSorley’s became an institution by remaining steadfastly authentic and providing only two choices to its customers: McSorley’s Dark Ale and McSorley’s Light Ale. Both beverages have a lot more character than PBR, though at these prices, it won’t be long before you stop noticing.

column7: If you’re seeking civilized company of the upwardly mobile variety, join the well-coiffed after-work crowd at MercBar. The lodgelike interior, dressed up with landscape paintings and a canoe suspended above the sleek mahogany bar, feels like the tony lakeside cabin that belongs to your rich friend’s parents. Bartenders stick with the getaway theme, mixing the signature Vacation (rum, cachaça, pineapple juice and 7-Up).

The lone pool table in back sees more action than the star quarterback at the senior prom, and three songs on the rock-ruled jukebox cost just $1.

column7: This no-nonsense Nolita dive has an Italian moniker, but that’s where the affectations end. Suck in your stomach and squeeze through the narrow stretch between the bar and the clammy back wall, a bottleneck for the eclectic crowd of artists and perpetual barflies. You might need to holler your order over the juke’s noisy rock tunes—keep it simple and ask for the signature combo of Guinness and a shot of Jameson ($11).

Sink into a wooden booth and lap up a creamy Irish coffee with Bailey’s.

column7: A dance floor, show-tune-playing pianist and cabaret acts add up to the ultimate gay package at this long-standing haunt. The diverse crowd assembles for happy hour (get a buck off well drinks Mon–Fri 4–9pm and Sat 2–9pm) and sticks around for shows in the spacious basement. Drag queen Jesse Volt hosts High Voltage on Wednesday nights at 11pm, and Barbara Herr fires up another drag show, Sabor Latino, at midnight on Mondays. On weekend nights, the frisky go-go boys and upbeat atmosphere make the low cover charge ($3–$7) a steal.

column1: Classic NY spot
column7: You wouldn’t think of such a stunning classic as a backdrop to activism, but in the ’60s, Gloria Steinem refused to vacate the then for-men-only premises, even after the manager removed her table. And in 2003, the bar took a high-profile stance against Mayor Bloomberg’s smoking ban, until the ensuing statewide ban put the kibosh on the bar’s premium cigar trade. Still, the Oak Bar maintains the Plaza’s landmark status in the modern age (although the clientele may be stuck in a bygone era), and that extends to cost ($13 to $24 for a single-malt Scotch) and dress code (no jeans). Need we add there’s no jukebox?

column7: At first glance, O’Flaherty’s looks like an average pseudo-Irish pub (it might be the name), but in addition to the standard entertainment—pool table, darts, TVs—you’ll discover some unexpected pleasures. One front room has stacks of books to peruse, while another is an espresso bar. If it’s chilly, take a seat by the fireplace; in summer, relax in the garden. O’Flaherty’s serves several house brews, and during happy hour (noon to 6pm), pints of Bud cost just $3. Around 10:30pm, a guy with a guitar is likely to appear.

column7: Pete’s does its best to re-create an old-time Brooklyn longshoremen’s saloon—even if it’s too far inland to feel totally authentic. Upmarket offerings include a wide selection of microbrews (Victory Hop Devil, Green Flash IPA, Brooklyn Pennant), multiple ciders and snacks like ländjäger (a smoked pork-and-beef sausage). The tried-and-true burger-and-brew combo is a fine way to go too—true to Pete’s heightened pub gestalt, you can sub a wild-game patty in place of ground sirloin.

column7: It’s across the street from the Empire State Building, but this pub isn’t out to fleece tourists—a loyal (and local) clientele that favors three-buck Miller Genuine Drafts is proof of that. The site has housed a bar for more than a century, and the marble urinals and 140-year-old Tiffany glass wall were salvaged from the original Waldorf=Astoria Hotel. Not that there isn’t something to lure the occasional out-of-towner: a collection of 1,600 signed baseballs, including one from Joe DiMaggio.

column7: The circular bar at this comfortable neighborhood fixture, established in 1927, is packed almost nightly with postshow revelers seeping out of nearby Carnegie Hall. Sketches of bar patrons by contemporary artist Robert Cenedella (he’s captured regulars at Broome Street Bar as well) add a genteel touch to the mahogany walls, but most eyes focus on TVs showing a steady stream of sports. Crispy, beer-battered fish-and-chips complement a solid list of brews—21 on tap include Guinness and Blue Moon.

column7: The name suggests a wine bar, but patrons at this midtown drinkery tend toward the hard stuff. Sure, there are 15 vinos by the glass (among them Black Opal, a peppery Australian shiraz), but it’s the gargantuan martini selection that really blows us away: More than 200 of them—from the pomegranate-based Nadia’s Perfect 10 to the fruity Champagne Supernova—are named in the tome of a cocktail list. Paper-covered tables populate the front room, and postcurtain actors congregate in the back, where couches lend a coffeehouse feel. Stop by for a first date—the drinks make for fine conversation fodder.

column7: The ubiquitous Starck aimed for the mysterious here, combining blackboard walls of chalked “musings” with crystal chandeliers, and faux-fur throws with crisp-linen-covered couches. Smitten singles make out in murky corners, while chic hotel guests and after-work suits sip showy cocktails (the Cosmo was overwhelmed with raspberry puree; the Tanqueray martini was perfect). A DJ spins Thursday through Saturday; other nights can be eerily quiet. The real scene is at the Library Bar, on the mezzanine. The fashionably dressed, along with the occasional celebrity, loll in love seats and pashmina-covered couches. And the Tanq martini is two bucks less. Go figure.

Smashed into a brick wall up front is a scene of doll carnage—Guernica with an all-Mattel cast. Have another drink; you’ll figure it out.

column7: Hanging at Enid’s is like when you were a kid, spending the weekend at the cool house down the street, where you could play the most radical video games and the parents let you drink. There’s a life-size gold camel overlooking the ’70s-basement decor. The weekend brunch may well help that nasty hangover; on Sundays, Enid’s is the perfect mellow-date destination: Grab a cheap beer from the attractive bar staff and watch ’80s TV shows, play video games, or make faces for the vintage photo booth. You’ll never want to go home.

column163: The Heights Bar & Grill2867 Broadway between 111th and 112th Sts, second floor (212-866-7035). Subway: 1, 9 to 110th St. Mon–Sun 11:30am–2am. Average main course: $11. Amex, MC, V.In a rural college's student union, this place would be the popular bar and grill, a "Zeebee's" or "Pit Stop." The second-floor burger and burrito spot is in New York instead, but it's still got a college feel to it, owing in large part to its proximity to Columbia and a menu full of pub favorites, drink specials and flavored margaritas. The Ivy Leagers dominate the small, angular space come 10pm, but at lunch and dinner time a mix of young families, other locals and students fill the bunched up tables. The Mexican standbys, particularly the heaping nachos and burritos, incorporate noticeably fresh ingredients and have a leg up on the hit-or-miss burgers and popcorn shrimp. The windows that form the front wall and afford a tree-top view of Broadway are opened when it's warm, and so is a roof deck.

Step outside for a breath of fresh air on the terrace under the port-cochere on Vanderbilt Avenue, and you're surrounded by potted plants and signs of more recent times – placards exhorting “No Smoking.”

column7: In the afternoon, Eastern-European retirees and unemployed folks in their twenties and thirties take advantage of the fine stock of domestic beer and decent liquor starting at $3. At night, the grime-encrusted dive is the place for locals on a budget, who crowd into rickety booths and around the red-felt pool table while downing $15 pitchers of beer. Why blue and gold? They’re the colors in the flag: Forty years after opening, the bar is still owned by the same Ukrainian family.

column7: The bouncers at the door aren’t window dressing—they’re serious about keeping out the rough element that characterized this hangout for much of its 80-year history. True, the venerable dive has evolved, hosting events with such partners as Triple 5 Soul (there’s an occasional cover of $5) and adding DJs who spin jungle and new wave. It hasn’t evolved too much, though: 169 remains a satisfyingly obscure place to get a beer for $3 and, until it’s time to hide the pool table, pump the music and start dancing.

column7: Not one, not two, but three paintings by a certain Paul Joyce (great-nephew of James) adorn the back wall of this pub. That means we’re in Irish territory. In fact, the name of this bar is Emerald Isle slang for fish-and-chips, the house specialty. Order a basket and you’ll get flaky beer-battered cod fillets with a pile of crisp fries, perfect for soaking up malt vinegar. Wash ’em down with one of 12 beers on tap. Naturally, one of those is always Guinness.

column163: Proudly considered a Chelsea favorite by the post-workout, pre-XL bar crowd, Foodbar remains a place catering more to eye candy rather than consistent menu items. Dinnertime is packed with tables of two - surprising to see muscle distributed so equally among boyfriends. The dim light and subdued beat music are always perfect for gay courtship. "Appeteasers" such as the crabcake and the quesadilla with mixed veggies truly tease you into thinking that the entrees will be just as scrumptious. Alas, the weight-conscious clientele may be the reason why the food here lacks rich flavor or (dare I say) creamy calories. While offering multiple options of pasta, chicken, fish, and even steak dishes, Foodbar somehow manages to score high on presentation and low on taste. Angel hair with grilled sea scallops, tomato, and broccoli rabe was generous on the pepper and undercooked on the seafood. The tamarind-grilled salmon with lime leaf broth was black on top and accompanied by bland jasmine rice. If you actually splurge on dessert, steer clear from the dry chocolate truffle cake and definitely dig into the restaurant-recommended key lime pie. On the way to the restroom, get a load of the random cathedral-like setting of assorted Virgin Mary paintings. Maybe if you say your prayers beforehand, you and your date can skip dessert and head home early. For Sunday brunch, get an eyeful of the various guy gangs working off hangovers generated by last night's partying at Earth or The Roxy. Nothing beats male bonding over an $11.95 prix fixe meal or the hearty "Chelsea Boy Special" (4 scrambled egg whites, chicken breast, and steamed spinach).

Still unafraid?

column163: Even though it opened way back in the go-go late ’90s, the crowds are still spilling out the door for a sampling of Esperanto’s flash-in-the-pan-Latin menu. During prime chow-down hours, the staff actually does its best to keep everybody relatively happy, even providing a realistic E.T.A. column7: Semaphore flags, naval caps and sailboat photos give a classic Irish sports pub a nautical twist. Three floors—including an Astro Turf–patio—let you know this place means business. Tucked into this tourist-central location since 2000, the saloon attracts a steady stream of camera-toting visitors and semilocals alike. Fifteen beers on tap and drink specials help ensure that Hurley’s will stay afloat for the next hundred years.

column7: It’s only proper for an authentic chrome diner to focus on food, but Relish also offers a full bar to drinkers capping their night or just starting it. Although this isn’t a place to cruise, it’s perfect for a date, because it’s quiet enough to have a conversation. Groups of friends can hang in the black Deco room, which feels like a private lounge; smokers can relax in the humongous backyard. If you’re in the mood to eat, there’s no hipper diner-bar in Williamsburg...at least, not on this block.

column7: At one end of the bar, a waiter from Georgia decries the state of his country over a bottle of Baltika No. 3. At the other end, a wine-addled composer vaunts his latest unmounted musical. The Vodka Room’s wood-paneled darkness is a place of comfort for dreamers and eccentrics—even the Monday-night jazz trio looks quirky. Diners nod along to the mellow bass, and couples cozy up in the alcoves to sample infused vodkas. Live piano music is the official entertainment; regulars provide the sideshow.

column7: Take an architectural tour: This striking spot, located in the basement of Mies van der Rohe’s Seagram Building, was outfitted by Diller + Scofidio. It features backlit bottles stored horizontally behind opaque glass, a long granite bar and walls of curved pear wood. Neighborhood big-suits do business over chef Luc Dimnet’s French and Alsatian fare. If the patrons—who include a smattering of against-type tourists—don’t entertain you, the screens above the bar display stop-motion images of new arrivals entering the room.

column7: In New York City, Madiba captures the lively flavor of the i-shebeen, a drinking hall that is common in South Africa but not so much in these parts. The restaurant-bar has won over a diverse crowd. Patrons sit in mismatched chairs at tin-topped tables to enjoy the country’s wines, tasty cuisine and regular servings of live world music. Kick back with a beer and sample the Durban samosas (spicy vegetable triangles served with archar, a condiment made of pickled mango seeds).

column7: Beyond the bouncers at the ’30s-style supper club and lounge is an earth-toned oasis filled with curved banquettes, velour couches and leafy potted plants. The pulchritude of the clientele makes the long lines at the bar more tolerable, and Eugene’s signature drinks (like the $12 Stoli-based Jade Dragon) are tasty. A plethora of promoter parties means that most nights, you can avoid the $20 cover. And once you start moving to the DJ’s hip-hop, R&B and house stylings—played over a remarkable sound system—you’ll forget how much lighter your wallet has gotten.

But wait, there’s more: an intriguing mix of bar snacks (tikka masala, panini, potpies); deep house and hip-hop in the revamped downstairs lounge; and cozy, secluded booths. You’ll delight in seeing those relics of a bygone era—ashtrays—littering the bar. And you won’t be alone. Everyone from NYU kids to retirees regards this bar as a refuge from the Bloomberg-era blues.

column7: The tight fit and tiny tables at this sexy Spanish boîte make it easy to jump-start a conversation with a stranger. Shareable tapas (fried olives, salt-cod fritters) and stiff cocktails like the refreshing mango margarita (fresh fruit puree, just-squeezed lime juice and Herradura Silver tequila) help too. After 8:30pm on weeknights and Sundays, enjoy live music, including jazz and Cuban salsa.

column163: In this fashionably low-lit den, unassuming painted wooden tables showcase the vibrant traditions of Basque cuisine. You can taste the Mediterranean in the salt-cod stuffed piquillo peppers drizzled in basquaise sauce with a hint of armagnac. The attentive servers will be happy to educate you about the pintxos plate - a sampling of Basque tapas that changes daily. On one evening, this cornucopia held a blade of endive cradling aromatic Roquefort cheese and walnuts; a cigarillo-shaped pastry filled with mint-and-paprika-seasoned beef; savory albacore tuna salad spiked with anchovy atop a crunchy baguette; and the traditional tortilla espanola with egg, potato and onion. The assortment only faltered once with skewered morsels of octopus that were a tad over-cooked. Spain’s seafaring heritage shines in a paella replete with clams, mussels, calamari and shrimp, and cut through with the spice of char-grilled chorizo sausage. Other seafood on offer includes roast monkfish; Atlantic scallops; and tomato bouillon with monkfish, shrimp, mussels, and clams. Carnivores can feast on buttery filet mignon in a rich brandy and green peppercorn sauce, accompanied by patatas bravas – golden fried potatoes, perfectly shaped for dipping in a velvety aoli. While ordering dessert may not be top-of-mind at a Spanish restaurant, don’t make that mistake at Oliva. Try the cool vanilla flan glazed with black cherry confiture, or the warm chocolate almond torte – light, moist and not-too-sweet, it may just be the best dish on the menu.

column7: The Seventh Avenue digs of this congenial Italian wine bar are roomier than its East Village original, but the prices remain unchanged: Most small plates cost less than $8. Only one bartender caters to the after-work, wine-swigging crowd, but you won’t have to wait long before a thin-lipped glass is placed in front of you. A sandwich of Italian tuna and ripe tomatoes is sandwiched between slices of soft white bread. Grappa-soaked apples are paired with equally bold sidekicks of speck and Taleggio cheese in one of the pressed sandwiches. Desserts, too, are reliable, especially the dense pear sorbet.

column7: Sitting squarely on the boardwalk, Ruby’s has been weathered into a pleasing decrepitude. There has always been room for everybody in the hangar-like relic: Leather-skinned local old-timers, Hispanic families and black-clad, goateed hipsters with their tattooed girlfriends all sit together, enjoying the seabreezes that mingle summers present with those long past. Over a plastic cup of Bud draft at the grey formica bar or at a table laden with knishes or clams, they muse over Coney Island’s past glories or nothing at all.

column5: Sasha Petraske is the city’s most esteemed mixologist
column7: The only clue is an alterations sign in the window (the space was formerly a tailor’s shop). Even if you do find the graffitied door, you can’t simply walk in—you must text or email to reserve. Still intrigued? You should be. This stealth speakeasy will transport you to the 1940s: Sinatra croons on the sound system, couples chat in semicircular booths, and candles offer the only light. Owner Sasha Petraske can readily mix more than 400 drinks; yours arrives on a gleaming silver tray with a slender block of hand-cut ice. If you’re lucky enough to find the phone number, mind your manners when you arrive; house rules include “Gentlemen will not introduce themselves to ladies” and “Don’t invite anyone you wouldn’t leave in your apartment alone.”

column7: The W Hotel’s Wet Bar is the place for the young and the restless to get loaded and make out; think of it as a fancy frat party. In the space of an hour, we saw two women take a spill on the steps from the bar to the lounge area. We also spied a sixtyish businessman smooching with a much younger woman, oblivious to the crowd. Take in the chaos from a plush leather couch in the lounge, a dark room with a fireplace and pools of incandescent yellow and red light

column7: Leather-bound books line the walls of what was once the reading room of the Mansfield Hotel. Now a sleek circular bar sits beneath an ornate glass cupola, beckoning the thirsty midtown office set. A cocktail list features specialties like the Mansfield old-fashioned—whiskey, bitters, sugar, soda, cherries and orange. Visit on Wednesdays at 7pm, when there’s live jazz.

column7: Union Square’s dark lounge is outfitted with handsome walnut walls and a room-length oak bar plus an eardrum-piercing retro-rock and hip-hop soundtrack. After work, lawyers and bankers congregate on the tile floor to slap backs and sip fishbowl-size $10 dirty martinis delivered by efficient, little-black-dress–clad waitresses. Ties are loosened pretty quickly in this Scotch-and-soda crowd.

column7: Before Fifth Avenue was Park Slope’s most bustling nightlife row there was Loki (as in “low-key”). The neighborhood drinking establishment still has the bases covered: moderately priced beers, wines for every budget, a pool table, a dartboard, a well-stocked jukebox and a garden. Vets might be baffled by the presence of suit-clad Upper West Side types, but everyone seems to get along. That includes the occasional couple, who can retreat to the curtain-draped back room, where couches invite romance.

column7: Although there are 25 different beers on tap and 60 by the bottle at this airy trilevel pub, Guinness is the star: Thanks to the pricey Kilkenny cooling system, the black stuff tastes almost as good as it does on the Emerald Isle. Gaggles of Irish and other Euro expats take their pints at the enormous bar or small wooden tables. Retreat to the slightly quieter downstairs to tuck into pub grub like bangers and mash (available until 4am) in peace.

column7: Don’t let their contrived apathy fool you—the creative types gathered at the Half King’s yellow pine bar are probably as excited as you are to catch a glimpse of the part owner, author Sebastian Junger (The Perfect Storm). While you’re waiting, order a draft like Widmer, a cloudy Hefeweizen, or a specialty cocktail (we like the Parisian, made with Hendrick’s Gin, sauvignon blanc and elderflower liquor). A better bet for aspiring scribes: the weekly Monday night reading series.

column7: In 2002, the owners turned a neighborhood spot into a comfortable lounge, complete with a DJ booth in the back and Chimay at the bar. Furniture is bolted to the floor and a sign reads no dancing —but that didn’t stop a lively group from doing the Watusi next to their barstools. And even though La Linea instituted a dress code (no ball caps, hoodies, sports jerseys or tank tops), the crowd was not necessarily up to par on that score, either.

column7: This down-on-the-bayou joint ain’t fancy. Hard-working locals and tourists lured by the Southern theme come for the happy hour and the decor—hand-painted signs, mounted swordfish and a wooden kiosk that houses a raw bar. Snacks include creative adaptations of N’awlins favorites such as crab cakes and jerk-chicken heros.

column7: Shame is not an option at Waikiki Wally’s. Conceived by the owners of the nearby Lucky Cheng’s, the place goes all out with Polynesian kitsch—from the plastic lei presented at the door to the thatch-roofed bar, staffed by girls in bikini tops and guys in Hawaiian shirts. Cocktails rely heavily on rum, coconut and pineapple, but there are also martinis and Cosmopolitans. Just take your time—those silly drinks served in tiki mugs pack a punch. A few nibbles from the extensive menu (ribs, fish, salads) may help you last the night.

There are 150-plus wines by the glass, and 250 or so cheeses–enough permutations that you can forever swear off chardonnay and Brie.

column7: You know how some places just make everyone look better? Rue B is like that. Silver-blue banquettes line the walls, candles illuminate the polished-zinc tables, and photographs of jazz icons oversee the action (which includes nightly live music). Drinks are mixed with fresh-squeezed juice—the apple martini is made with Stoli, fresh apples and a touch of syrup—and they slide down all too easily. Draft beers include Guinness, Brooklyn Pennant and Brooklyn Pilsner; sangria and sake are also available. May as well tuck into some of the tasty nibbles on offer; you’ll be here awhile.

column7: Between unpretentious and run-down is Rififi, a dive bar with old-world charm. The popular back room is known to film geeks as Cinema Classics, which screens movies several nights a week; there are also occasional bands and burlesque shows. Rififi (the title of Jules Dassin’s heist masterpiece) has become a local hangout in its own right, and you can usually find clutches of hipsters engaged in serious conversation.

column7: Seeing bouncers and a velvet rope on a shadowy block of Fulton Street is surprising, in a good way but that’s how you know you’ve found the party. You’ll hear, and sometimes feel, the bass thumping half a block away. And once you’re inside, you’ll feel the love. The bar has made a name for itself in Brooklyn’s growing dance-party scene. If that isn’t your speed, drop by after work and recline while listening to the DJ’s quieter lounge and house.

The downstairs lounge is packed to the gills; try your luck in the mezzanine bar, which is less spacious but quieter.

column7: An anonymous cement facade makes it more hidden than forbidden. Still, winklepicker-shod bohos and NYU students manage to find the signless door, once neighboring joints are cashing out. The horseshoe-shaped bar is lit by flickering storm lamps; silent manga cartoons and kung-fu classics are projected onto the back wall. Around 2:30am, Alphabet citizens are joined by a surge of postshift chefs and baristas ordering sake and gimlets; elegantly plated black cod, sushi and dumplings are served till near closing time.

column7: The importance of a great neighborhood café cannot be overstated. This no-frills, longtime favorite is a sterling example of the genre. You can linger indefinitely over coffee or wine while reading old books or contemplating the meaning of life. By day, the Lotus Lounge serves good, cheap sandwiches and salads. Come dusk, laid-back types chat over low-priced draft microbrews and stiff cocktails.

column7: While the interior gets high style points, this is still just a friendly neighborhood place for beer—and drag queens. A pleasant mix of lads converge around the small tables up front and in the back room, which is full of inviting, get-comfy couches. Drinks are always stiff (bit o’ trivia: Queer Eye’s Kyan was once a bartender here), the crowd is good-looking, and DJs keep the place pumping. The divine drag shows (with Candis Cayne, Shasta Cola, Shequida, Aurora and Sherry Vine) take place Sunday through Thursday. Wanna-be divas like Tonya Harding and Tammy Faye Bakker have been known to stop by.

column7: Rocky takes its immigrant roots seriously. It’s named for the character James Cagney played in 1938’s Angels with Dirty Faces. Political posters of Jack and Bobby Kennedy dot the exposed-brick walls, and the jukebox is filled with Irish tunes. Evening activities keep the crowd lively— readings on Wednesdays, trivia on Thursdays (know your popes!) and live Celtic hip-hop on Friday and Saturday nights.

column7: Its art-covered white walls are perfect, its dimly lit double mezzanines are perfect, and its $10 Perfect Peach Martinis are...well, you know. The bar is known for its extensive wine list, and the food is an attraction, too—on Wednesdays, the kitchen serves a $14 whole-lobster special. Chill music, large banquettes and a healthy-sized bar make this lounge great for groups. An artsy crowd, yes. But on one visit, the TV behind the bar was surrounded by a rowdy tribe of sports fans cheering on the Bombers with the best of ’em.

column7: Endearing owner Reis Goldberg, who’s behind the bar most nights, has made all of the neighborhood’s diverse elements—yuppie newcomers, lifelong residents, artists, lesbians—happy together. Three levels ensure that there’s always a spot for quiet conversation as well as periodic jazz performances and poetry readings. Sit at the main-floor bar while you sort out the wine selections, or hit the pool table in the candlelit downstairs lounge. The backyard garden is open every day (weather permitting) until 11pm.

column7: Want to see how T.G.I. Friday’s would look if it were owned by the heavy-metal band GWAR? No fake Tiffany lamps or wacky street signs; walls here display disembodied doll heads, plastic skulls and a full-size coffin. Like Friday’s, it’s all surface: Aside from the kitty-litter stench of ratty couches, there’s nothing truly scary. If you can handle the phony dive theme, you’ll find cheap beer and a jukebox loaded with music that inspires vigorous air-drumming by the aging metalheads hunched over the bar.

column7: Drop in and join a mixed bag of happy, freaky East Village hedonists in search of (or in the process of stirring up) a good party. Drinks at Sin Sin are affordable and the happy hour is long: 1 to 8pm daily. DJs at upstairs Leopard Lounge span the globe from deep house and nu-jazz to drum ’n’ bass and underground hip-hop. Former Liquid Liquid frontman Sal Principato spins Afrobeat here on Sunday nights.

column7: It’s odd to call it middle-of-the-road, but that’s just where Flash Dancers falls in the Manhattan strip-club continuum. Neither skanky dive nor executive club, Flash Dancers delivers the T&A essentials in a clean, comfortable setting. Part with the cover charge and drink minimum, then join the carousers watching topless and soon-to-be topless women strut on a winding catwalk. A lap dance will cost you $20; back-massage specialists add another option for stress reduction. Remember to keep your hands to yourself.

column7: Dive doesn’t always equal dump. At Otis, a lounge crowd sips red wine while fratboys pound pints two stools down; plush couches flank a pool table bathed in cranberry light; and modern art hangs across from TVs tuned to ESPN, as Guns N’ Roses blasts from the jukebox. Attentive bartenders offer a refill as soon as your glass is empty, and if you need sustenance, they’ll supply take-out menus. This not-so-divey dive is as comfy as your living room.

column7: If you’re looking for the right place to break up with your significant other, consider the quiet bar at this intimate restaurant. Any inclination to make an emotional scene will be stifled by the room’s palpable serenity, and the lovelorn can console themselves with appropriately bracing drinks, like the fresh lime and ginger daquiri, and comforting fried bar bites, such as crisp oysters with lemon rémoulade. Sure, you dumped your honey, but you also gave them a taste of a great neighborhood bar.

column7: “I’m sorry, is my smoke bothering you?” asked a stylish young woman. She didn’t add “Too bad,” but she could have: This is one of the city’s few legal cigarette lounges. Some 150 exotic smokes are offered for sale; a “flight” of one of each brand is $1,500. The other tasting menu features such pairings as three special champagne kirs (apricot, raspberry and peach) with slices of rare filet mignon on a buttered croissant followed by Shepheard’s Hotel German cigarettes.

column7: You might ask à la South Park, “What the fuck is a Bavarian beer garden doing in Alphabet City?” Upon entering, you’d have your answer: It’s schvimming mit kustomers. After knocking back a few, you too will be shaking a tail feather.

column7: Body parts and booze are the hallmarks of this quirky drinkery. Energetic DJs spin an array of tunes to satisfy punk rockers and casual locals. Cocktails like Blue Balls and Ankle Breaker might make you feel like a cadaver the morning after, but you’ll love the affable bartenders and soft candle glow that fills the space. Co-owner Sean Hollitz plans to add X-ray–film lighting, and unmentionable men’s and women’s bathroom indicators.

column7: Parted velvet drapes reveal vaulted ceilings, plush banquettes and a backlit glass wall at this pretty boîte beneath the Bryant Park hotel. Ease into the luxe environs with one of 17 oversize cocktails, such as the Porn Starr (rum, kiwi-infused cognac and passion fruit puree with cranberry and pineapple juices), and bowls of gratis guacamole. The clientele (plenty of suits and halter tops) and music (was that Bone Thugs-N-Harmony?) aren’t quite as fabulous, but it’s a worthy trade-off for such glam surroundings.

column7: Once a taxi garage, the chichi Park is now a vast, multiroom bar gorgeously appointed with hanging lanterns and extravagant floral arrangements. MePa revelers not put off by the icky velvet rope amble through the indoor and outdoor spaces, clutching well-crafted cocktails like the Sexy Bitch (peach vodka, pineapple juice, mango puree and grenadine). The rooftop, when not booked for private parties, is a rare urban oasis. Exhibitionists can bring along bathing (or birthday) suits for a dip in the hot tub.

Tournaments can be serious business with this crowd; order up a Jameson and watch a motley crew run the table. Think of it as an urban Discovery Channel.

column7: It’s no bungalow; it’s more of a chateau. If you can negotiate your way past the attitude at the door, you’ll find $12 champagne cocktails and such light bites as a $26 lobster club sandwich. Then use the concierge service to book your last-minute helicopter ride to Atlantic City. These luxuries belong to a decadent era long past, and to an indulgent crew in the present, but the castle’s a fun place to visit—if you’re prepared to spend royally.

column7: This larger branch of tiny Bread is more downtown, but more grown-up. The drink menu lists a wide variety of Cosmopolitans, martinis and top-shelf liquors, as well as an impressive selection of wines. (Beer gets only a nod, and nothing’s on tap.) The service is very accommodating: When our Cosmo with a lychee-basil twist didn’t quite work out, the bartender willingly replaced it with a Maker’s. About the only concession to bardom is the TV off to the right. It’s a plasma screen, of course, and it wasn’t playing sports. No, this crowd called for Flashdance.

column7: The same aesthetic that works so well at Boat and Great Lakes (same owners) is in play here—votive candles, found art, comfy couches and a killer jukebox. No fancy libations, just eight beers on tap, eight more in bottles, and the standard wines and liquor. Still, the bar has the same clientele as its flashier neighbor Quench: folks who listen to classic Gen-X sounds and gab on the latest 65k-color cell phones. Games like Clue and Yahtzee are on hand but don’t get much use; at the Roxy, simpler pleasures take center stage.

column7: Ninth Avenue in Hell’s Kitchen was once populated by winos; now oenophiles line up at this slice of Paris, eager to taste selections from the 300 varieties kept in a cellar that once served as a bank vault. Wine director Sterling Roig has received accolades for putting together an eclectic list with overlooked vintages from France’s Languedoc-Roussillon and Loire regions, and Sardinia and Sicily, in Italy. More than a dozen wines are sold by the glass.

column7: This noisy, singles-friendly, packed-to-the-gills bar, just steps from the TKTS booth, has probably been the scene of more than a few hookups. A school of fish is suspended overhead, and a staircase floats up to the dining area, decorated with backlit faux-tortoiseshell panels and mod white chairs. The kitchen cranks out crowd-pleasers such as sesame-crusted bigeye tuna with ginger-soy vinaigrette and pan-seared halibut with lemon herb gnocchi and petite portobello mushrooms. The crab-cake appetizer, with an accompanying sweet-and-sour cucumber salad, is the perfect way to start reeling in your own catch of the night.

column7: This brasserie may lack the seedy intrigue of the Paris nabe it’s named for, but it still has that famous je ne sais quoi. Pigalle is an after-theater spot for actors, a munchie rescue station for drooping club kids, a restaurant worker’s rest cure—and a bustling breakfast café. The menu is traditional French; overnight offerings include omelettes, croissants and luscious homemade desserts. Wines by the glass are $7 to $10; the beer selection includes many imports. If a weekend jaunt to Paris is out of the question, Pigalle may be the next best ticket.

column7: Cozy red booths in tufted red velvet, serious French food...on Amsterdam Avenue? Owner Ed “Jean-Luc” Kleefield’s modern bistro is a bona fide hit. No doubt this is partly because Julio Quisbert (Raoul’s) now runs the kitchen, and Karl Kozel, former Balthazar bartender, consults on the wines. The front saloon, decorated with antique mirrors and mahogany tables, is a smoldering singles’ scene. You want the sangria—don’t be daunted by the inclusion of Coke and cinnamon schnapps.

column163: Jean-Luc507 Columbus Ave between 84th and 85th Sts (212-712-1700). Subway: B, C to 86th St; 1, 9 to 86th St. Mon–Sun 5:30pm–midnight. Bar Mon–Sun 5:30pm–2am. Average main course: $23. Amex, DC, Disc, MC, V.As recently as the late '90s, observers from critics to diners declared the Upper West Side the frontier of Manhattan perhaps most neglected in its desire for high-quality restaurants. The idea that this was a myth was novel enough to be a publishable column. Newcomers at the time, Calle Ocho, Ruby Foo's and Ocean Grill were hailed as significant steps in the right direction, and since it opened in 2001, artistically appointed French eatery Jean-Luc has certainly joined them. Chef Eric Le Dily brings his experience at Raoul's to the notable grilled red snapper with earthy red beet gnocchi and an array of immaculate appetizers. Shrimp Napoleon in champagne sauce and bison carpaccio serve as estimable supporting players to the tarragon-tinged lobster bisque. A singles scene of West Siders in their 30s thrives at the large bar area in the front of the space, while families, retirees and the young and beautiful take to the ostrich-leather banquettes of the dining room. Regardless of where they're sitting, patrons should avail themselves of a wine list specifically created to vie for a Wine Spectator award, assembled by David Sturno, "21" Club's sommelier.

column7: All sleek white interior, artful track lighting and modular seating, this hideaway oozes Barbarella cool. A long, narrow front room leads to a small dance floor and DJ station (Latin, house, hip-hop and funk tend to rule the turntables). Rum is a house specialty (some 50 varieties), but bartenders are knowledgeable enough to fix any number of exotic combos. The phrase lawsuit waiting to happen will inevitably come to mind as you climb the metal ladder and scramble through the tiny porthole leading up to the roofdeck (open Fridays and Saturdays, May through October). Band occasionally play up here, and bar service is available—but be careful not to indulge too much: That ladder is even scarier on the way down.

column163: Carne2737 Broadway at 105th St (212-663-7010). Subway: 1, 9 to 103rd St. Mon–Sun 11:30am–midnight. Bar Mon–Sun 11:30am–2am. Average main course: $17. Prix fixe: $20.02. Amex, MC, V.Add "for the neighborhood" to just about any accolade conferred upon Carne's meat-and-more cuisine. Go ahead -- it's as fun as tacking "in bed" to the end of your fortune. There's nothing so upscale and ambitious as Carne in this tweener zone of the Upper West Side south of Columbia, and the eatery's reputation is a benefactor. The percolating dining room's Mid-Century Modern design with large, hoop-like hanging lamps, flowing orange drapes and central communal wood table rightfully attracts energetic locals of varying ages. In keeping with the name, a meat-dominated menu ranges from skirt, rib eye and strip steaks to creative American chicken, pork and fish dishes. Patrons get what they pay for from many entrees, including a respectable $20 filet mignon that otherwise would appear to be a bargain. Mussels in chipotle broth, duck confit salad and Japanese eggplant typify the laudable selection of international starters, although a seared foie gras overpowered by its eggy sauce leads the list of appetizers prepared non-traditionally or just plain off. There's work to be done, but it's fantastic for the neighborhood.

column163: What is it about this upscale pan-Korean restaurant, which opened last April, that makes it so late-'90s? Is it the meditative floating-candle pond in the front window? Is it the long wood bar with a lit-up distressed-glass base and an open DJ booth perched overhead? Is it the soothing muted-cream back lounge outfitted in roomy booths and antique chandeliers, and sprinkled with comfortable leather loveseats? You bet. But mostly it's Anju's whole communal feng-shui philosophy to dining that makes the restaurant seem to belong to that novelty fusion era of the moneyed 90s when Eastern ethos and spalike food therapy was served with a lofty price tag and without a hint of irony. At the top of Anju's menu, there is a little blurb about "holistic consciousness," the value of sharing with friends, and mind, body, and spiritual interconnectedness. But even for those who don't need an emotional upgrade at dinner or who like when only their silverware touches their entree, Anju provides some intriguing leaps with cuisine. The dining room is cordoned off to the front area of the airy high-ceilinged space, with chairs and banquettes situated underneath a wall of intersecting wood slats and a view of the street. Six-figure-salaried couples and young groups of Korean friends fill up the tables, sipping the bar's signature exotic cocktails (complete with names like "Apparition" and "Eclipse"). Anju also boasts an impressive wine list, not only separated into red and white but further divided by mood (Seductive, Meditative, Rejuvenating, or Luscious). But it's really the food where Anju makes up for its new-age mentality. Anju is Korean for "plate" and the menu is divided into dishes of small or large portions (presumably based on how much you want to share). Start with Anju's specialty rolls, four fresh shrimp wrapped with raw carrot and drizzled in a sweet honey mustard. The dish's simplicity emphasizes the kitchen's attention to pure, profound ingredients. The barbecue offerings are probably the most popular fare, mainly because a small earthen grill is placed in the center of the table, and raw paper-thin slices of bul go gi (rib eye) or kal bi (short ribs) are served for DIY grilling. Wrapped in a lettuce leaf with sliver of beets and dipped in one of three sauces, the first-rate quality of the meats is indeed enlightening. The fish and noodle section is equally life-affirming (particularly the house-recommended black cod simmered in a heavenly spicy, garlic reduction), but don't be surprised if, by the time the entrées are served, a red-rope is placed at the door, house music blares at full volume, and the feng-shui attitude is quickly replaced with lusty guidos and bridge-and-tunnel fashion nightmares cruising each other. Quickly the dining room becomes an extension of the dance floor, leaving many customers to cancel orders for a liquid dinner, or flee the embarrassingly bad nightclub scene entirely. Anju does have a small red-and-pink-colored side room downstairs called the "sake therapy lounge," which boosts eight house-customized sake drinks, but if that isn't enough of an asylum, better as a rule to eat early and leave when the DJ rolls his records in.

column7: On a sketchy stretch of Fulton Street, next to a nondescript diner, this no-frills bar is keeping a low profile—which is just fine with the locals who frequent it. Settle into one of the well-used couches or chairs just inside the door, or grab one of the high tables along the exposed-brick wall. If you’re feeling talkative, the bartenders are happy to chew the fat. Or you can just settle in and enjoy the ball game on the projection TV. It’s your call.

Trailer Park’s signature big gulp is a strawberry margarita ($5 during daily happy hour from 4 to 7pm).

column7: The best thing about this Slope spot is its jukebox, which is stocked mostly with homemade mixes. CDs are constantly rotated in and out, but if you settle into one of the joint’s wide wooden booths over a pint of foamy Boddington’s, you might hear Pavement, the Cramps and Hank Sr.—sometimes all on the same disc. The staff is so dedicated to its refined musical selection that when a White Stripes song began to get hefty radio play, it was cut.

column7: The proliferation of luxury-hotel bars—from the stalwart Four Seasons to the Matsuri at the Maritime—makes Morgans feel a little shopworn. Until you’ve had a drink or two, the place looks like what it is: a small, dressed-up basement. The overall aesthetic is louche-baroque, with red-velvet drapes, tufted ottomans and delicate chandeliers. Because this is Ian Schrager’s debut hotel bar, cocktails still run $12, but the tab seems excessive in a space that has seen better days.

column7: The plainspoken name, the American flag... Get it? It ain’t no disco, it ain’t no party, it ain’t no foolin’ around. The walls are covered with vintage steins, coasters and other paraphernalia celebrating beer. Instead of happy hour, there’s a monthly beer special, with a pint of a select brew going for $2 at all hours. Add better-than-average pub grub, and it’s clear why the raucously good-natured crowd has found this to be a perfect refuge.

column7: Outside, a smiling, six-foot fiberglass pig beckons—apparently unaware that, inside, his porker brethren are being doled out in the form of glistening hot dogs, gas-station food-mart style. The huge selection of beers (including house brand Rudy’s Red Ale), the strong $3 well drinks and the rock-and-blues-heavy jukebox bring together khaki-clad office types and grizzled neighborhood regulars. Don’t bother asking for a fancy cocktail—it ain’t that kind of place.

column7: Romance comes in two flavors at this Spanish tapas restaurant. On the main floor, a long wooden bar leads to the back dining room, where bartenders serve excellent sangria and the lighting is sultry. Things are quiet during the week, but on weekends, downtowners come out to play. The Gaudí-esque lower level is a bejeweled blue grotto where, later in the week, DJs amp up the volume.

column163: Visit the entire country of Spain in Salaís diverse and delicious menu>in an atmosphere that caters to ideas of what Spain might be like:>dark, romantic, and later, pretty boisterous.  You might start with>some pinchos from the Basque region in Northern Spain. Theyíre tapas>that sit on a slice of thick, crusty bread, like four strips of duck>breast, topped with balsamic vinegar and shallots, or roasted marinated>pork with gruyere on another. Or you may want to order a raciones, a>more traditional kind of tapas, big enough for sharing. The grilled>calamaris racione were sweet, plentiful and perfectly textured: chewy>without the slightest bit of rubberiness. You could easily make a meal>out of snacking on the pinchos and raciones, but then youíd be missing>out on all the entrees, like the roasted lamb shank sitting on top of a>mound of fried potatoes, Segovian style, or tender sea bass. You can>sit upstairs in the dining room, or sprawl out on Morroccan-style>benches in the blue-walled lounge downstairs. Later in the week,>however, you may have to share that lounge with a dj and a partying>crowd. Thereís flan and profiteroles for dessert among other familiar>standards in case you must indulge your sweet tooth, but with the>treats all over the rest of the menu, why save room?

column7: Once a bar of the moment, Sugar’s current status is crystal clear: It’s dissolving. The few customers more likely arrived via E-ZPass than MetroCard; Jennifer Beals vaults silently across a large-screen TV; and Michael Jackson, playing on the decks, sounds nostalgic for the days when Billie Jean would’ve wanted to be his lover. Despite the ongoing hipness of Thriller-era fashion, the spot has traversed the route from cool stop to total waste of cash. If you must go to Sugar, do it on a Tuesday night, when filmmaker Dahlia Smith hosts a booze-soaked screening of watch-worthy short flicks. Otherwise, look for your sweet-hot action elsewhere.

The honeyed tea is similarly snappy, and a post-theater crowd regularly fills the dramatic 5,000-square-foot space and plays in the labyrinth of leather couches.

column7: A stylishly restored trilevel space with bordello-red walls, Victorian-style lamps and Berenice Abbott prints, this place is part restaurant and part lounge, part nostalgia and part postmodern. At the fieldstone bar in front, toast your ancestors for braving the trip, just so you could someday down a French Hooker while listening to Brazilian jazz. If you can get a seat in the wee lounge upstairs, try a Chilean cabernet and let your thoughts fly through the skylight. A DJ drops by on Fridays and Saturdays.
