column7: Another sign of civilization’s decline: Bars with “Blarney” in the name are becoming an endangered species in this town. Thank goodness the Blarney Cove is still in business. A pitcher of brew never runs more than $12 (Guinness and two kinds of Bud are also on tap), and most drinks are $4. The jukebox offers few surprises, with the notable exception of Linkin Park, which it seems to favor when left unattended. As night comes on, the blue-collar crowd yields to disaffected youth, but this is one place where we can all just get along.

column7: Here’s the bar version of that grungy but fun-loving kid in the next dorm room. He parties all night and plays his out-of-tune electric guitar far too loud, yet you can’t help but love the guy. The sweet weeknight bartender at Fred’s still enjoys his job after five years, and won’t hesitate to explain the place’s idiosyncrasies—like the “Leave a Drink” board, where you can prepay for an absent friend. He says that on an average night, he knows 99 percent of his customers by name, and insists that even if the live music downstairs is not consistent, he has more fun here than anywhere else he’s ever worked. Fred’s room may be a mess, but this spaced-out kid sure knows how to have a good time.

column7: Rodeo Bar The honky-tonk shtick gets maximum play at this Gramercy roadhouse, where antler chandeliers and a stuffed bison are suspended above rowdy tipplers in the main bar. Take it all in from the semisecluded lounge upstairs and sample from among eight margaritas, including pomegranate and prickly pear. Bonus: Free live music (alt country, country and bluegrass) plays nightly, and a five-spot gets you a margarita during daily happy hour from 4 to 8pm.

column163: You may not think a giant stuffed buffalo or a rusted red-white-and-blue grain silo make for sensible New York dining décor. But the wonderful thing about Rodeo Grill is when you step foot inside this large converted horse trailer, you kiss the city goodbye and say hello to the rootinâ tootinâworld of the west. The gigantic silhouette beam of a cow skull projected onto the next door building beckons an eclectic but loyal crowd of local country-music folk, Manhattan natives who miss their Texas home, and foreign tourists who want a different taste of the old USA. But whoever is crowded around the bar or eating at the tables, they all get to enjoy the free live music, ranging from country to rockabilly, alt country to bluegrass that plays nightly. Of course even when the bands arenât twanging, the wagon-wheel lamps, antler chandeliers, ropes, saddles, neon beer signs, and rodeo memorabilia set the right mood for the extensive Tex Mex menu. Start with the cowboy kisses, succulent shrimp covered with a fried jalapeno pepper and wrapped with a strip of bacon. The appetizer comes with a watery chipotle sauce, but even alone, itâs hotter than a firecracker in August and too darned delicious to stop. In terms of entrees, most of the menu sticks to traditional Tex Mex favorites-three-cheese quesadillas, chicken fried chicken, and some seriously rich barbequed ribs and chicken are among the hits. The crispy catfish, served with mashed potatoes with the peels thrown in, is surprising light underneath its potent fried crust and the moderately priced Texas steaks are as tender and juicy as anything served this side of the Mason Dixie. Houston would be proud. Of course, washing it all down with one of the Rodeoâs famous $26 pitchers of frozen margaritas (it comes in six different flavors) will have you singing like Johnny Cash and staggering like Vince Gill in no time. Just remember to shed the honky-to

column7: Rock cred abounds at this Billyburg spot, owned and staffed by members of local bands the Rogers Sisters and Oakley Hall. Despite potential for music-snob tude, the bar is surprisingly inclusive. The drinks transcend the average dive’s: The signature Margaveza features a pint of lager topped with a green frozen margarita. Five-buck artisanal ales like Blue Point Toasted Lager anchor the lineup of drafts. Daddy’s doesn’t host live acts, but there’s an impressive jukebox, and DJs throw down anything from Willie Nelson to MGMT. The ’hood may be barreling toward boutiquedom, but here’s one place that straddles the line.

column163: Subway: B, Q to 57th St. AmEx, Disc, MC, V.With all of the hubbub surrounding Brasserie 8 1/2’s demonstrably minimalist-modern digs, it’s a wonder that people actually come to this restaurant to eat rather than ogle. Designed by Hugh Hardy and situated in the eye-catching Gordon Bunshaft building, the main showstopper is the snaking staircase that segues the otherwise upwardly mobile and polished clientele down into the lounge and dining room. Ferdinand Léger’s only known stained glass piece, which divides the open kitchen from the dining room, is an attraction unto itself. And who wouldn’t want to stare at the rest of the room from extra-deep leather banquettes—simply made for intimate under-the-table moments? While this spot might be a beacon for fans of buffed chrome and sweeping Guggenheim-esque spaces, Brasserie 8 1/2 serves up more than song and dance. While incumbent bistro classics like steak frites and côte de boeuf paired with airy pommes soufflés shine, chef Julian Alonzo, who studied under David Bouley and Paris’s Guy Savoy, takes a cue from his surroundings and throws in some modern angles. Black sesame-flecked tuna tartare with passion fruit cream and grated-at-your-table wasabi will entice you to boycott single-minded sushi, and a crispy jumbo-lump crab cake finds a fresh edge in its sidekick salad of sea beans and razor-thin artichokes. As you pause for breath in between courses, take a gander around the room. Matisse artwork dons the walls, and if looked at from the lounge, the Léger glasswork makes sense as a design element rather than a dining room diversion. The unpretentious and pulled-together vibe plays out in the white-chocolate mousse and devil’s food cake ring ding. It’s delicious enough to make you forget about the artwork and the ambience and devote all of your attention to what’s on the plate.

column7: This smart little wine bar appears out of nowhere on a bleak industrial stretch in Woodside. Though it’s tiny, the atmosphere is intoxicating: Candle wax drips slowly down brick walls, and on most evenings the sounds of live singing drift in from the neighboring restaurant.

column7: Local cool kids—and some refreshingly room-temperature types as well—crowd the scruffy basement (the “den” part) of a popular Chinese restaurant (the “bistro” part) all week long. Thursday through Saturday, entertainment might include an acoustic house band, spoken-word or party-jam DJs, and there’s Sunday-night hip-hop karaoke. Exotic specialty drinks are well mixed (cocktails are half price on weekends from 2 to 4am), and Rheingolds are always $3. Don’t miss the hangover-friendly dim sum brunch, served every Sunday in the main space upstairs.

column7: Forget Chelsea. You can satisfy your bulging-bicep fixation at an East Side bi-level haunt for muscle queens and downtown hipsters alike. The bar offers the perfect vantage point to survey the prey, both in the room and on the bar: Go-go boys strut in thongs and tall black boots—right over your drink—to the latest deejayed remixes. Check out the drag show on Sundays or go for broke on Bingo Mondays. Ass Wednesday, hosted by Flotila DeBarge, brings out all the boys vying to show their stuff to win $100 in cash.

column163: 205 East 4th Street between Avenues A and BSubway: 6 to Astor Place; F to Second AveThe East Village is sprinkled with dozens of yuppifiedauthentic-Italian trattorias and cafes. Assenzio, which opened in November of lastyear, is the newcomer to the family. This Italian hotspot isn't going forthe "just like grandma's kitchen" slant but instead takes the romanticwood-paneled candle-lit wine-bar approach to new ends, thankfullyinjecting the dusty genre with a certain youthful downtown edge. "Assenzio"is Italian for absinthe, the infamous liquor banned in the U.S. for itshallucinatory effects. Here, prepared without the illegal wormwood, thebar offers ten varieties of the bohemian green fairy, as well as anextensive wine list of reds and whites imported directly from themotherland. Bottles range from a $29 montepulciano to a $155 bottle ofperfectly aged full-bodied amarone. Whatever the spirit, the real surprise isthe menu. When authentic Sardinian dishes aren't offered flat out, theregional island's flavor invades everything from the insalate to thetaglieri. The standard options are not always the most extraordinary—thecarpaccio and cheese platters offer a little too much drizzled olive oilto compensate for the skimpy amounts of thin-sliced meets on a crispSardinian cracker bread. But more unusual dishes make up for lost time.The gnochetti sardi explodes with tiny croissant-shaped dumplingscovered in a heavenly wild boar ragu. The kitchen is more than capable atusing spices to enhance, not hide, its pastas. In another regionaldelicacy, the Sardinian suckling pig is a juicy sidekick to roasted artichokehearts and pecorino cheese. Flickering candles decorated withmagnifying glass sets a romantic mood, but the wine bar doesn't stay old-worldfor long. On Friday and Saturday nights the turntables in the diningroom finally see some action, turning the serene décor into a house-musicparty more fitting to the new-world flavor of the neighborhood.

column163: Directly across the street from the Brooklyn Academy of Music is>glowing yellow bistro called Thomas Beisl. In Vienna, a ìbeislî is a>place where all kinds of people can meet up, from executives to>students to society ladies to old men. This is part of the vision that>chef Thomas Ferlesh is bringing to life in his bright yellow bistro and>bar. Serving a mix of Viennese classics and traditional bistro food,>there are delights at every turn. The chicken liver pate is both>creamy in texture and dense with liver, served with a cranberry compote>that makes a sweet-tart cut into the creaminess of the pate, the>breaded mushrooms seem to explode in your mouth. While Ferlesh, who>was a ìstar chefî at the age of 23 at Vienna 79, and the went on to>spend ten years at Café des Artistes, wants to reproduce the>traditional, he has made a few twists. The guylash is served with beef>cheeks, making the sauce all the more rich and deep, and the spaetzle>alongside it is pleasantly chewy and sauce-friendly. The sauerbraten>comes with a nearly candied red cabbage, spiked with cinnamon and>pulling out the flavor in the meat. In addition to the Viennese>cuisine, thereís also a more traditional bistro menu with burgers,>sandwiches, cheese and charcuterie plates. The wine list is made up of>Austrian, Italian and French wines, including some delicious reds and>the always-sensational Grüner Veltiner. The crowds are dense and itís>recommended that you reserve, as it appears as though the entire>audience at BAM marches across the street for dinner every night. In>the spring, Thomas Beisl will be opening a garden patio, which will>hopefully help with the heavy demand for their cuisine. For dessert,>the linzer torte, reputed by Austrians about town to be better than>anything you can find in Vienna, has a crust made with half almonds,>half hazelnuts. Get it mit schlag and two forks, itís heavy and>delicious. The menu changes with the seasons, so be sure to come back>and see whatís new at Thomas Beisl.

column7: A stylish crowd gathers at the stainless-steel bar of this classy joint on still-gentrifying Flatbush Avenue. The Trinidadian owners pride themselves on unusual drinks: Their mojito ($10) gets a twist of mango and tamarind, and rum shots ($5 each) are infused with ginger, rosemary or ginseng for the botanicals’ reputed healing properties. On Tuesdays, ladies can “be healed” for half price all night as they dance to calypso, hip-hop and reggae.

column163: Chef Phoebe Gumbs' Pan-Caribbean food would taste good anywhere, but if you findyourself under warm, yellow light at a table prettified by tall vases ofbanana leaves, the flavor seems just right. With Sugarcane, Trinidad-bornowners Charmaine Gumbs (little sister of Phoebe) and Gaspa Rodriguez havebrought a flash of class to a mostly-dull stretch of Flatbush. A stainlesssteel bar plays off the mirrors hung on the walls, and a hardwood floor thecolor of sand makes the space feel larger than it is. Settle into a cozycorner booth and prepare to stuff yourself; a menu that includes ital stew,plantain-encrusted red snapper, tangy guava-glazed ribs and choices of twofree sides with every main course (pigeon peas, fried plantains, callaloocreamed kale and others) can make for bigger eyes than mouths. The mostpopular dish, jerk chicken, arrives with a medley of West-Indian rootvegetables that calms the cayenne heat nicely. After 9pm on most weekends,patrons eat to live calypso or reggae. Notable oddity: the women's roomcontains two gleaming stainless steel toilets, side by side, without stalls.

column7: There’s a reason this place feels so authentic—just about every square inch was schlepped from the Emerald Isle. A knotted floorboard comes directly from an Irish hotel; the makeshift still was constructed in County Cavan; and Gaelic bands rock out live every night. Eight taps, made specifically for the pub by Guinness, pour the black stuff almost exclusively. You can get Bud here, too, but why would you want to?

column7: Irish pubs are a dime a dozen, but very few possessa history as star-studded as this one. Sidle up to the oak bar for a few shots chased with the house’s own McManus Ale; if you get lonesome, slip into one of the two old-school telephone booths and drunk-dial.

column7: When current proprietor Tom Chahalis’s father and uncle first opened this place in 1942, an Austrian gentleman they had met on the boat over to America became a regular patron but couldn’t cover his bar tabs. He wound up paying for his beer with art, which explains the Teutonic landscape murals on the walls and the soldier diorama tucked away behind a TV in one corner. Everything else is textbook dive, from the outside signage to the cheap drinks and classic-rock jukebox.

column7: If you like beer and brown liquor, you could do worse. Five dollars buys a bucket of four Rheingolds, and there’s a shelf lined with good Irish whiskeys behind the bar. Ten TVs should satisfy anyone looking to catch a game, and a dartboard and a pool table are available if you feel like playing. The bartenders give warm welcomes to Timboo’s regulars, calling them by name and opening a bottle of beer before they sit down. Martini sippers are advised to turn back to the trendy part of Fifth Avenue.

column7: Never again let anyone say there aren’t any good bars near Penn Station. This Irish pub is a cut above, with a handsome interior (two bar areas and a dining room) and a clientele to match. (The name means “land of eternal youth,” but the commuter and MSG crowd is a little more varied than that.) Nary a panel of wood or glass isn’t intricately detailed in Celtic patterns; many of these elements have been salvaged from Irish castles and cathedrals. You might pair a glass before or after the game with such American fare as oven-roasted cod.

column7: Don’t think twice about the sign requesting proper attire. Baseball caps, cutoffs and tank tops (for guys) are the only truly verboten apparel at this gentleman’s gay bar: The older, designer-suited patrons, however, do appreciate a tony sense of style. First-timers to this converted brownstone may think they’ve entered a hotel lobby: Soft music plays in the front room, which is decorated with prim-and-proper furniture and oil paintings. The scene all but demands the slow sipping of top-shelf Scotch. For a less sedate affair, wander into the back-room piano bar, where a show-tune sing-along might erupt at the stroke of a piano key.

column7: Restaurant Il Bagatto’s bar has a woodsy feel; a ceiling of tangled branches hovers above patrons who sip from an impressive, Italian-heavy selection of 35 wines by the glass and more than 150 varieties in bottles. A fruity Falanghina Feudi di San Gregorio or a full-bodied La Sala Chianti Classico is the perfect accompaniment to the complimentary taralli, crunchy bread rounds that look like miniature doughnuts. The small menu of snacks changes seasonally. In the fall, options include a tart of porcini or potatoes; the pizzella, a fried tomato-basil mini pizza, is available all year long. The long communal table in back is great for meeting fellow wine lovers.

column7: In a timeworn space just below street level, the notoriously anonymous Alibi Club is easy to miss. That’s the way the owners like it—they even took the phone out of service. If you do find it, you’ll be in the company of art students from nearby Pratt, neighborhood characters and the occasional suit, all enjoying beers and stiff drinks in the dark front room. On busy nights, the crowd spills into the graffiti-covered back room and rear garden.

column7: Founded in 1932 by Pat Kelly, who came ahead of her husband from Ireland to establish the place, Kelly’s is simplicity itself. The proprietors supply the beer and liquor, a dartboard and a jukebox filled with classic rock; the patrons provide the ambience and entertainment. Current owner John Nolan, a son of one of the Nolan brothers who bought the bar from the Kelly family, says the joint still draws the same neighborhood blue-collar crowd it always has. And why would they ever leave? Kelly’s serves 50-cent drafts and $1 malt liquors every day of the week.

column7: You may feel a sense of déjà vu upon entering this Irish pub, even if you’ve never been here before. It’s the type of watering hole that exudes nostalgia: The 1897 building, originally a Syrian Catholic church, is a historic landmark, and the owners are third-generation proprietors. To complete the picture, 12 beers are offered on tap, the menu includes a nicely charred burger, and the waitstaff speaks in a lovely sing-song brogue.

column7: In a city overrun with excessively styled nightspots, there’s a lot to be said for the “come in and drink beer” manifesto of one seasonal haunt. Squeezed next to an F-G subway entrance and Bagels by the Park, the GYC—an outdoor beer garden for ironic, scruffy types—has a garage sale–meets–fraternity house decor. On cool nights, bartenders may fire up the potbellied stove to take the chill off. The half-barrel grill is usually glowing, so you can chow down on bockwurst, then slake your thirst with a pitcher of Dentengem’s Witbier.

column7: Upstairs from superstuffy Shelly’s is the Blue Lady, a large lounge that’s long on wow. Small jazz bands perform in the center of the room, and all around them are jazzy explosions—blood-red walls, leather banquettes and booths, and a smaller raw bar. The dim, intimate space has massive windows overlooking 57th Street. You’ll be hanging with midtown workers, cool old guys and sophisticated tourists. Once you’re settled into a couch, with an oyster platter and a Calvados sidecar (Calvados, Cointreau and lemon juice), you won’t be blue.

column7: This urbane dance club probably does seem like manna for anyone tired of the artsy B-burg scene. The music tilts toward Latin, especially on Saturday nights, when DJs spin old-school merengue, salsa and Spanish rock. On Fridays, you’ll hear hip-hop and R&B; on Thursdays, you’ll have to suffer through karaoke. Bartenders mix surprisingly inexpensive cocktails behind a gleaming stainless-steel bar, while the crowd dances “on the two” in the raised lounge in back. The dress code is strict, and caps of any sort are discouraged.

column7: A holiday stop at Rolf’s is like visiting a David Lynch film set in Bavaria. The bar, populated by Gramercy residents, has vines and branches creeping up the walls and across the rafters. A chandelier of fake deer antlers hangs above it, and the room is lit with enough Christmas lights to approximate Pointillism. It’s nice, in a kooky way. Servers are solicitous, and best of all, they break out the free finger food (sandwiches, cold cuts, potato pancakes) every evening at 5pm, to go mit das Bier.

column163: For the past 35 years Rolfâs (named after first owner Rolf Hoffman) has been serving Bavarian cuisine to Gramercy locals and Teutonophiles. The comprehensive menu is not for vegetarians: once you get beyond the nice, light appetizers (shrimp cocktail, goats cheese salad), there are more than 30 entrees to choose from and most are heavy on the meat. There are six different types of schnitzel, goulashes and meatloafs, and a sausage platter of weisswurst, knockwurst, and bratwurst. Most are accompanied by spatzle - little potato balls, but some, such as the roast suckling pig (an enormous plate of tender, delicious meat), come with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes. In the unlikely event that you have room for dessert, the apple strudel and chocolate mousse cake are recommended. Afterwards, while you rub your belly and wonder how you could have ingested so much, be sure to take in the environs - the charming old-fashioned booths, the stained glass windows, the cuckoo clock. If your visit coincides with a holiday, check out the decorations: the staff hang 27,000 fairy lights around the dining room every Christmas; inflate hundreds of red and pink balloons for Valentineâs Day; and install hundreds of fresh flowers and vines for Rolfâs annual Spring festival.

column7: Though years past its peak as a music-industry and rocker after-hours hang, China Club still has the Jade Terrace, a top-floor indoor-outdoor garden. The meaty door guy and the metal detector downstairs may make patrons think they’ve reached some inner sanctum of New York nightlife. They haven’t. And they haven’t seen their last doorman, either; the terrace has yet another. Each of the three levels has a bar, and on the weekend, each seems to represent a different geographic wedge of New York’s suburbs.

column7: You know those ridiculously stereotypical ideas born-again preachers harbor about the “gay lifestyle”? Chances are they look something like SBNY (a.k.a. Splash Bar). Everything at this dance bar is big and, er, vivid: carb-free, pectoralicious bartenders; mirrors at every angle; and a full arsenal of body-rockin’ beats. It even has an ATM and a store (lube or condoms, anyone?), so come for happy hour, stay for dancing, and do your best to yank away the itty-bitty towels worn by the go-go boys. Jerry Falwell should be so lucky.

The decor is shabby; the strippers, predictably bored; and the management, unabashed about airing unpleasant prejudices. If you must go, eschew the desperation downstairs in favor of the upstairs lounge. Its wooden beams and vaulted ceiling oddly bring to mind a countryside retreat—now frequented by the prepsters who call the Financial District home.

column7: This 14-year-old music venue may not have the storied punk history of nearby CBGB, but it doesn’t have the skanky bathrooms, either. Performance photos of Iggy, Blondie and Green Day line the walls, but musical trailblazing has given way to a steady stream of sound-alike hard-rock hopefuls. Still, the narrow, wood-floored space is clean, friendly, loud and cheap (most shows are free; others rarely top $5). Plus, with shots a mere $2.50 extra with every beer, and five shots for a ten-spot, there’s hardly a better place in town to stretch your drinkin’ dollars.

column7: Eclecticism reigns at the swank cabaret in the Public Theater: Joe’s may book sultry German chanteuse Ute Lemper, the new-millennium burlesque “Jewish Girls Gone Wild,’’ an indie-rock band or a late-night DJ dance party. Sight lines are full and clear from every seat in the house; wine and champagne are available primarily by the bottle, and specialty cocktails (fresh-mint mojitos, Remy sidecars) are $10. A full Italian menu is also offered, and may help meet the required minimum—either two drinks or $12 worth of food per show. The velvet ropes are largely decorative, but buying tickets ahead of time is still recommended.

column7: Tribeca’s famed music venue moves across the river to a smaller Williamsburg location. Instead of the tri-level layout of yore, the new spot features a single performance room cleverly designed to look like a giant recording studio, complete with soundproof glass dividing the bar area from the concert space. The bar (dubbed “Knit Bar”) includes ten beer taps pouring mostly local and craft varieties, a handful of wines selected for their value and quality, and specialty cocktails featuring organic booze. Be on the lookout for familiar sights; some parts of the original venue have been incorporated into the decor here.

Bartenders have seen it all (including indie-minded celebrities who pop in to see up-and-coming bands), and if you’re professional and courteous, they’ll usually return the favor.

column7: It may be pocket-size, but that pocket is full of goodies. Evenings begin with readings, poetry and art. On Bingo Tuesday, blue-haired ladies battle yuppies for 99-cent prizes, and Wednesday’s Quizz-Off draws top-drawer TP mavens; Scrabble is on Saturday. After the games, there’s free music in the Pullman-car-shaped performance space, with acts on the cusp of wider recognition appearing nightly. When the weather warms, the backyard opens to stargazers. Throw in surprisingly good pressed sandwiches and an El Diablo (tequila, cassis and ginger ale) the size of a Big Gulp. What more could you want?

column7: It’s not the original bebop and hardbop club that hosted Basie and Coltrane—it’s better. A brilliantly designed and acoustically superb venue, Birdland has perfect sight lines and manages to feel intimate even at 4,000 square feet. Veteran marquee names stop by, but the place is also known for the great bands-in-residence. Sundays belong to the Chico O’Farrill Afro-Cuban Jazz Big Band; Mondays to the Duke Ellington Orchestra, directed by Paul Mercer Ellington and Jack Jeffers. Tuesdays and Fridays, the early shows have a bargain $10 cover (plus $10 minimum).

column7: The name is an acronym for Sounds of Brazil, and outstanding samba bands play on Saturday nights. But this is really a venue for world music and world dance styles. Come early for dinner and a table seat, or resign yourself to a night of perpetual motion.

column7: Two French-born Brooklynites have brought European literary flair to the neighborhood. Music-snob bartenders play lounge and soul while serving French wines and flaming Absente (a perfectly legal substitute for absinthe). Events fill the comfy Beat-ish back room—jazz, folk and world music performances; readings by local authors; and silent movies accompanied by live bands. Intentionally more “French” than French, Barbès manages to be fun without being ironic.

column7: Fans of the old down-and-dirty Sweetwater Tavern (often described as the CBGB of Brooklyn) might experience culture shock in this gussied-up incarnation. New owners—the trio that started the Smith Street renaissance with Patois—have canned the live music but stock a great jukebox. They kept the old mahogany bar and tile floors but added a pleasant back porch. The beer is still cheap ($4 for a 20-ounce Guinness) but now there’s a menu of bistro hits such as escargot with garlic butter and roasted chicken with portobello mushrooms. And while you can get a chocolate martini, you can also down the old house drink, a Car Bomb: a pint of Guinness with half a shot each of Jameson and Baileys.

column7: For those who take their comedy seriously, “Eating It,” the quirky showcase that runs most Monday nights (with a summer hiatus) is a can’t-miss. In the back room, big-name emcees encourage the city’s best comics to stretch out creatively, even if it means bombing. In other words, it’s where you’ll get comedy that may be too ambitious—and sometimes just too weird—to ever make it to the regular clubs. Other nights, live (and often gratis) performances include underground pop and roots bands, some of which appear on the club’s record label, LunaSea.

column7: Dinner, drinks and a show in this glittering room can feel like an evening that only an oil sheik could afford, but commit to it: The Carlyle is the place to open your wallet and live the high life. Woody Allen sometimes sits in on clarinet with Eddie Davis and his New Orleans Jazz Band on Monday nights; call ahead to confirm. To drink in some atmosphere without spending quite as much, try Bemelmans Bar across the hall.

column7: Setting the pace for campy, good-natured fun (though not classic glamour), the city’s oldest cabaret is still going strong at 55. A generous mix of regulars and tourists laugh and sing along with drag performers, comedians and rising stars in the cabaret room on the second floor. (Special showcases are still in the intimate game room, which is also upstairs and has a separate bar.) In the ground-floor piano bar, the merry singing waitstaff is entertaining enough to avoid charges of gimmickry.

column7: Settle into a banquette in the legendary oak-lined room and enjoy the likes of Tierney Sutton, Karen Akers and Stacey Kent. They’re in good company: The Oak Room launched the careers of Harry Connick Jr., Diana Krall and Peter Cincotti, among others. First-rate cabaret commands top-shelf prices, so most shows (Tuesdays though Saturdays) come with a $50 cover. On Fridays, Saturdays and select Thursdays, there’s a compulsory $50 prix-fixe dinner for early shows, and a $20 minimum for late shows. A night at this storied venue will have you singing for your supper soon enough.

The Skylight Room will remind many fans of defunct Reno Sweeney, despite its offbeat address inside the Grand Sea Palace restaurant, “where Bangkok meets Broadway” on touristy Restaurant Row.

column7: Some commuter bars are built for killing time, but this historic spot could entice you to miss your train on purpose. The O-Bar dates back to 1913, and its vaulted ceilings and desultory service suggest its institution status. Cocktails are competent classics (there may be no greater environment in which to enjoy a standard Manhattan) but the real draw is the wine: A list of 300 bottles includes by-the-glass selections like an $8 Pichon viognier. If you’ve got a long wait, order a half dozen oysters too.

column7: Enough about wine bars! Game-day imbibers of both genders just want a pleasant, courteous, spill-proof experience—and Social provides three spacious floors’ worth. Candlelit chandeliers illuminate exposed-brick walls but don’t compete with big-screen TVs on the first floor. (A hint at the place’s loftier aspirations lies in quotations from Aerosmith and Emma Lazarus on the front wall.) The top-floor Fusion lounge provides a deck for smokers, offering $3.50 Buds and $4 well drinks Monday through Saturday nights until 8pm.

column7: Britishisms sound cooler than their American equivalents—hence the name. A trio of HBO stars (Granville Adams, Tom Fontana and Natasha Lyonne) has transformed an Asian strip club into a bi-level bar, with a mirror-mosaic basement lounge. The huge, curvy cement bar feels chilly, but gold Miró-inspired murals, indigo tea lights and plush banquettes warm the space. Cocktails are large and lovely, and a tap-drawn pint is only a fiver.... So where is everyone? While waiting for the crowds, duck into the velvet-lined private room for a spot of snogging.

column7: Spirit hasn’t yet come close to filling the void left when superclub Twilo departed this sacred ground. The New York outpost of a successful Dublin venture, this is a one-stop nightlife complex with a restaurant, live performance space and dance club. One miscalculation has already flopped here: The strange hippie vibe of the Mind lounge (tarot readings, massages, psychic sessions) scared off night crawlers, as did the high prices. So Spirit took the predictable route and hired mainstream promoters and DJs who play generic house and hip-hop to a generic trendy bunch.

column7: Owned by the proprietors of next-door Kobma, the tiny space packs in varied groups. Spanish speakers perch at the bar, eating sushi and singing along to piped-in Latin tunes. Weary suits down bottles of Red Stripe (no beer on tap), or sip one of the many exotic teas for which the place is famous. Around midnight, the twenty-somethings show up (in droves on weekends), and the music switches to reggae, hip-hop and downtempo.

column7: There are a number of catwalks to feast your eyes on: the sidewalk, where smokers and passersby can be ogled through floor-to-ceiling windows, and the wide, steel staircase that serves as a de facto pedestal for the dolled-up patrons. But the real show—and the architectural feature for which the place is named—is the narrow platform that stretches above the bar, where revelers can break it down, Soul Train style. Leather couches in the upstairs lounge offer a fine place to rest, but take a few sips of a pricey specialty drink like the Katini (raspberry vodka, chambord and sour mix), and you’ll be raring to go again.

column7: The geniuses who turned Avenue A into a nighttime gay runway with the opening of Starlight and Wonderbar (since sold) have opened a not-so-gay gay bar in the depths of Alphabet City. Come during the extended happy hour (all drinks are two-for-one from 6 to 10pm), to avoid running up a Soho-size tab.

column7: The name means “grandma” in Yiddish, but to celebs, punksters and stroller-pushers who wait all morning for a table, it means brunch. The sun-blasted restaurant, originally a pie kitchen, has morphed into an all-day gourmet picnic; at the front, insulated from the pram parking lot, is the bar. The fluorescent dessert cases and gaudy floral wallpaper will fade after one of the signature “loco” cocktails (the Slow Comfortable Screw blends Southern Comfort, champagne and OJ). Top off your buzz with Bubby’s mile-high apple pie. Then, stick a fork in it—you’re done for the day.

Forgive the menu scribe, because the combination of red or white wine, Malibu rum, and pineapple and lychee juices with floating fruit chunks, is gulpably good. This and other trademark cocktails are likely to be spilled down your front during the evening; the crowding is half the fun. The other half, of course, is simply sharing a plate of Thai-spiced french fries over a couple of bottles of Singha.

column7: Only in New York: a watering hole that’s half homeless shelter and half swank, overpriced hotel. In the basement of the Maritime Hotel is a posh, cavernous space furnished with dark wood and a sharp-looking crowd. (The 17th Street side of the distinctive portholed building is still the Covenant House headquarters.) The slyly lit bar in the top balcony has side booths overlooking the restaurant, for prime people-watching. The six-page sake menu is brilliantly organized, identifying both type and region of origin. If sake’s not your thing, order the delectable Midori martini. Less a cocktail than a not-too-sweet alcoholic version of a Slurpee, it’s a slushy apple-green mountain topped with a sour cherry.

Later, DJs pump it up to an ear-shattering level and the space is commandeered by squeaky-clean postcollegiate Upper East Side singles; the proceedings feel like a house party at some rich kid’s estate. The cover charge on weekends is $25, a simple vodka and cranberry is $10, and the place is mobbed. Go figure.

It’s open practically 24 hours: You can have breakfast in the café (it opens at 8am), lunch or dinner (Latin-Asian cuisine) in one of the dining rooms, then drink and dance until the wee hours. Music leans toward Top 40; guests lean toward white twentysomethings from slightly out of town.

column7: Wogie’s (rhymes with “oh jeez”) is the tall, dark and handsome kid on the block. The owners structured a fresh, masculine space through the liberal application of wood paneling. The place quickly caught on, and Philly cheese steak fanatics cram the booths all day long. The bar, with its bank of mirrors reflecting the passing street scene, is shaping up as a relaxed, inclusive after-work spot. Pleasant staffers, a no-surprises playlist and a middle-of-the-road drink selection make this a straightforward, low-risk, blue-chip option. Our rating: Buy.

column7: Everything you need in a bar—and absolutely nothing you don’t—is here. Ten TVs, including one big screen, for sports; a pool table in the small back room; classic rock blasting from the jukebox; and a fair, reasonably priced selection of tap beers. The only way this place veers from the Platonic ideal of a tavern is in the salty snacks. Yep, those are Goldfish in the little wooden bowl, not pretzels. Close enough.

column7: Mismatched sparkly-star wallpaper, tiger-print couches, glowing palm trees and a disco ball–Plan B certainly lacks the design focus of Drinkland, the beloved local bar it replaced. Drinkland threw wildly popular parties nearly every night of the week; Plan B doesn’t yet have that much social pull. But word is spreading about Derek, the hunky bartender who has become Plan A for a good number of women, and he’s got the energy to single-handedly make this place cool again. Guys, meanwhile, can try their luck with the house punch, which is strong enough to tilt the playing field.

column7: The original working-class clientele is leaving as hipsters invade Inwood—but they all find harmony (in a low key) at night, when the no-nonsense watering hole feels as comfortable as the spirits are affordable. Late one recent evening, the only other woman to be found was the bartender, but the fellas were all perfectly polite.

column7: Good luck finding this single-malt Scotch haven—there’s no awning and no sign. Ring a bell, wait for the buzzer, climb the stairs and...you’re in a windowless room filled with golf paraphernalia, light jazz and more than 300 rare bottles. Owner Koichi Hiraiwa largely caters to Japanese businessmen, which makes sense when you see the price list: $16 to $800 (for Black Bowmore) per shot. Jackets are required (the sign says so) and Hiraiwa has been known to charge a cover. Get on his good side, however, and he might share some delicious Japanese food (small plates that normally go for $10), or even crack open a special bottle.

column7: It may be the only bar in the South Bronx that has “Stairway to Heaven,” R&B, salsa and merengue on its jukebox. That’s a clue to the inviting, inclusive feeling owner Aronne Baietti wanted to establish when he opened the place in 2002. French doors, exposed brick, rotating art by local artists and every-other-Tuesday poetry readings provide a sophisticated backdrop for the regulars—serious pool players who line up for the $1 pool table. The place may be ahead of the curve, but neighborhood renovation (fading affordable rents!) is catching up.

That little eight-seat area has become a big social scene for local thirtysomethings and for celebs coralled by David Burke’s food and Donatella Arpaia’s Rolodex. The Ford Excursion limo parked out front is the cigarette lounge.

Grab a cozy candlelit nook, sink into one of the black leather couches—but stay away from the seemingly guileless specialty drink dubbed the Painkiller (a strange concoction of coconut, rum and orange juice). Swallow one too many of those, and the hall of mirrors leading to the blood-red bathroom could look more like a terrifying carnival maze than a playful remnant of downtown’s smutty heyday, when this space housed an S&M bar.

column7: The former Limelight has managed to resurrect itself once again, and this time it has risen above and beyond its former incarnations. The revamped gothic church is an intriguing labyrinthine maze—secret passageways and hidden rooms snake off from a cavernous main hall with vaulted ceilings. The club books the world’s finest prog- and tech-house DJs on Friday and Saturday nights. If electro isn’t your thing, the Chapel room downstairs hosts Top 40 and hip-hop tunes. VIPs and wanna-bes should check out the Spider room, which attracts all kinds, from candy ravers to tight-leather-pants yuppies.

If you’d like something to nibble, a full menu is offered until 2am (3am on weekends) from the adjacent trattoria, La Lanterna di Vittorio.

column7: Williamsburg is growing up. Owners Tom Schmitz and Tom Kenny run a bright bar with attractive touches—oversized windows, mirrors flanking the room, a long wooden bar and four cozy booths. An array of single-malt Scotches and microbrews is available; attentive (and attractive) bartenders are happy to make suggestions.

column7: A pagoda centerpiece carved into the main staircase adds drama to the descent from the dining level to the lounge. Votives flicker over a fashionable crowd that comes for the scene, the fruity cocktails and the street-market–inspired dishes (by Jean Georges Vongerichten). Arrive early to snag one of the prized tables; latecomers will be spectators at the bar (showing up past 11pm on a weekend will leave you on the wrong side of the velvet rope). Service from the sexily clad waitresses is quick and snooty. The rich and famous take to the plush private rooms lining the back wall, where pillows and bottle service come at a steep price.

column7: This addition to the West Chelsea nightlife scene works the early shift as an art gallery. By day, paintings are on display under a magnificent skylight. At night, the space becomes a lounge with a $20 cover. To corral the crowds, the owners divided the 7,500-square-foot warehouse into three sections: a ground-level bar, an elevated champagne lounge and a VIP area perched high above the action, next to the DJ booth. Female servers wear J. Lo’s line of lingerie, boy servers don Hilfiger House. As for you, no jeans, no sneakers and, please, no trucker hats.

column7: Before mustachioed hipsters even knew what Chimay was, this subdued West Village bar was pouring bold Belgian brews. Though VDN’s list hasn’t matured much since the bar opened in 1995, it remains one of the city’s coziest, if most predictable, hops havens. Ten drafts include the malty Maredsous 8 and biting La Chouffe, and there are nearly 30 bottled beers, many of them Trappist (Westmalle, Rochefort)—a solid, enjoyable lineup. Add some first-rate pub food—moules and fries—and it’s clear that even in this beer-forward climate, VDN’s simple pleasures still satisfy.

column7: On a relatively quiet block, a pair of Germans have taken nightlife matters into their own hands, and the result is a multitasking complex. Their bar, Nautilus, is next door to the their restaurant, Grotto, and downstairs from their second-floor espresso bar, Monterone, and connected to their Mediterranean-style back garden. Inspired by 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea, Nautilus is decorated with portholes and diving-helmet lamps. At press time, a late-night bar menu was in the works, featuring small plates to pair with mojitos, bellinis, caipirinhas and more.

column7: Unparalleled views of the Chrysler and Empire State buildings make the bar on the rooftop of the Shelbourne Hotel a revelation to boarders and visitors alike. Lounge beds and ample seating guarantee comfortable sightseeing; strings of lights decorate the foliage. Wednesday and Thursday evenings bring DJs and dancing.

The space nails the industrial-chic look—high ceilings, wood beams and brick walls painted black—and some old-fashioned touches (vintage gilded mirrors, ornate sconces) soften the room. The tapas menu is the work of Einat Admony (Danube, Patria, Bolo, Tabla). Become a regular and you can rent a locker for $50 a month—perhaps to store bottle-service leftovers

column7: In This Is Spinal Tap, Nigel Tufnel boasts that his amps can be turned up to 11—a joke that inspired the name of this LES alternative to the Chelsea club scene. The decor is much like its West Side counterparts, as are the velvet rope, the sexy waitresses bringing bottle service and the high ceilings that give the big sound system some room to boom. But the similarities end there: Patrons at Eleven gravitate toward cheap cans of Pabst Blue Ribbon. A second bar, downstairs, plays house, hip-hop, Brazilian, electro and more. Paris and P. Diddy have made their appearances, and rock bands like to hang here, too: Matt Safer, of the postpunk Rapture, doubles as a resident DJ.

column7: Area professionals unwind here, as does the Gotham Rugby Club, so there’s not a lot of attitudinizing going on. It’s a hale-fellow-well-met sort of pub, and those who don’t grow roots at their stools can visit the back room, stocked with TVs, a pool table, dartboard and video-game console. Oversize leather booths are filled on Sundays with a passionate football crowd. All that’s missing is a kitchen and an outdoor deck, but the owners haven't overlooked that. A second-floor deck is slated for next year.

column7: The bar atop the Hotel Gansevoort offers a great aerial view of the Meatpacking District (it trumps the Soho House by eight floors), but it comes at a premium. Drinks are $14 apiece, and without an actual cocktail menu, loungers are left to order an overpriced version of their usual poison. The stylish executives and banker types who squeeze in here nightly can lounge at tables lining the stone terraces, or they can venture out to the crowded back garden, where low sofas and wooden benches provide additional seating. What they cannot do is take the plunge in the outdoor swimming pool on the hotel’s rooftop. If you’d like to visit, come midweek, when it’s calmer; the view is well worth it. Just block out the coos of older gents trying to convince PYTs to join them in the Hamptons.

column7: When Matt Dawson heard that Società Riposto was closing, he thought the old Sicilian social club would make an ideal hipster watering hole. So he gutted the bland card-playing room and installed designer touches, right? Fuhgeddaboudit. He kept every detail he could and even hung photographs of the original members on the walls. The bar has been kept simple (and prices, reasonable), but there’s one significant add-on: a backyard with a patio.

column7: How can an upstart watering hole lure ever-fickle customers? By having celebrity DJs? Exotic cocktails? Audacious art? David Sliskin, manager of the Alligator Lounge, pulled an even hotter idea out of the oven: From 6pm to 2am, free pizza is served with every drink. Word spread quickly, and now penny-pinchers from all over the borough make the pilgrimage for $10 pitchers of Rheingold and fine thin-crust pies, baked over a wood-stoked fire. At a time when little seems to rouse tousle-haired Brooklynites from their ennui, enthusiastic patrons fill the bar every night. And the DJs? Free pizza, Sliskin says, is the best DJ in town.

column7: Adam Robertson wanted his space to resemble the Louisiana house his great-grandfather built in 1909, so he called his father. Accompanied by a carpenter, they shopped for wood and other materials down South and built the U-shaped bar and cocktail tables, then loaded everything onto a trailer (along with a few antique mirrors) and hauled it up to Brooklyn. Maybe it’s the DIY savings that allows Robertson to offer 24 wines by the glass, each between $4 and $10. At these prices, you can easily spring for a few appetizers, such as a well-balanced cheese plate or the Nawlins-style shrimp cocktail—the recipe is courtesy of his dad.

column7: Paris and Nicole can skip their next trip to the boonies and just take a trip to Atlantic Avenue. There, the bar Floyd, NY is modeled after taverns in Floyd, Iowa, owner Pam Carden’s hometown. She and her husband, Jim, have have added rural elements like a jukebox stocked with Hank Williams and the Bad Livers; tin ceilings; vintage signs; a salvaged 1870s bar; and nice bartenders. It looks like a joint that’s been around for ages—not a renovated liquor store. Schlitz beer and Kentucky beer cheese complete the theme. An indoor bocce court, on the other hand, doesn’t make sense at all.

column7: If you want to open a rock & roll bar, it helps to be a rock star—or be partners with one. The owners of Chelsea’s Vela lounge have teamed with Scott Weiland (Stone Temple Pilots, Velvet Revolver), Duff McKagan (Guns N’ Roses, Velvet Revolver) and Brett Scallions (Fuel) to open Snitch. They’ve lined the bathrooms with old rock magazine covers and dressed the staff in vintage rock T-shirts. Even the menu has attitude: “shut up” banana splits and “beer balls” (shareable kegs) mingle with mac and cheese and fried chicken. In rock-star fashion, Snitch is open 24 hours on weekends.

column7: An architect, a glassblower and a music publicist are opening this bar in Williamsburg, and it’s a big deal: an 8,000-square-foot space divided into a 3,000-square-foot bar, two gallery spaces, a billiards room and an outdoor garden. The decor incorporates handblown-glass lighting. And the prices are comparatively low with $3 Buds, $4 and $5 pints, and $6 high-end cocktails.

column7: One of life's great vices is eating in bed—but things can get messy. Now you can get busy on someone else's sheets, at this restaurant-lounge in the old Centro-Fly space. The horizontally inclined can eat, drink and be merry on one of 23 beds. Restaurateur Sabina Belkin brought in custom-made beds (larger than king-size) and dressed them with 400-thread-count sheets, gold satin pillows, and drawers for shoes and purses. She hired chef David Coleman, formerly of Union Pacific, to develop dishes like slow-poached hake, East Coast oysters and lamb three ways. Squeamish types will be happy to hear that the sheets are changed after each party leaves.
column92: 45 W 21st St between Fifth and Sixth Aves
column144: Subway: F, V, R, W to 23rd St (W weekdays only)

column7: Owner Osman Cakir operated this antiques shop for three years before deciding it could serve triple duty, incorporating a wine bar and restaurant. In addition to the Turkish and French pottery, visitors will find more than 120 wines (including some from Cakir’s native Turkey) and a small menu of Mediterranean foods. He’s also packed an antique couch, a small bar and a few tables into the 800-square-foot space.

column7: Taking over the space from Noa, a closed tikki bar, the young Irish owners of Bua (Irish for victory) quickly stripped away the tiki-ness, leaving behind an exposed brick lounge area with a garage door that swings open to let the outdoors in. With freshly stenciled walls and beers like Hefeweisen on tap, it’s not a typical Irish bar, though they do expect to add standard pub grub such as burgers eventually. On the sidewalk, there's a porch with rattan couches, perfect for watching the pedestrian traffic near Tompkins Square Park.

column7: Taking the decadence of bottle service to the next level, club owner Aram Sabat has added a few luxury amenities to the menu at his West Village lounge, 49 Grove, including limousine drivers who double as concierges, personal bodyguards and decor that references a private-library theme. Located in the space formerly known as Halo, 49 Grove is outfitted with oversize leather couches, large ottomans and shelves lined with leather-bound books. In addition to specialty cocktails, Sabat serves gourmet dishes like baby beef Wellington, Petrossian Iranian caviar and terrine of Hudson Valley foie gras. Bottle service is also available—at all 30 tables.

column7: The cool kids in Williamsburg have moved their party east, and now they have a wine and beer bar to call home: a raw but comfortable spot with deep couches, high ceilings and a large outdoor garden. Although the name sounds dirty, stain in this case refers to the ring a wine glass leaves on the table. You’ll have plenty of chances to witness this phenomenon; there’s an ever-growing selection of wines, all of which come from New York state.

column7: East Village bars are often a little rough around the edges. Not Mundial. The owners hired Sylvain Bazinet, a partner in Chelsea’s slick Open lounge, to revamp the former bar Totem. Bazinet brought in TV tables and a drop-down screen to show art videos—and occasional soccer games, as the name suggests—and he installed black slate floors and cedar paneling to update the look. The menu will evolve as business picks up, with a limited selection of panini to start. The signature drink is the Mundial Mango, a frilly blend of mango vodka, triple sec and lime juice. But, as at any decent East Village spot, there are plenty of beers on hand, too.

column7: When the Upper West Side Greek restaurant En Plo opened in April, it looked a lot like the Greek eatery Pelagos that formerly occupied the space—and the food was awfully familiar, too. It was from the same chef, Peter Spyropoulos. But now an alluring subterranean lounge has opened downstairs, and it serves spectacular, rare Greek spirits. You can sample any of 20 ouzos——a licorice-flavored liqueur—in addition to 12 ouzo cocktails (like “ouzopolitans”), dozens of Greek wines and a separate menu of Greek mezes. DJs mix on Friday and Saturday nights.

column7: The August closing of beloved Sparky’s left the desolate section of south Carroll Gardens in dire need of a watering hole. Jennifer McShane has set out to fill the void with this elegant, 375-square-foot bar. While the room is tiny, the drinks menu is not: McShane carries more than 30 international wines by the glass, more than a dozen high-end bourbons and an array of specialty drinks, including the Girl Scout Martini, which comes with a Thin Mint.

column7: It’s not easy to fool around when two gold Buddhas are staring at you, but the owner of Sutra wants to put you in the mood. Ariel Palitz has revamped the Flat as a sultry playground where you’re seduced with incense and warm amber lighting. A downstairs cave is preserved as an old Turkish gentlemen’s club, and an upstairs bar and billiards room is lined with red velvet banquettes and bordello-style lamps. You can nibble on chocolate-covered strawberries and sip concoctions like the Sutra Martini, with vodka, vermouth and crème de cassis. Pace yourself, though: Lines for the bathroom might be long, as Palitz has papered the walls with pictures of Kama Sutra positions.

column7: Taking over the space in Hell’s Kitchen that was Revolution, this bar and grill provides midtowners with everything they need after a day at the office: seven 50-inch flat-screen TVs, 25 beers on tap, and an eclectic menu of American, Irish and Thai dishes. Chef Paul Morello, formerly of Les Halles in Miami, serves shepherd’s pie and meat loaf, as well as Thai wings, crab cakes and grilled-tuna wraps. Sports fans can watch the Jets, Giants and Eagles games while feasting on burgers and steaks cooked on the pub’s charcoal grill; it’s a taste of tailgating without the traffic to the stadium.

column7: It’s in New York, but doesn’t feel of New York. The windows overlook a Hudson River view that resembles San Diego more than our own bustling metropolis. But during the summer, it’s wonderful to be near the promenade and sailboat-dotted marina.

column7: Ouest brings grown-up big-city dining to an area that’s been Blockbustered and Baby Gapped into suburban submission. The buttoned-down predinner crowd here knows its way around a martini. The long, narrow room, done in glossy ebony and lipstick-red, gets busy after work as well. Specialty cocktails are restrained versions of the classics, from a proper martini made with Junipero gin and an onion-stuffed olive, to the Ouest sour, tarted up with Ketel One and yuzu juice. And you can dig into Tom Valenti’s big, brawny food at the bar

column7: Delicious tapas and an excellent selection of Spanish wines by the glass are enough to draw plenty of people on a winter’s night. Other enticements include wooden rafters, ochre walls and candlelight that evoke the romance of the Mediterranean, and expat bartenders who are friendly and full of wine and food advice. Yet the real fun begins when the weather turns warm and the doors open to the enormous garden (you can hear neighborhood kids at play in a nearby park). There are few better ways to beat the heat than to sit here with a plate of fresh sardines and an icy pitcher of sangria.

column7: The young, diverse crowd perches on bar-stools to tune up their palates before dining in the single-room Vietnamese fusion restaurant, which has brought a smooth touch to a still-rough stretch of Avenue C. Choose from a surprisingly broad wine list or, if you’re tilting to the Asian side of things, order a saketini or the banana-mango-rum drink, boldly rimmed with ultrahot spices and black sesame seeds. Either is perfect preparation for the pungency of Southeast Asian cuisine.

column7: If you’re lucky enough to get owner Pietro Bardocci talking about his 145-bottle wine list, you’re in for an Italo-oeno education. And what better environment for it than Via Della Pace’s exposed brick, Tuscan-muraled soffits and candle glow? Arty people—who were probably pioneers in the neighborhood two decades ago—linger at the bar, engaged in tête-à-têtes and enjoying generous, reasonably priced glasses of finds like ’97 Barbera d’Asti Superiore, prosecco Impero or one of ten grappas by the glass.

column7: Inside this retro-modern café, friendly young staffers do their best to create an all-inclusive scene. column7: Life is so very pleasant at Baldo Vino. The patrons are trendy, well groomed and usually come in pairs. The music, like the staff, is lively and fun without being overwhelming. The room has an earthy, intimate atmosphere, with plenty of raw wood and candles; when weather permits, there’s also a back garden. If you’ve come to appreciate Italian wines, try bruschetta specifically designed to be enjoyed with vino. Bottles from the Italian list (more than 70 from all over the boot) range from $24 to $149. How perfectly civilized.

column7: Don’t come with next-big-thing expectations to this dance and supper club: It’s Radisson, not radical. The space is huge, and the address sort of out of the way for late-nighters. That’s where David Schefer’s design comes in, employing deep-red terrazzo floors and gold-leaf wallpaper to create a warm, tropical feel even when there’s no crowd to heat up the place. Ja Rule threw a birthday party and Johnny Depp’s Secret Window was feted here, but dance-club aficionados might find the doormen ill-mannered and the DJs dropping dated beats.

column7: At this brick-walled, double-decker bistro, the sleek, gray bar in the round has just five seats, but it’s a popular stop nonetheless for both diners waiting for tables and locals dropping in for a drink and a bite. Lingering is encouraged, if not downright enforced: Since there are no wines by the glass, wine drinkers have to make their choice from the extensive, alluring list of half and full bottles, all at shockingly gentle retail (not restaurant) prices. Dice-size chunks of Parmesan are served as bar snacks, but once you have your bottle, you’ll probably want to graze through the French-Italian menu (onion soup, mussels, pasta specials, five kinds of steak, a six-dessert sampler) and make an evening of it.

column7: The bar at this rustic Meatpacking District restaurant, located in an 1848 brownstone, is flush with speakeasy charm. The space is all exposed beams and brick, and the main ingredients in the heady cocktails are Scotch, cognac and whiskey. The “Weeski,” for one, is a potent blend of whiskey, Lillet, Cointreau and orange bitters. A fireplace and one of the city’s prettiest gardens add to the intimate atmosphere—a stylish beacon within the area’s garish nightlife scene.

column7: The bar menu of the natty Pan-Latin bistro reads like a brief history of trendy drinks from warmer climes: margaritas, mojitos, caipirinhas, a tasty sangria and the house’s own Yucatini (what else?). Beer drinkers can choose from a few $5 drafts (including Dos Equis, an unusual find on tap) or the standard bottles. But the main reason to drop your drinking dollar here is to try chef Ricardo Cardona’s “cocina Latina” tapas.

column7: It took three Irishmen—the oldest, a sprightly 30 years of age—to turn the conventional idea of an Irish pub on its head. Gone are the shamrocks, the homeland relics and the thickly accented bartenders. What remains is a stripped-down, autumn-hued pub with a tiny garden. Panini replace bangers and mash, and the flat screens carry Yankees, not footballers (at least not yet). So what’s Irish about Lunasa? It’s a good place to have a pint among friends.

column5: Sambapolitan: Grey Goose Citron, fresh blood orange juice, Triple Sec; Quatros Pinas: Van Gogh Pineapple vodka, Tropical Pineapple liqueur, pineapple juice, pineapple garnish.
column7: At Saturday’s Thirty Somethings party, the DJ supplies Latin-tinged disco and salsa to the festive restaurant and club. Many patrons show up for a late dinner and stay for the dancing. During the week, Samba is quieter, though the music may still drown out conversation. The sleek bar offers an attentive barstaff, well-poured drinks and a Nuevo Latino menu offers appetizers such as sweet-potato–and–pork tamales, cool octopus salad and golden, crisp empanadas.

column7: When the more popular (read: overcrowded and overrated) bars run out of room on a Saturday night, the Lighthouse shines. Fifteen beers on tap are complemented by Costa Rican bocas, such as enyucado (fried balls of yuca dough filled with seasoned ground beef). The kitchen is open late, and you can even smoke on the patio out back.

column7: Bring the address with you—Alta is hidden a few steps below street level on a sleepy block of West Village brownstones. Once inside, ask for sangria. The bartender will fill an oversize goblet with ice, orange juice, a hefty shot of spiced rum and a topper of red wine. The bar is gleaming copper, the stools are padded leather, and the walls are lined with rounded river rocks and weathered brick. Among the many tapas available are salty marcona almonds and an intriguing combo of cauliflower, clams and chorizo.
column8: Conversation-friendlyFoodDate placeWine bar

column7: Take a cue from the name and give this long, slim place a try. A selection of 30 wines, 2 sakes and 8 beers on tap is complemented by generous tasting plates of aged cheeses, dried meats and preserved vegetables, all served in a candlelit brick space decorated with vintage school maps. The whole deal is inspired by a well-known restaurant in Barcelona that serves conservas, or preserved foods—and nothing has been lost in translation.

column3: Ladies’ night Fri and Sat 2 for 1 drinks
column7: This candlelit space, outfitted in sweeping orange curtains, hosts a young, thirsty crowd partial to eclectic drinks like the 718 martini (Finlandia vodka, Cointreau, grapefruit juice and cranberry). Those subscribing to the Tom Cruise school of cocktail flair will appreciate the Cucaracha: The barkeep pours Kahlúa and 151 into shot glasses, then sets them aflame.

column7: While it’s a bit of a stretch to call this place a bar—it doesn’t stay open past midnight—the college-town coffeehouse feel is a pleasant change of pace. Score another point for the couple that runs Mud Coffee: This café fits right in with their cool orange trucks, cheap coffee and indie spirit. Take that, faceless corporations! Grab a stool at the bar, or a little table in the back; sip your wine, beer or sake (Thursdays include sushi); and relax and smell the coffee.
column8: Conversation-friendlyWine & beer onlyFoodNonalcoholic nightlifeWheelchair accessible bathroomHappy hour
column92: 307 E Ninth St between First and Second Aves
column144: Subway: L to First Ave; 6 to Astor Pl.

column7: If the Discovery Channel ever wanted to record the rituals of downtown wildlife, this remote Afro-Euro bar-restaurant would be the place to do it. The ivory, brown and gold room is enhanced with pony skins, zebra-pattern ironwork and African masks. Hip hunters devour snacks like steak with yuca fries and down drinks like the Jericuara cocktail (ginger, honey, rum, and lemon juice).
