column7: This nightlife destination hopes to lure the right crowd with its exclusivity: Private cabanas have their own minibars and bathrooms and DJs have access to a state-of-the-art sound system.
column92: 14 E 27th St between Fifth and Sixth Aves
column144: Subway: 6 to 28th St

column7: Brothers Martin and Mark Whelan have the luck of the Irish: After success with St. Andrews and Maggie’s Place, they’ve scored 16,000 square feet for their beer theme park, Stout. You can sample 142 beers and devour oysters, or pub grub like shepherd’s pie and fish-and-chips.
column92: 133 W 33rd St between Sixth and Seventh Aves
column144: Subway: 1, 2, 3 to 34th St–Penn Station

column7: Though not much larger than a king-size candy bar, there’s always room to shake it at this jungle-inspired hangout located on a remote stretch of the Lower East Side. The local art and leafy-green murals adorning the walls and camouflage banquettes enliven the space, while deliciously spiced sangria and DJs spinning hip-hop and reggae fuel the cool, but never pretentious, crowd.
column92: 21 Essex St between Hester and Canal Sts
column144: Subway: F, J, M, Z to Delancey–Essex St

column7: In a bizarre twist on the small-plates invasion, this Chelsea lounge-restaurant is promoting oversize dishes. Ravenous clubgoers can devour 22-ounce shakes, 14-inch burgers and more. Lindsay Lohan threw her wrap party for the movie Just My Luck at the space on April 15; other bigwigs can book time in the VIP room, which has nine pool tables.
column92: 54 W 21st St between Fifth and Sixth Aves
column144: Subway: F, V, N, R, W to 23rd St

column7: It’s not unusual to hear Serge Gainsbourg’s francophone crooning fill this dusky, tin-ceilinged downtown dive. The main draw isn’t the moody soundtrack, but an expertly curated selection of 40-odd bourbons, many of them single-barrel. For drinkers who don’t take their whiskey straight, there are also fine cocktails like the Samhattan: rye whiskey, triple sec, sweet vermouth and fresh lemon.
column8: Date place
column92: 173 Mott St between Broome and Grand Sts
column144: Subway: J, M, Z to Bowery; 6 to Spring St

column7: This Mediterranean wine bar in the former Ovo space has kept the woodburning oven in place, and added plenty of Spanish and Italian wines—and food that makes them taste that much better: cheeses, shaved ham, wood-roasted vegetables and other seasonal dishes.
column92: 65 Second Ave between 3rd and 4th Sts
column144: Subway: F, V to Lower East Side–Second Ave

column7: This stylish lounge prides itself on a no-cover, no-list, no-hassle policy. Slip through the glass-and-metal front door and you will be pleasantly surprised by the mod decor. Bars at both ends of the room bask in the glow of white-and-chrome globe lights and produce a steady flow of cocktails. DJs and Thursday-night guest bartenders draw an eclectic mix of regulars and in-the-know out-of-towners.
column92: 244 E Houston St between Aves A and B
column144: Subway: F to Delancey St; J, M, Z to Delancey–Essex Sts (M weekdays only); V to Lower East Side–Second Ave

column7: A decade’s worth of municipal red tape—and a handful of floods—forced the downtown dyke bar Meow Mix to close, but felines have more than one life. Owner Brooke Webster followed many of her former patrons across the bridge and opened Cattyshack in Park Slope. You could easily get lost in the bi-level club, which has two bars, two dance floors and a spacious roof deck for smokers. Indulge in $3 Tecate beers, a monthly party for gay men and a karaoke night. Plus, the club’s cabaret license means riot grrrls (and the boys who love them) can shake it without worrying about raids from the dance police.
column8: Lesbian
column92: 249 Fourth Ave between President and Carroll Sts
column144: Subway: M, R to Union St

column7: Show up at 9pm Sundays at this ramshackle dive and you can sip a $2 Schaefer, listen to the honky-tonk likes of Sean Kershaw and the New Jack Ramblers, and feast on free sausages from the sidewalk grill.
column92: 46 Third Ave at Atlantic Ave
column144: Subway: B, Q, 4, 5 to Atlantic Ave; D, M, N, R to Pacific St; 2, 3 to Bergen St

column7: Despite its titular nod to damnation, this Hell’s Kitchen’s destination—attractively outfitted with dark mahogany panels and a slate-topped bar—has heavenly amenities. Particularly commendable are the 16 brews on tap and 18 by the bottle. We like the hard-to-find German Weihenstephan, a smooth Hefeweizen poured from an Irish Kilkenny system that chills each line from keg to tap. The result is a clean, cold brew every time. Nothing hellacious about that.
column92: 692 Tenth Ave between 48th and 49th Sts
column144: Subway: C, E to 50th St

column7: Who says there's no smoking in bars? At this Murray Hill lounge, small white clouds rise from the tables and bar, generated by ultrasonic mist makers. Visitors can watch the fog, colored lights and clubby crowd while sitting at the black leather banquettes in the front room or from inside a slightly elevated "white room" in back. Owner Mark Titone, who helped launch Duvet, has hired a staff that's well trained on bottle service; they've worked at Lotus, Biltmore Room, Bed and the Hudson Hotel. Drink enough Amazon Mists—a sake-spiked caipirinha—and your head will be even cloudier than the room.
column92: 143 Madison Ave between 31st and 32nd Sts
column144: Subway: 6 to 33rd St

column7: Queens-born twins Bill and Keith Reichenbach have surrounded themselves with beer: The two are shareholders in beer mecca David Copperfield’s, organizers of the annual Brewtopia beer event, and are the proud owners of this East Village alehouse. They’ve decorated the space, formerly Stingy Lulu’s, with vintage beer ads, Trappist-monk figurines, and a chalkboard menu that lists 30 beers on tap and more than 100 by the bottle. In keeping with the tavern theme, the pub offers moules frites, wings, quesadillas and brunch.
column60: Mon 4pm–1am; Tue–Fri 4pm–4am; Sat noon–4am; Sun noon–1am
column92: 129 St. Marks Pl at Ave A
column144: Subway: 6 to Astor Pl

column7: The owner of Shine and Mission realized that the Garment District lacked a good postwork drink spot, so he converted this former showroom into a spacious lounge. The fashion motif is far from subliminal: Antique sewing machines perch above the bar, and on the cocktail menu you’ll find apparel-themed drinks. Try the Silk Scarf, a mix of Stoli vanilla, triple sec, orange juice and lime juices, which is potent enough to burst anyone’s seams.
column92: 247 W 37th St between Seventh and Eighth Aves
column144: Subway: A, C, E to 34th St–Penn Station

column7: The owners of Buster’s Garage have built another open-air sports bar—right next door. Cheering fans will find two giant TV screens and a deck lined with faux-palm-tree lights.
column92: 180 West Broadway at Leonard St
column144: Subway: 1 to Franklin St

column7: Luca Marcato has opened an outpost for UES grape lovers with 55 wines, plus Italian cheeses and one hot entrée daily from Luca Restaurant.
column92: 1728 Second Ave between 89th and 90th Sts
column144: Subway: 4, 5, 6 to 86th St

column7: This downstairs lounge, beneath the restaurant Providence, has been serving playful cocktails like the Orange Crush (Bacardi O, Orange Curaçao, lemon juice and Sprite) and well-mixed martinis since April. The room features a brick floor, which gets plenty of action on Friday and Saturday nights, when the DJ spins ’80s, reggae and hip-hop beats for a mixed crowd of bankers, young professionals and tourists. You’ll find quieter refuge in the upstairs lounge, which was once a Baptist church and later a recording studio for Jimi Hendrix and John Lennon.
column92: 311 W 57th St between Eighth and Ninth Aves
column144: Subway: A, C, B, D, 1 to 59th St–Columbus Circle

column7: Eventually, club kids have to grow up, and Lotus owner David Rabin has a place for them when they do: a cocktail lounge called the Double Seven, across the street from his sceney Meatpacking District den. It’s small—just 75 seats—and built for conversation, not craziness. Drinks (by consultant Sasha Petraske of Milk & Honey) are a whopping $16, but each one is served with Debauve & Galais chocolates. No need to wait in line: The place takes reservations for parties of four or more.
column92: 418 W 14th St between Ninth and Tenth Aves
column144: Subway: A, C, E to 14th St; L to Eighth Ave

column7: Sasha Petraske’s flagship bar, Milk and Honey, may require reservations, but Little Branch, his clubby, low-ceilinged Village rathskeller, retains an open-door policy. As befits Petraske’s liquid legacy, the drinks—like a velvety-smooth, mildly spiced hot buttered rum—are nigh perfect. If you choose to deviate from the menu, just give the neatly attired, polite bartenders a base liquor and a hint of your mood, and they can tailor a drink on the fly. A call for rye got us a spot-on Italian twist on a Manhattan, featuring maraschino liqueur, Carpano Antica vermouth and amaro. Custom-made cocktails—no password or secret handshake required.
column92: 20–22 Seventh Ave South at Leroy St
column144: Subway: 1 to Houston St

column7: Tucked away underneath Astoria’s elevated subway line lies an unlikely hybrid. This cabaret/go-go dancing/sports bar is not a gentleman’s club per se, but the atmosphere might suggest otherwise. Dancers gyrate to Greek and Latin beats on a narrow stage at the center of the circular oak bar, while bartenders pour strong, high-priced cocktails, such as a Seven and Seven or a rum and Coke. Mermaids may not be a treasure in an ocean of bars in Queens, but it is definitely a different world.
column92: 31-06 31st St between 31st Ave and Broadway
column144: Subway: N, W to Broadway

column7: You can cobble together a meal of salt cod fritters and fried polenta with tomato fondue at this Iberian tapas lounge inside the Hotel Giraffe, but the real scene is at the bar. Sure, there’s red and white sangria served by the icy carafe, but cocktails can be ordered in pitchers too, encouraging liberal sharing among the well-heeled crowd. Try the fruity Havana daiquiri, made with rum, lime juice and pineapple, or the bubbly Zygasm—a peach vodka-and-cava concoction so potent you might need to book a room upstairs.
column92: Hotel Girraffe, 365 Park Ave South at 26th St
column144: Subway: 6 to 28th St

column7: This exclusive nightclub offers an unusual taste of upscale Africa—with a bit of Vegas fabulousness. Walls suffused with a sunset-orange glow showcase exotic touches like a straw-thatched ceiling and a huge, stuffed gazelle head mounted over the DJ booth. Wednesday nights, hosted by Richie Rich, offer the most diverse party; you’ll see gay celebs posing haughtily alongside suited-up Euros and guys in baseball caps. The high prices on African-themed cocktails, like the Jeffries Bay, a butterscotchy concoction floating with chewy tapioca-like basil seeds, become more agreeable when you learn that a portion of the proceeds are donated to the Nelson Mandela Children’s Fund.
column92: 544 W 27th St between Tenth and Eleventh Aves
column144: Subway: C, E to 23rd St

column7: This Prohibition-themed bar cultivates an exclusive vibe, but there’s no cover and no trouble at the door. Pass by the palm reader in the window (it’s a front) and you’ll find an amber-lit deco interior where formality still flourishes: Servers wear custom-designed frocks and bartenders don waitstaff whites. The real stars are the cocktails like the West Side, a lethal mix of lemon vodka, lemon juice, mint and club soda. Don’t come looking for a bargain—the drinks are priced as if alcohol were still available only under the table.
column8: NYCVisit: TrendsetterNYCVisit: RomanticNYCVisit: Culture buffNYCVisit: Explorer
column92: 510 Hudson St between Christopher and W 10th Sts
column144: Subway: 1 to Christopher St–Sheridan Sq

column7: This four-level Times Square bar and lounge is built for the indecisive. Those wishing to converse over a cold pint can choose from 13 beers on tap, sports fans can view the game from seven big-screen televisions, and warm-weather fans can drink alfresco on the rooftop. A weekday happy hour runs all day until 7pm; on weekends, DJs draw a twentysomething crowd.
column92: 783 Eighth Ave between 47th and 48th Sts
column144: Subway: N, Q, R, W, 42nd St S, 1, 2, 3, 7 to 42nd St–Times Sq (W weekdays only)

column7: Eclectic Mexican cuisine is what originally established Rocking Horse Café as a unique eating place in Chelsea (duck confit tamales are especially popular), but the bar holds a distinguished reputation for the tongue-numbingly stiff frozen margaritas. Choose from fresh-fruit varieties like papaya, mango and passion fruit, or consider a Mexican bottled beer. Free chips and salsa and outdoor seating (weather permitting) are a bonus.
column92: 182 Eighth Ave between 19th and 20th Sts
column144: Subway: C, E to 23rd St

column7: The folks at this subterranean bar are so proud of their Irish credentials, they display a James Joyce Pub Award on the wall—an icon that largely goes unnoticed in the dusky interior. Here, scruffy intellectual types and British expats engage in lively banter over college rock that may be a bit too loud for highbrow discussions. When there’s room at the shiny copper bar, pony up and try a pint of the Widmer Brothers Hefeweizen from Oregon, poured from an old-fashioned tap, or any number of frozen drinks (most beers are $5 during happy hour, daily from 2 to 8pm).
column92: 155 Second Ave between 9th and 10th Sts
column144: Subway: L to First Ave

column7: Nostalgia for rowdy college days is the stock-in-trade here, where a fratty crowd guzzles cheap beer and stages Guns N’ Roses karaoke sessions, Thursday through Saturday from 10pm to 2am. But the jukebox is solid, and a classic oak bar embellishes this otherwise typical pub. Happy-hour specials, Monday through Thursday from 3 to 7pm and Friday and Saturday from noon to 7pm, include a free buffet of buffalo wings and fries.
column92: 106 E 19th St between Park Ave South and Irving Pl
column144: ubway: L, N, Q, R, W, 4, 5, 6 to 14th St–Union Sq

column7: On Williamsburg’s ultrahip Bedford Avenue, hip-hop is criminally underrepresented. That’s why Triple Crown is such a refreshing blast of bass. In a departure from slummy indie-rock dives, the sleek, minimal lounge specializes in DJs dropping science. Multicultural crews of baseball-hatted beats-lovers splay across Ikea-like couches and square stools, nodding their heads to Hot 97 jams and old-school faves. If ears are ringing, step outside and ogle the camouflage-graffiti pig and rooster.
column8: TrendyGood for large groupsCover chargeLive DJSinglesSidewalk tablesBottle serviceLoungeWheelchair accessible bathroom
column92: 108 Bedford Ave at N 11th Street
column144: Subway: L to Bedford Ave; G to Nassau Ave

column7: The concept is simple: a large, rowdy crowd in a small, dingy room, five TVs tuned to ESPN, $5 beer-shot combos and Buck Hunter II next to the bathrooms. A sign behind the bar instructs, “Don’t hassle the ladies.” But if the patrons (usually a frattish mix) must be reminded, it’s a safe bet that the house rule is often breached. Rock stars seem not to have a problem, though, which might explain why indie heartthrob and East Villager Conor Oberst has been seen here playing air hockey with friends.
column92: 140 First Ave between St. Marks Pl and 9th St
column144: Subway: L to First Ave

column7: The inspiration for one of the city’s last remaining genuine honky-tonk bars was the bear, not the baseball legend. Fans of the departed Village Idiot will love this place: When not dancing on the bar, waitresses serve ice-cold pitchers, pints and cans of mainstream American brews. It’s a beer commercial come to life—good ol’ times for good ol’ boys.
column8: Happy hourAfter-work crowdCheap drinksJukeboxFree snacksClassic NYSports barSinglesOlder crowdFrattyDive barDartsPinballVideo gamesWheelchair accessible bathroom
column92: 2156 Broadway between 75th and 76th Sts
column144: Subway: 1, 2, 3 to 72nd St; B, C, 1, 2, 3 to 72nd St

column7: Since 1941, locals, postwork drinkers and those looking for a friendly nightcap have been crowding into this cozy Upper West Side Irish pub, where three generations of Campbells (Michael, Charles and Charles Jr.) have doled out cold, creamy pints of Guinness, martinis, whiskey and Irish coffee. For snacks, pub-grub standards (burgers, mozzarella sticks) join Irish staples (fish-and-chips, corned beef and cabbage).
column8: TrendyAfter-work crowdConversation-friendlyNoted mixologistSports barSinglesArtsyCheap drinksFoodClassic NYOlder crowdDive bar
column92: 205 Columbus Ave between 69th and 70th Sts
column144: Subway: 1 to 66th St–Lincoln Ctr

column7: Ticketless Rangers fans are in luck at Hickey’s Bar, a narrow, tourist-free hockey hangout near Madison Square Garden. The game is always on, and silver-haired Irish bartenders keep sports buffs (and postshow theater hands, oddly) lubricated with ten beers on tap, including $6 Bare Knuckle Stout.
column92: 139 W 33rd St between Sixth and Seventh Aves
column144: Subway: B, D, F, N, Q, R, V, W to 34th St–Herald Sq; 1, 2, 3 to 34th St–Penn Station

column7: This comfortable Brooklyn restaurant offers great food and relaxing spirits to anyone willing to walk through its wrought-iron doors and into a gothic setting decorated with small lion figures. The narrow bar with a view to the open kitchen (and other hidden rooms) offers an elegant spin on tapas, such as the Guinness-braised short ribs. Terrific beers are on tap—like the smooth German pilsner Bitburger and the microbrew Blue Point—while the well-stocked bar satisfies more cocktilian tastes.
column92: 638 Bergen St at Vanderbilt Ave
column144: Subway: 2,3 to Bergen St; B, Q to Seventh Ave

column7: This sleek, modern space stands out next to the clumsier, frat-friendly spots in Murray Hill. But, as evidenced by an overabundance of flat-screen TVs and a deafening conversational roar, the more sophisticated aspirations of this bar have not been fully realized. The unfocused DJ spins anything from OutKast to house music, and waitresses hawk hackneyed drinks like lychee martinis and a forced-quirky bar menu, including a dim sum plate.
column92: 354 Third Ave at 26th St
column144: Subway: 6 to 28th St

column7: The wine list shows a nice selection of pinots, the cocktails are stiff and elegant, and happy hour lasts from 4:30 to 6:30pm daily. There’s also a short, simple menu with shareable Italian dishes like thin-crust pizzas and grilled calamari. Weekly events include guest DJs and film screenings. Drinkers in the know head downstairs to BelowDekk, where DJs spin freestyle or world music.
column92: 134 Reade St between Greenwich and Hudson Sts
column144: Subway: 1, 2, 3 to Chambers St

column7: Duff’s, on a desolate corner a block from the East River, is set away from bustling Bedford Street, but it’s not quite a throwback to the old neighborhood: We can’t remember seeing any old Polish bars with Nosferatu masks, vintage nudie playing cards and an upright coffin. On a recent visit, a friendly, tattooed bartender suggested PBRs or $2 shots of green, sticky-sweet “Jesus juice”—although the ingredients are a secret, it tasted a lot like Midori and Amaretto. Meanwhile, the metal-heavy jukebox, a holdover from the hearse-driving owner’s previous venture, Bellevue of Hell’s Kitchen, devotes as much space to indie classics like the Cramps as it does to softies like Peggy Lee.
column92: 28 North 3rd St at Kent Ave
column144: Subway: L to Bedford Ave

column7: Looking for the Living Room? Epstein’s is what you’ll find now that they’ve relocated. The space is about half the size of its predecessor, and is more about canned music than live shows—a small neon jukebox and loft space for the resident DJ can be spotted among the café tables. Grab a burger and a friend on Sunday, when there’s a two-for-one burger special, and munch them at the outdoor café to avoid the flat-screen TVs inside.
column92: 82 Stanton St at Allen St
column144: Subway: F, V to Second Ave–Lower East Side

column7: The decor at the Local NYC chain’s West Side outpost—Corinthian columns, iridescent mosaic tile pillars, a disco ball—doesn’t exactly scream sports bar, but the flat-screen TVs, rock music and proximity to Madison Square Garden make it more than suitable for watching a game. There’s also a slightly more chic, couch-filled downstairs lounge, plus a roof deck where frozen margaritas are available when it’s warm out. But beware: Open-air orders cost extra.
column8: Happy hourAfter-work crowdOutdoor seatingFrattyFoodGood for large groupsNoted mixologistSports barLoungeNo steps at entrance
column92: 1 Penn Plaza at Eighth Ave and 33rd St
column144: Subway: A, C, E to 34th St–Penn Station

column7: While Mama’s Food Shop feeds the soul, the next-door drink annex raises spirits by serving infused cocktails, like a pear-ginger martini and a tequila lime Rickey—plus imports and microbrews on tap. Open for about a year now, the bar’s speakeasy feel is embellished by the Christmas lights strung along the sparsely decorated walls and a jukebox playing classic soul and funk. In the fall, the bar plans to start happy hour with hors d’oeuvres specially made from Mama’s.
column92: 200 E 3rd St at Ave B
column144: Subway: F to Delancey St; F, V to Lower East Side–Second Ave; J, M, Z to Delancey–Essex Sts

column7: This popular postwork midtowner offers daily drink specials, homemade sangria, plenty of imported beers (mostly bottled) and a live DJ spinning pop, rock and R&B every night but Sunday. The casual bar has an old-timey feel (lots of mahogany, stamped-tin ceilings, exposed brick), while the more upscale rear lounge features a second bar, ritzier red leather banquettes, and slate and quilted-fabric walls.
column8: Happy hourAfter-work crowdFoodNoted mixologistSports barSinglesFrattyLive DJSidewalk tablesBottle serviceExtensive beer selectionLoungeNo steps at entranceWheelchair accessible bathroom
column92: 1003 Second Ave at 53rd St
column144: Subway: E, V to Lexington Ave–53rd St; 6 to 51st St

column7: This large Franco-Vietnamese restaurant and bar, located in a converted warehouse, is swathed in white- and cream-colored silk worthy of an old-time Hollywood starlet’s boudoir. The Cosmojito—a concoction of Bacardi Limón rum, fresh mint, sugar, lime and passion-fruit puree—is a tart take on two trendy faves. And the Sapa mint lemonade—a blend of Stoli citrus, fresh muddled mint, fresh lemon juice and simple syrup—is justifiably famous. Oyster happy-hour specials add some saline sustenance to the party.
column92: 43 W 24th St between Fifth and Sixth Aves
column144: Subway: N, R, W, 6 to 23rd St

column7: Onetime Village Underground manager Tim Wood remade the goth spot Duck into this modest bar with slightly rickety tables pushed up against black, paint-speckled walls. No pretense is made to gussy up the purely functional space. What separates Satellite from the neighborhood’s many other cheap-beer-and-pool dives is a growing slate of live music on Friday and Saturday nights, sponsored by Urban Folk magazine (the acts tend to be low-key because the small stage can’t fit a full drum set). Two popular open-mike nights dominate the midweek schedule, and the bar has also become something of a dog lover’s locus, serving as a meeting place for a canine-friendly pub crawl.
column92: 505 E 6th St between Aves A and B
column144: Subway: F, V to Lower East Side–Second Ave; L to First Ave

column7: The cabin-inspired decor makes sense when you consider the bar’s lineage—Whiskey River comes from the same owners as Gramercy’s Black Bear Lodge. This rustic, backwoods-style saloon features an unholy trinity of bar games—Big Buck Hunter, video bowling and beer pong. That, combined with flat-screen TVs and a killer selection of the namesake spirit— 20 whiskeys include oaky Bulleit Bourbon—helps keep the boisterous Murray Hill crowd entertained.
column8: Happy hourGood for large groupsOutdoor seatingJukeboxSports barSinglesFrattyVideo gamesWheelchair accessible bathroom
column92: 575 Second Ave between 31st and 32nd Sts
column144: Subway: 6 to 33rd St

column7: Sunsets over the Hudson remain the drawing card at this sleek space formerly known as Open. Owner Eddie Lee improved on the nearly transparent, glass-paned hangout by adding Brazilian cherrywood and charcoal-gray accents to the stylish room, a fine choice for low-key postgallery drinking. The most significant improvement is the custom-designed sound system and DJ booth.
column92: 559 W 22nd St at Eleventh Ave
column144: Subway: C, E to 23rd St

column7: Commitmentphobes will appreciate this wine spot’s try-before-you-buy philosophy: In addition to a lengthy list of international vinos (35 by the glass include a crisp $13 Adelé Rouzé sauvignon blanc), the narrow enoteca features all manners of cured meats and cheeses (try the meaty epoisses, a semisoft cow’s-milk variety). In the adjacent shop, you can peruse more than 300 old- and new-world bottles—pop one open at the bar for an additional $15 corkage fee.
column92: 211 West Broadway at Franklin St
column144: Subway: 1 to Franklin St

column7: Come here for the jailbait—this appropriately named bar has been a favorite for the young college crowd since it opened in 2001. The space is filled with an eclectic mixture of antiques and midcentury-modern furniture, suggesting the more sophisticated tastes of Humbert Humbert. Sip a “Lolita,” a specialty drink made with raspberry vodka, peach schnapps, orange and cranberry juices and a splash of triple sec, while enjoying some homegrown entertainment (readings, a comedy night) in the downstairs lounge. Free wireless Internet is a rare perk for those who like to log on while drinking—especially good if you still need to finish your homework.
column92: 266 Broome St at Allen St
column144: Subway: F, J, M, Z to Delancey–Essex St

column7: Suckers for skyline views relish Alma’s sprawling rooftop perch overlooking the water—and Red Hook’s loading docks. With aromatic pineapple vanilla margaritas, Al Green in the background and oscillating fans, there’s no better spot for a relaxed rendezvous. But if you just want to imbibe, get here as soon as the roof opens, because the coveted seats are intended for those buying a flauta or two.
column92: 187 Columbia St at DeGraw St
column144: Subway: F, G to Carroll St

column7: Show up at 10pm on a Friday or Saturday night and you might be turned away (we were). Come back at 7:30pm on a Tuesday and you can walk right up the stairs and into a practically empty South Cabana (there’s also a North Cabana; each can be rented for private parties). Comfy alfresco couches, tropical drinks and a canopy of paper lanterns help set the mood.
column92: 363 W 16th St at Ninth Ave
column144: Subway: A, C, E to 14th St; L to Eighth Ave

column7: Jade Terrace Sultry singles salsa in the indoor lounge, while the mellower types escape the cruisy vibe for a prime piece of outdoor real estate on a pagodalike terrace overlooking Times Square. After paying the $10 to $20 cover charge, grab a drink ($10–$15) and apologize to the small army of Buddha statuettes for your overindulging ways.
column92: The China Club, 268 W 47th St between Broadway and Eighth Ave
column144: Subway: C, E, 1 to 50th St

column7: Looking for fun and feeling groovy? Check out the views of the 59th Street Bridge from the wrap-around U-shaped balcony on the 21st floor of the Bentley Hotel while you guzzle a $5 beer. Sure, it’s prac-ti-cally in the East River, but that’s why the view rocks.
column60: Mon–Sat 5–10pm; bar stays open as late as 1am
column92: The Bentley Hotel, 500 E 62nd St at York Ave
column144: Subway: F to Lexington Ave–63rd St; N, R, W to Lexington Ave–59th St (W weekdays only); 4, 5, 6 to 59th St.

column7: This -Koreatown spot is perfect for the budget--conscious tippler (most tropical drinks are $10) and native Floridians. If you’d like to have a close-up of midtown but don’t mind the cheesy greenhouse look, the fenced-in wooden patio or the almost-too-close view of the Empire State Building, bottoms up.
column92: 17 W 32nd St between Fifth Ave and Broadway
column93: Sun Roof at La Quinta Inn
column144: Subway: B, D, F, V, N, Q, R, W to 34th St–Herald Sq

column7: Sweeping views of midtown and the East River are not the only draws at Top of the Tower, a swank lounge with two small outdoor terraces, perched on the 26th floor of the Art Deco landmark Beekman Tower hotel. There’s also live jazz piano (Thursday through Saturday) and signature cocktails like the chocolaty Gotham Martini.
column92: Beekman Tower, 3 Mitchell Pl at First Ave
column144: Subway: E, V to Lexington Ave–53rd St; 6 to 51st St

column7: In keeping with the evolution of Murray Hill, the owners of this subterranean bar have decided to create a multipurpose space for all types. A third of the sprawling venue feels like a neighborhood pub (lined with exposed brick), another section is a swank, libraryesque lounge dotted with leather couches and low wooden tables, and the backyard functions as a sports bar. Underground doesn’t serve food, but it does offer classic cocktails like Campari and soda, and a daily happy hour ($1 domestic drafts and $3 well drinks) from 4 to 8pm.
column8: NYCVisit: Explorer
column92: 613 Second Ave between 33rd and 34th Sts
column144: Subway: 6 to 33rd St

column7: Soft Spot is not what you might expect from a musician-run bar in Williamsburg. Rather than open yet another rocker hangout, owner Matt Webber has built a classy, sensual piano bar, decorated with purple and red walls and hanging votives, and set to the tune of live jazz. The homey “living room” has fake bookshelves, a fireplace and the bar’s centerpiece: Webber’s grandmother’s piano. You can take a seat near it or at the curvy wooden bar for a French martini with Grey Goose, Chambord and pineapple juice, and a bar snack of hot wasabi peas. Sophisticated as the place is, it still has the neighbors in mind: Two-for-one beers are on tap during happy hour.
column92: 128 Bedford Ave at North 10th St
column144: Subway: L to Bedford Ave

column7: West 27th Street seems to welcome places with a gimmick. The strip is already home to nightclubs with cotton-candy machines, beds and even a concierge service that will book your last-minute helicopter ride to Atlantic City. So we’re guessing that Home, a megaclub that looks primed for a spot on MTV Cribs, will settle in just fine. Four nightlife moguls have collaborated with the designers of Marquee and Butter, and they didn’t skimp on decadence. Commanding crystal chandeliers hang in every room; ceilings are covered with black leather; and an endless mile of plush couches will suit the bottle-service crowd. Drop by earlier in the evening to sip your cocktail in peace, or come late-night when worldly DJs like Mark Ronson are on deck.
column92: 532 W 27th St between Tenth and Eleventh Aves
column144: Subway: C, E to 23rd St

column7: Like moths to light, shakers and moneymakers will be drawn to the latest giant nightclub on the outskirts of the Meatpacking District—a bi-level dance palace called Glo. Located near the Maritime Hotel, this 11,000-square-foot space (formerly Powder) emphasizes the glow theme with colorful lights that bounce off the white walls, emanate from the three full-service bars and shimmer across the disco floor. Upstairs, the DJ booth has been transformed into a living room with an adjacent VIP area that has its own bar and bathroom. Guest DJs can bring a posse and look down on the madness from above. It’s what you might call high style.
column92: 431 W 16th St between Ninth and Tenth Aves
column144: Subway: A, C, E to 14th St; L to Eighth Ave

column7: Owners Denis Keane and Adrian McCarthy have opened a Irish pub—albeit one that spans 6,000-square-feet, with a mini-waterfall, bottle service and a VIP room. Celebrity mixologist George Delgado crafted the cocktail menu; chef John Donnely has created an adventurous menu of tuna-tartare tacos, smoked salmon and potato knishes, and more. There’s no cover fee—but there are $6 pints of beer, so a line might develop soon.
column92: 137 Ludlow St between Rivington and Stanton Sts
column144: Subway: F, V, J, M, Z to Delancey–Essex Sts

column7: The nightspot formerly known as Float has been renovated, redesigned and reopened as Temple. It’s one hell of a space: 15,000 square feet of dance club spread over three floors. Like other clubs, this one has sleek leather booths, bottle-service options, a balcony overlooking the dance floor and a serious sound system. Unlike others, it is located in the heart of the theater district—not a draw for everyone, but awfully convenient for tourists.
column92: 240 W 52nd St between Broadway and Eighth Ave
column144: Subway: 1 to 50th St

column7: Downtown booze connoisseurs frequent this so-called library, the only one we can think of where liquor lines the walls. A novella-size drinks menu lists a glossary of spirits and 100 cocktail options, among them the Corpse Reviver (gin, lemon juice, Lillet Blonde, Cointreau and Pernod) and the Jarnac Ginger (cognac, bitters and ginger beer). Paying $13 for one of these earns drinkers a basket of gratis gougères (warm cheese puffs).
column8: Conversation-friendlyFoodNoted mixologistFireplaceOlder crowdDate placeSidewalk tablesBottle serviceCigarsNYCVisit: RomanticNYCVisit: Power brokerNYCVisit: Glamour houndNYCVisit: Culture buffNYCVisit: Trendsetter

column144: Subway: 1 to Franklin St
column162: nn TONY 488 RR James Oliver Cury

column7: The owners of the ’80s-themed Culture Club have graduated to the next decade with Nerveana, a nightclub dedicated to the 1990s. Robert Watman and Tim Ouellette have opened the spot right above their first period piece and decorated the 5,000-square-foot space with a white Ford Bronco (O.J.’s model), Sharon Stone memorabilia and a hip-hop room housing a fridge of 40s. Cocktails include the Ricky Martini and the Billy Ray Citrus. The star attraction, however, is the music: a mix of grunge, boy bands, rap, and one-hit wonders from Right Said Fred (“I’m Too Sexy”), the Spice Girls (“Wannabe”) and other acts you swore you’d successfully forgotten.
column8: Cover chargeGood for large groupsLive DJLive musicVIP sectionBottle serviceDress codeNo steps at entranceWheelchair accessible bathroom
column92: 179 Varick St at King St
column144: Subway: C, E to Spring St

column7: You may feel like you’ve walked into a rainbow roll at this Upper East Side Asian-fusion eatery and lounge—amber lights glow from within the floors, fluorescent blue beams highlight the steel-top bar, and hot pink rays illuminate a wall-long waterfall. The Lite-Brite effect, ear-crunching music and flat-screen TV don’t seem to distract the mostly local crowd from enjoying cocktails like the Geisha’s Secret (sake, grenadine, pineapple juice, Malibu rum, and Bacardi Limon) or from ordering off the globe-trotting menu.
column8: After-work crowdCheap drinksFoodNoted mixologistPrivate roomsNo steps at entranceWheelchair accessible bathroom
column92: 1406 Third Ave at 80th St
column144: Subway: 4, 5, 6 to 77th St

column7: The owners of Barolo—the Italian restaurant in Soho with the sprawling back garden—have opened another leafy spot, in the Meatpacking District. But instead of big plates of pasta, they’re just serving drinks. There’s no name yet—look for the wrought-iron gate next door to Paradou.
column92: 10 Little West 12th Street between Ninth Ave and Washington St
column144: Subway: A, C, E to 14th St; L to Eighth Ave

column7: Thanks to the arrival of other serious mixology dens (PDT, Death & Company), Audrey Saunders’s imperial Pegu Club is no longer cutting-edge. But it’s still the gold standard for some of the city’s finest elixirs. The eponymous house cocktail is a sweet-and-sour blend of gin, bitters, fresh lime juice and orange curaçao; the Earl Grey MarTEAni, a tipsy take on afternoon tea, features Earl Grey–infused gin and lemon juice frothed with egg white. If you want to tweak your tipple, feel free: Every table comes with droppers of simple syrup, bitters, and lemon and lime juices.
column8: NYCVisit: Power brokerNYCVisit: Trendsetter
column92: 77 W Houston St between West Broadway and Wooster St
column144: Subway: B, D, F, V to Broadway–Lafayette St; N, R to Prince St

column7: Antique chandeliers and vintage couches lend this Park Slope spot the feel of a fine sitting room; fish-bowl cocktails and oversized pints remind you that you’re here to let loose.
column92: 245 23rd St at Fifth Ave
column144: Subway: R to 25th St

column7: Beach party Midtown may not summon images of sultry nightspots, but Nikki Midtown hopes to change that. The lounge, which the owners bill as “the sexiest party on Earth,” brings a South Beach theme to the East 50s with the help of white canopied beds, tiki torches and go-go girls. The bilevel space won’t have the palm trees and sand that made the original Nikki in Miami so popular, but it will likely woo the same upscale crowd of investment bankers starving for a midtown model-watching spot. In addition to the booze and girls, there’s a family-platter menu and tapas such as basil-crusted tuna loin and baked country Brie wrapped in puff pastry and topped with brown sugar and pine nuts. Big shots can splurge on the $150 Sunday brunch, which features caviar, champagne, sushi and Florida lobster tails.
column92: 151 E 50th St between Lexington and Third Aves
column144: Subway: 6 to 51st St; E, V to Lexington Ave–53rd St

column7: Lisa Buono christened her Williamsburg spot after the term used to describe after-hours bars in England. Modestly priced cocktails, a spacious backyard and odd knickknacks, such a chastity belt, give the place an unpretentious feel.
column92: 949 Grand St between Olive and Morgan Sts
column144: Subway: L to Grand St

column7: The owners of Paris Commune maintain a wine and cocktail bar in the cellar below the restaurant. The room is reminiscent of belle epoque Paris (antique-mirrored ceilings, a giant mural of Gare Montparnasse), but the French-inspired cocktails, like the Très French martini—vanilla vodka, Chambord and a splash of pineapple juice—taste refreshingly modern.
column92: 99 Bank St at Greenwich St
column144: Subway: A, C, E to 14th St; L to Eighth Ave; 1 to Christopher St–Sheridan Sq

column7: In an attempt to create the perfect lounge, bar owners Michael Matzo and Craig Skiptunis (Bistro Ten 18) didn’t settle on just one concept. Their Soho lounge, Obivia, wears many hats. It’s gimmicky: Shots come in blocks of ice embedded with exotic flower petals. It’s luxurious: You can rent a liquor locker for $500 annually. It’s trendy: The place is located around the corner from La Esquina, and the small-plates menu includes chicken lollipops and duck meatballs. It also appeals to artsy couch potatoes: Five plasma-screen televisions are rigged with B movies like Planet of the Apes and Abbot-and-Costello flicks. The decor is equally scattered, with a hodgepodge of items that include amber-hued antique light fixtures and Oriental rugs, and music provided by an iPod featuring jazz and funk tunes by the likes of Ella Fitzgerald and George Clinton.
column92: 201 Lafayette St at Kenmare St
column144: Subway: 6 to Spring St

column7: For access to this ersatz speakeasy, look for a sign that reads THE LOWER EAST SIDE TOY COMPANY. Pass through the gate, walk down an alleyway and up a set of stairs to find a dimly lit den fitted with a gleaming bar. Cocktails are poured into teacups, and bottled beer is brown-bagged before being served. A trick bookcase leads to the real “back room,” a VIP-only lounge.
column92: 102 Norfolk St between Delancey and Rivington Sts
column144: Subway: F, V, J, M, Z to Delancey–Essex Sts

column7: Glossy black-and-white patent-leather ottomans, polka-dot wallpaper and raw-metal panels give this swank Meatpacking destination a glam look. Live bands perform six nights a week on the black-velvet–backed stage. Even cocktails play to the theme: The Lynyrd Skynyrd, $10, is made with Maker’s Mark, Tuaca, lemon, mint and ginger ale.
column92: 416 W 14th St between Ninth Ave and Washington St
column144: Subway: A, C, E to 14th St; L to Eighth Ave

column7: This bar from the owners of Jarnac also serves food.
column8: Food
column92: 67 Clinton St between Rivington and Stanton Sts
column144: Subway: F to Delancey St; J, M, Z to Essex St

column7: Karaoke junkies now have an upscale alternative to all those traditional seedy Japanese joints. This space boasts oversize portraits of Axl Rose and Jim Morrison, flat-screen TVs looping ’80s videos and all kinds of specialty shots.
column92: 757 Sixth Avenue between 25th and 26th Sts
column144: Subway: 1 to 28th St

column7: The cavernous interior of this former Chinese catering warehouse has been transformed into a tri-level bar-lounge–rock venue. Drink in one of three areas: a ground-floor bar, a sunken lounge with low tables, or a floating mezzanine illuminated by a skylight and chandeliers constructed from old ceiling fans. Aspiring VIPs can inquire about the private-entrance basement lounge that hosts live bands.
column92: 112 Rivington St between Essex and Ludlow Sts
column144: Subway: F to Delancey St; J, M, Z to Delancey–Essex Sts.

column7: The theme is “girls gone Wild West” at this lowbrow Upper East Side boozatorium, with horseshoe decorations and beer-pong tables in the back. The “beergarita,” a (brace yourself) vodka sour mixed with beer, goes for $7, or get two for the price of one during happy hour (daily 5–8pm). Stick around for postsunset horseplay—a hardwood bar is popular among local ladies, who get up to dance to country tunes.
column8: Happy hourCheap drinksGood for large groupsJukeboxSports barSinglesFrattyDive barPool tableFoodDartsVideo games
column92: 1683 First Ave between 87th and 88th Sts
column144: Subway: 4, 5, 6 to 86th St

column7: The spin-off bar of Soho’s New York–only wine store is a fine destination for postshopping vino. Try one of the 200 wines by the glass at the steel-and-wood-accented bi-level space, or a flight of three two-ounce samples (rosés for $9, or dessert wines for $13). The hungry can ask the waiter for pairing ideas, such as the spicy duck meatballs with a 2005 Hosmer Cabernet Franc.
column92: 482 Broome St at Wooster St
column144: Subway: N, R, W to Prince St
column145: 1, 2, 3 to 96th St

column7: John Roberts, owner of Bushwick Country Club, believes that “miniature golf and drinking go great together,” so he added a nine-hole course out back. Find your inner John Daly by putting through a Pabst Blue Ribbon windmill or drilling a ball into a robot’s belly. There’s never a wait to play, and non-country club members can afford the greens fee: Everything but the beer is free.
column92: 618 Grand St at Leonard St
column144: Subway: L to Lorimer St

column7: This neighborhood beer haunt serves up free Sunday breakfast in the form of all-you-can-eat bagels and cream cheese. Add a Bloody Mary or mimosa ($5) to make it a proper brunch.
column60: Mon noon–2am; Tues–Sat noon–4am; Sun noon–2am
column92: 228 Atlantic Ave between Brooklyn Bridge Blvd and Court St
column144: Subway: M, R to Court St; 2, 3, 4, 5 to Borough Hall

column7: The latest addition to West Chelsea’s clubbing district is Guest House, which wisely meets the gentrified expectations of moneyed clubgoers. Expect frosty door reception, a $50 (four drinks) bar minimum, and a mostly white, late-twenties-to-late-thirties crowd, where men in suits and slim, well-groomed ladies suck on cigarettes and champagne. The smallish, two-room space offers simple decor; it’s lined with exposed brick, candlelit dark-wood cubby holes, and chocolate-brown “pleather” couches. If you’re lucky, you might see a saxist leap atop the deejay booth and belt out non–Kenny G. riffs to the dancing crowd’s delight.
column92: 542 W 27th St between Tenth and Eleventh Aves
column144: Subway: C, E to 23rd St

column7: It’s easy to make an ass of yourself at this UWS beer bar, especially on Thirsty Thursdays, when $15 gets boozers unlimited house liquor or bottomless pitchers of Coors Light. Despite the frat-house vibe and dorky decor (think theme-appropriate donkey images), most nights draw a neighborly, after-work crowd ready to down a pint of Killian’s and catch a game on the big screen. There are plenty of arcade diversions, a pool table and air hockey, so drinkers who work up an appetite find the connected diner—Homer’s Famous Malt Shop—particularly appealing.

column7: A lounge-club has opened on the 49th floor of the Marriott Marquis Times Square hotel—above the touristy rotating restaurant the View. The space is a work in progress, but it has killer views and bottle service.
column92: 1535 Broadway between 45th and 46th Sts
column144: Subway: N, Q, R, W, 42nd St S, 1, 2, 3, 7 to 42nd St–Times Sq

column7: With its high ceiling, dim hanging lamps and leather banquettes, this Gramercy Park lounge inherited much of its sultry DNA from its Nolita sister of the same name. The ’80s music is loud, as is the crowd, but the potent specialty cocktails go down easy. Neckties and pointy shoes not required, but they are de rigueur among the young professionals who come early and stay late.

column7: A gleaming wood bar and large bay windows give this pubby East Village bar a polished feel. Spotted Pig veteran Carolynn Spence designed the light menu of appetizers, panini and salads.
column60: Mon–Wed 4pm–2am; Thu, Fri 4pm–4am; Sat noon–4am; Sun noon–2am

column144: Subway: L to First Ave; N, Q, R, W, 4, 5, 6 to 14th St–Union Sq

column7: Members get to cut the line at this semi-exclusive midtown club, but civilians can enjoy some privileges for a $20 cover. The glam, Klimt-inspired interior makes buying into Fizz’s decadent fantasy easy—gilded murals and rich red fabrics were handpicked by Spice Market decorator Jacques Garcia. Naturally, champagne is the drink of choice; 30 varieties are offered, none of which are cheap (glasses start at $18, and bottles run $170 and up). If you want a seat, table service comes at a pricey two-bottle minimum. Note: Doormen are strict about the dress code, so no sneakers or scruffy jeans.
column92: 137 E 55th St at Lexington Ave
column144: Subway: 4, 5, 6 to 51st St–Lexington Ave

column7: This cavernous rock & roll wonderland has an impeccable jukebox, live bands in the downstairs lounge, and an enormous back room with zebra-striped banquettes and a pool table. A Dirty Harry mural takes aim over the main bar—it just might make your day.
column92: 105 Eldridge St between Broome and Grand Sts
column144: Subway: F to Delancey St; J, M, Z to Delancey–Essex Sts

column7: Nightclub owner Paul Drohan (Quo) has partnered with John Zaremba (Scopa) to open this Chelsea club and restaurant in the former Discothèque space.
column92: 17 W 19th St between Fifth and Sixth Aves
column144: Subway: F, V, N, R, W to 23rd St; 1 to 18th St

column7: Irish-born, English-raised bar owner Sean O’Rourke has opened a distinctively Irish bar in Williamsburg, with 21 beers on tap.
column92: 769 Metropolitan Ave between Graham Ave and Humboldt St
column144: Subway: L to Graham Ave

column7: It only took 24 years, but the hormone-driven bar from the raunchy cult film Porky’s has finally been reincarnated as a real live nightspot in Chelsea. The owners of Porky’s NYC promise, “Warm beer, lousy food, crazy fun!” What kind of fun exactly? The bosomy waitresses will literally wear the menu (last we heard, desserts would be scrawled on their butts) and the bar has been fitted with funnels for easier chugging. Howard Stern fans are already drooling.
column92: 55 W 21st St between Fifth and Sixth Aves
column144: Subway: F, V, N, R, W to 23rd St

column7: The owners of East Village bar the Raven have reopened an 80-year-old tavern, offering 12 beers on tap, a free jukebox and free Wi-Fi.
column92: 579 Meeker Ave between N Henry and Monitor Sts
column144: Subway: L to Lorimer St; G to Nassau Ave

column7: Despite the telling name, this basement joint is not particularly Irish. At this pleasant sanctuary along an otherwise uneventful stretch of 14th Street, the walls are warm with wood paneling, but the atmosphere is less lodgelike than beery tavern. Above-average bar food comes with the usual roundup of cold pints and mixed drinks, and is served by an attentive staff that lords over the modest dining area and ten-seat bar.
column8: Happy hourConversation-friendlyJukeboxFood

column7: The folks behind Irish pub One and One have opened this sleek spot below the bar, featuring maroon banquettes and onyx and dark wood tables.
column92: 76 E 1st St at First Ave
column144: Subway: F, V to Lower East Side–Second Ave

column7: If the Queen of Sheba had a bar in Soho, it would probably look like this sprawling lounge, with hieroglyphics-painted walls and Arabian-style lamps. Patrons can enjoy an apple-flavored hookah while reclining on cushy couches, or sip a sturdy martini (beware: the fruity ones favor syrups over fresh purees). DJs spin house beats nightly, and the music goes late on weekends.
column92: 157 Lafayette St between Grand and Howard Sts
column144: Subway: J, M, Z, N, Q, R, 6 to Canal St

column7: A former partner of Les Halles has opened this small Portuguese wine bar in...Times Square.
column92: 155 W 46th St between Sixth and Seventh Aves
column144: Subway: B, D, F, V to 47–50th Sts–Rockefeller Ctr; N, R, W to 49th St

column7: If you prefer to make like a punch-drunk, head to this divey East Village hang for a carafe of creamy Guinness and a chance to wail on the coin-operated punching bag.
column92: 507 E Fifth St at Ave A
column144: Subway: F, V to Lower East Side–Second Ave

column7: This slender, wood-paneled taproom hasn’t closed for a single day since Prohibition—or so boast the chatty barkeeps manning the storied Irish saloon. Afternoon regulars, young tipplers and occasional tourists make up the steady Guinness- and Jameson-sipping clientele. Outside, a neon Celtic harp (installed in 1933) glows bright yellow and red. Inside, flat-screen TVs appease the sports fans, and a jukebox spits out everything from Sinatra to Justin Timberlake.

column7: Although the 1980s movie of the same name conjures high-school hell, this East Village bar makes chillin’ in the classroom rather cool. Artsy locals perch on school chairs, sip $5 drafts and scribble messages on the chalkboard-covered bathroom walls. Live DJs enhance the quirky ambience several nights a week.
column92: 506 E 13th St between Aves A and B
column144: Subway: L to First Ave

column7: Brooklyn-based sports fans take note: This bi-level bar has five flat-screen TVs, two pool tables and two foosball tables, as well as a pub-style menu that features eight different burgers.
column60: Sun 10am–1am; Tue, Wed 11:30am–1am; Thu, Fri 11:30am–4am; Sat 10am–4am
column92: 72 Clark St at Henry St
column144: Subway: 2, 3 to Clark St

column7: An airy, wood-paneled space flanked by elegant wide-plank tables draws a well-dressed crowd of young professionals. This Hell’s Kitchen spot boasts a notable imported beer list: 35 types of brew, including seven frothy Belgian beers such as the chocolaty Corsendonk. It isn’t just a suds haven, either: Scotch-lovers can select from among 30-plus single-malts. That ought to keep the Vikings satisfied.
column92: 815 Ninth Ave at 54th St
column144: Subway: C, E to 50th St

column7: Leah Allen, a Carroll Gardens artist, has decorated her watering hole with thrift scores, a rescued church pew, a 27-foot-long bar and painted grasslike patterns. She also swears there will be no hip hop or TVs—if she can help it.
column92: 442 Court St at Third Pl
column144: Subway: F, G to Carroll St

column7: Dark Room co-owner Jason Baron has revamped the space that was formerly the industrial-looking club called Eleven. He’s added mahogany walls, gray banquettes and large, Art Deco light fixtures to the bar.
column92: 152 Orchard St between Rivington and Stanton Sts
column144: Subway: F, V to Lower East Side–Second Ave

column7: An unobtrusive facade, with maroon curtains in the windows, makes this East Village hookah bar look like it’s been in the neighborhood forever. Moroccan music videos play on a projection screen in back, while patrons smoke a variety of tobaccos—rose, tangerine and Turkish coffee, to name a few of the 45 flavors offered.
column92: 89 E 2nd St between Ave A and First Ave
column144: Subway: F, V to Lower East Side–Second Ave

column7: “Any bum off the street can come in and eat for free,” remarks a gleeful bartender about the drippy, spicy wings at this LES barroom. Drinks are cheap enough (Bud pints $2, well drinks $3) that you’ll be willing to fork over the cash for something to wash them down.
column92: 115 Essex St at Rivington St
column144: Subway: F to Delancey St; J, M, Z to Delancey–Essex Sts

column7: There’s plenty of space for penitents of all persuasions at this expansive Gaelic sports bar. Locals are drawn in by Irish bands on weekend evenings, and every other Wednesday is the pub’s quiz night. The menu features organic specials including a moist, delicious roasted chicken—but after a few lethal apple martinis, you won’t be feeling virtuous for very long.
column92: 59-21 Roosevelt Avenue at 60th St
column144: Subway: 7 to 61st St–Woodside

column7: Clubhoppers have yet another Chelsea spot to explore. At this trilevel space, designed by Steve Lewis (Marquee, Butter, Home), each floor has a different vibe and music: house, hip-hop and rock. The cover is $20.
column92: 215 W 28th St between Seventh and Eighth Aves
column144: Subway: 1 to 28th St

column7: The trendy Hotel Gansevoort has a kinda kooky spa-and-bar hybrid. Located in the basement, the red-toned space has treatment rooms that, come nighttime, serve double duty as VIP lounges. Owners Scott Sartiano and Richie Akiva (both of Butter) will likely maintain a tight velvet rope.
column8: NYCVisit: Glamour houndNYCVisit: Power broker
column92: 18 Ninth Ave at W 13th St
column144: Subway: A, C, E to 14th St; L to Eighth Ave

column7: The folks at the bar won’t do your laundry while you sip your pint of Old Speckled Hen. The name refers to the storefront’s past life as a laundromat. Everything else is pure English pub, including the Tuck Shop meat pies, dark wood interior and earnest devotion to good beer (there are 19 varieties on tap). During happy hour, weekdays from 3 to 8pm and 1 to 8pm on weekends, all drinks are half off.
column92: 211 Ave A between 13th and 14th Sts
column144: Subway: L to First Ave

column7: A bit under the radar still, Boudoir provides a respite from the more over-saturated club scenes of West Chelsea and the Meatpacking District. Its opulent setup, which includes oriental rugs and antique-looking furniture, is striking, though once the music gets going and the lights dim no one seems to notice. Yet while the design is nice, it isn’t really breaking any new ground. The door can be strict, but generally speaking you’re not missing all that much. On weekend evenings, a glam crowd grooves to a mix of hip hop and club classics, intermingling in the posh surroundings. The selective door makes for a very comfortable, breathable environment, and the relatively low-key vibe (for a place like this) is perhaps one of the more attractive elements.
column92: 127 Eighth Ave at 16th St
column144: Subway: A, C, E to 14th St; L to Eighth Ave

column7: Creatures of the night come to nest at this subterranean East Village bar, where the lights are low, the patrons well-heeled and the drinks properly stiff. Stake out one of the stylish pressed-tin tables, nibble on house-marinated olives and sip a proprietary Blue Owl—a sultry mix of Miller’s gin, maraschino liqueur and fresh lemon juice.
column92: 196 Second Ave between 12th and 13th Sts
column144: Subway: L to First or Third Ave

column7: Irish Tony and Polish Krystian are running their neighborhood bar as a democracy. They picked the draft beers via a Craigslist survey: Stella, Guinness, Brooklyn Lager, and Hefeweizen won out, and 12-ounce drafts are only $3. A few racks on the jukebox remain empty for customers’ CDs, and all selections are free until 7pm. Mondays feature half-price wine by the glass and bottle, and every Tuesday at 9pm, rockumentaries (featuring subjects such as Wilco, Radiohead or the Pixies) are projected onto the back wall.
column92: 428 Bergen St at Fifth Ave
column144: Subway: D, M, N, R to Pacific St; B, Q, 2, 3, 4, 5 to Atlantic Ave

column7: A good review might ruin the antiscene at certain intimate bars. So if anybody asks, Clandestino does not serve meticulously mixed drinks at reasonable prices, the staff is inhospitable, and the tin ceiling and slender chute of a patio lack all charm. It’s our little secret.
column92: 35 Canal St between Essex and Ludlow Sts
column144: Subway: F to East Broadway

column7: Party promoters Alex Martini, David Sherman and Yura Shabetayev have opened their own Chelsea nightspot decorated by David Graziano (Pink Elephant). Expect a strict velvet rope.
column92: 28 W 20th St between Fifth and Sixth Aves
column144: Subway: F, V, N, R, W to 23rd St

column7: Stephen Schwartz, the director of booking at this tri-level megaclub, has already lined up heavyhitters like DJ Tommie Sunshine and the crew from Turntables on the Hudson to spin.
column92: 225 E Houston St at Essex St
column144: Subway: F, V to Lower East Side–Second Ave

column7: It’s easy to find a beer in this town for $5—so why not a fine glass of wine? To our rescue comes this subterranean, grottolike café on the Lower East Side; an abbreviated menu includes cheese and charcuterie plates, panini and mini-quiches.
column8: FoodWine barLounge
column92: 42 Rivington St between Eldridge and Forsyth Sts
column144: Subway: F, V to Lower East Side–Second Ave

column7: Coco66, located in the nether regions of Greenpoint, is a bar where barely legal locals down pints of Guinness, well-dressed businessmen sip Scotch and greasy-haired hipsters stay focused on the music.
column92: 66 Greenpoint Ave between West and Franklin Sts
column144: Subway: G to Greenpoint Ave

column7: There’s a certain ilk of New York bars that, at first glance, are decidedly ordinary—they offer nothing special in terms of drinks, decor or anything else. Somehow, though, these unassuming, often rundown spots transcend any one of a number of stereotypes and provide pub crawlers with a terrific bar experience. No place fits the bill better than TriBeCa Tavern. While the decor borders on decrepit (TriBeCa Tavern may be a contender for Manhattan’s Worst Restroom), it’s actually quite homey: Ample tables provide plenty of seating space, but the real prize is up front, where a cozy enclave provides patrons with a view of bustling West Broadway. The friendly bartenders are more than happy to whip up whatever drink you desire, though the reasonably priced draft beer, served by the pitcher, is really the way to go. The standard digital jukebox and surprisingly good sound system, like most things at this great little bar, sound better than you would’ve thought.
column8: NYCVisit: Trendsetter
column92: 247 West Broadway between Walker and White Sts
column144: Subway: A, C, E to Canal St; 1 to Franklin St

column7: The owner of Williamsburg’s the Abbey has unveiled a tri-level bar featuring giant circus sideshow paintings and Skee-Ball machines.
column92: 113 Franklin St at Greenpoint Ave
column144: Subway: G to Greenpoint Ave

column7: Germans have been guzzling beer for long enough to know what soaks it up best: boiled knockwurst with crusty rolls and hot mustard, mountains of kartoffelsalat (potato salad) and giant slabs of Wiener schnitzel. At this biergarten, with more than eight selections on tap, you can’t beat the $55 haus special: a shareable wurst party platter with a five-liter keg of Spaten or Dortmunder.
column60: Mon 4pm–midnight; Tue, Wed noon–midnight; Thu–Sat noon–1am; Sun 1pm–midnight
column92: 39 Grove St between Bedford and Bleecker Sts
column144: Subway: 1 to Christopher St–Sheridan Sq

column7: Television fans need not fight over the remote here; the place has 18 plasma-screen TVs. Chef Sean Olnowich (Olives, Punch and Judy) has come up with a bar-food-inspired menu that features mini cheeseburgers and Cajun-style popcorn shrimp.
column60: Mon–Thu 4:30pm–midnight; Fri 4:30pm–2am; Sat noon–2am; Sun noon–midnight
column92: 103 Second Ave at 6th St
column144: Subway: F, V to Lower East Side–Second Ave; 6 to Astor Pl

column7: Bright blue walls, vintage posters and red booths characterize this Hell’s Kitchen bar. Cheap ($3 to $4) pints are offered nightly, as are free hot dogs.
column92: 615 Ninth Ave between 43rd and 44th Sts
column144: Subway: A, C, E to 42nd St–Port Authority

column7: Drink, hurl, repeat. Brag to friends: “Dude! I was hammered.” A notice stating you puke, you clean suggests that wastoids may indeed be the target market; a drink called Ass Juice (boasting “a little bit of everything and a whole lot of love”) confirms it. Huge, dark and surprisingly clean-smelling, Double Down—an offshoot of the Vegas punk bar of the same name—strives to be a dive and, by God, it succeeds.
column8: Happy hourCheap drinksOutdoor seatingGood for large groupsLive DJJukeboxFoodNoted mixologistFrattyDive barPool tablePinballVideo gamesNo steps at entranceWheelchair accessible bathroom

column144: Subway: F, V to Lower East Side–Second Ave

column7: Sixty TVs flicker with every athletic pursuit imaginable at this sports lovers’ Shangri-la. Domestic beer is the patriotic choice (Bass, Sam Adam’s Summer Ale, Blue Moon) and a fine foil to greasy pub grub like wings and burgers. If you want to do it right, order by the pitcher. You won’t be taking any dates here, but it’s a fine place to convene with buddies.
column92: 212 W 79th St between Amsterdam Ave and Broadway
column144: Subway: 1 to 79th St
column145: Subway: 4, 5, 6 to 96th St

column7: Charlie Palmer’s Upper West Side restaurant Kitchen 82 has been replaced by this Irish restaurant and bar. The prix fixe menu has been swapped out for traditional Irish pub grub (think Shepherd’s pie and bangers and mash).
column92: 461 Columbus Ave at 82nd St
column144: Subway: B, C to 81st St–Museum of Natural History

column7: This sleek Italian-style wine bar, where banker types devour cured meats, cheeses and olive oil, offers refuge from the South Street Seaport tourist scene. Located on historic Front Street, this TONY Eat Out Award winner boasts cast-iron columns, a polished walnut bar and a nifty metal wine rack that showcases the horizontally stowed bottles. Most patrons come for the selection of 60 wines (20 are available by the glass), but a well-stocked bar satisfies those who prefer the hard stuff.
column92: 220 Front St between Beekman St and Peck Slip
column144: Subway: A, C to Broadway–Nassau; J, M, Z, 2, 3, 4, 5 to Fulton St

column7: This chic K-Town lounge is nearly impossible to find—look for the blink-and-you’ll-miss-it sign out front. Ascend to the third-floor drinkery via a freight elevator that opens onto a spectacular bi-level space with soaring ceilings and modern, wraparound banquettes. Bartenders shake upscale drinks like lychee martinis and mojitos, and Korean sojus are available in fruity flavors like mango. Shell out $250 and a five-person, soundproof karaoke room equipped with flat-screen TVs is yours for the night.
column8: NYCVisit: ExplorerNYCVisit: Culture buff
column92: 11 W 32nd St between Broadway and Fifth Ave
column144: Subway: B, D, F, V, N, Q, R, W to 34th St–Herald Sq

column7: This Hell’s Kitchen Italian wine bar is decked out with all the accoutrements you’d expect: burgundy walls, dim lighting, a marble-topped bar and more than 75 wines, primarily from Italy. Snacks include salads and cured Italian meats.
column92: 667 Ninth Ave at 46th St
column144: Subway: A, C, E to 42nd St–Port Authority

column7: Vlada von Shats (who runs Russian Samovar) has stocked this stylish gay lounge with Soviet-style spirits. In addition to the 15 kinds of vodka infusions on the menu, the space features padded leather banquettes; a long, sleek bar; works by local artists; and coming soon, drag shows.
column92: 331 W 51st St between Eighth and Ninth Aves
column144: Subway: C, E to 50th St

column7: The space that housed chi chi lounge Suede has been reincarnated as a gay club opened by porn star-turned-party promoter Aaron Tanner. Expect a velvet rope, nightly DJs and theme parties.
column92: 161 W 23rd St between Sixth and Seventh Aves
column126: Cover (Fridays and Saturdays): $5 at 10pm, $10 after midnight. Average drink: $7
column144: Subway: F, V, 1 to 23rd St

column7: Woodside, Queens, bustles on, but this worn Irish pub stays the same. Well-lubricated old-timers line the front bar, while the wood-paneled dining room—made all the more classic with stained-glass adornment—recalls an honest age of prechain family dining. Irish-American pub fare like steak, roast beef and shepherd’s pie dominate the menu, but it’s the renowned burger that justifies the trek: loosely formed from freshly ground New York strip, broiled to a perfect char and simply decorated with lettuce and tomato—cheese and raw onion optional. In a city lousy with buzzworthy patties, this simple warhorse is still among the best.
column8: PubFoodRestaurant & bar
column92: 57-24 Roosevelt Ave at 58th St
column144: Subway: 7 to 61st St–Woodside

column7: Noel Ashman, the club owner who ran NA in the space that was once Nell’s, has converted the bi-level space—again—into a smaller, purple venue. Celebrity investors include Chris Noth, Jesse Bradford, Petra Nemcova, Joey McIntyre, David Wells, Bo Dietl, Damon Dash, Ethan Browne and Simon Rex.
column92: 246 W 14th St between Seventh and Eighth Aves
column144: Subway: A, C, E, 1, 2, 3 to 14th St; L to Eighth Ave

column7: A long wooden bar with plenty of beer on tap dominates the first floor of this bi-level space, while the rest of the room is filled with well-worn booths, televisions and sports team banners. Upstairs is more of the same, with a second, smaller bar and two oversize Ping-Pong tables where beer pong champs can show off their skills. Beginning at noon every Saturday and Sunday, patrons enjoy cheap domestic pitchers and half price wings; pitchers start at $3.50 but increase by fifty cents every hour.
column92: 109 MacDougal St between Bleecker and W 3rd Sts
column144: Subway: A, C, E, B, D, F, V to W 4th St; 1 to Houston St

column7: Belly dancers, flickering flames, hanging tapestries—Moroccan flourishes sure are fun. On the heels of other North African hot spots—Moomia, Casablanca Tea Room and Nomad—comes this bilevel Moroccan lounge, which has taken over the space that formerly housed the Bowery club Mission. Guests sit at low tables behind wooden sliding screens and sip cocktails made with exotic fruits, or snack on consulting chef Jonathan Lindenauer’s (Jean Georges, Taj) abbreviated menu. The place ain’t seriously smokin’ yet—they’re still waiting on the hookahs.
column92: 217 Bowery at Rivington St
column144: Subway: J, M, Z to Bowery; 6 to Spring St

column7: This rooftop bar dazzles with truly spectacular views of the Manhattan skyline, but it’s the indoor lounge—with its wraparound sofas and bold lighting—that should not be overlooked. It’s an 8,000-square-foot room pimped out in indigo lights, glass walls and snazzy furniture from owner Steven Greenberg’s own mid-century collection. Specialty cocktails are expensive and unremarkable, but this upwardly mobile crowd is too busy ogling the view (and their fellow drinkers) to mind.
column92: 230 Fifth Ave between 26th and 27th Sts
column144: Subway: N, R, W to 28th St

column7: Jazz trumpeter Luca Fadda and his wife Giorgia Zedda took an improvisational approach to their wine bar named after the Thelonious Monk song, though music events are limited to two festivals a year. Inexpensive wines—mostly from their native Italy—are available by the glass, carafe or bottle. Patrons can grab a rickety café table or a seat at the bar to imbibe, munch on cheese and olives, or partake in light lunches (salad, soup and panini) and pasta.
column60: Mon–Thu, Sun noon–12:30am; Fri, Sat noon–1:30am
column92: 200 Mott St between Kenmare and Spring Sts
column144: Subway: 6 to Spring St

column7: A mixture of sports bar and Irish pub, this 40-plus-year-old tavern is a haven for downtown sports fans. The straightforward drinks, no-frills milieu and typical pub-grub menu offerings encourage barflies to camp out during major games. For those who don’t mind a bar whose focal point is a flickering black box, nonjocks are welcome, too.
column92: 359 Bowery at E 4th St
column144: Subway: 6 to Astor Pl

column7: The fireplace, cozy sofas and club chairs at this rooftop bar suggest the decadent penthouse apartment you’ll probably never afford. The enclosed greenhouse and the outdoor terrace (in less frigid weather) are both ideal perches for sipping luxurious cocktails—such as the $12 Hemingway made with rum, mint and champagne—and enjoying the multimillion-dollar view of midtown’s soaring skyscrapers.
column92: 299 Madison Ave at 41st St, 14th floor
column93: Bookmarks Rooftop Lounge at the Library Hotel
column144: Subway: 42nd St S, 4, 5, 6, 7 to 42nd St–Grand Central

column7: This Restaurant Row gem serves dual symbiotic purposes: Whether you’re an actor in need of a stiff drink, or a Great White Way fan looking for a dose of backstage gossip, swank watering hole Centrale is just the place to get both. The elegant space comes alive after curtain call (around 11pm), when folks like Nathan Lane start to roll in. Drinks—such as pricey martinis and Manhattans—are competently made and ample, if a bit fussy in presentation. Despite this grievance, Bar Centrale succeeds because it exudes a quality that often escapes the geeky world of theater: It’s cool.
column8: After hoursAfter-work crowdArtsyConversation-friendlyFoodLoungeNeighborhood barNoteworthy cocktailsStrict door policyTrendy
column92: 324 W 46th St between Eighth and Ninth Aves, second floor
column144: Subway: A, C, E to 42nd St–Port Authority

column7: The mindless depravity never ends at the sprawling, boozy Finnerty’s, where fresh-faced coeds amass to slurp swilly beer so cheap, even penny-scrounging longhairs can afford a pitcher or four. The dark corners of the dart room are ideal for furtive snogs, but who are we kidding? After 2am, most patrons are too trashed to notice even the most blatant make-out sessions.
column92: 221 Second Ave between 13th and 14th Sts
column144: Subway: L to First Ave

column7: Under pressed-tin ceilings and swirling fans, the barkeeps at this mellow Mott Street wine bar serve about 20 vintages by the (stemless) glass. The frequently updated, Eurocentric list focuses on small producers and eclectic varietals. The lineup is mostly French, but some Austrian, Swiss, Slovenian, German and Northern Italian vinos add some nice twists. Selections are refreshingly affordable (bottles range from $35 to $70) and the atmosphere is punctuated by the film noir classics on flat-screen TVs.
column92: 228 Mott St between Prince and Spring Sts
column144: Subway: 6 to Spring St

column7: Is there anything better than free pizza? World peace maybe, but you can’t get that with your beer. Kid sister to Williamsburg’s Alligator Lounge, the Crocodile offers a plain minipie with every drink to a clientele of tattooed twentysomethings.
column92: 325 E 14th St between First and Second Aves
column144: Subway: L to First Ave

column7: Take care not to miss this sleek Astoria bar, marked only by a discreet red light. Once inside, you’ll find creative drinks, such as the Chocolate Egg Cream (vanilla-infused Jim Beam, chocolate syrup, cream and club soda), and the rosemary-infused blueberry-vodka martini, priced to move at just $6. A spacious backyard packed with benches is the place to be on Sunday nights, when B movies and indie flicks are projected on a ten-foot hanging screen.
column8: NYCVisit: Culture buffNYCVisit: Explorer

column7: The design snobs at Soho’s Moss have partnered with the wine geeks at I Trulli and Vino to open a wine bar with 100 Italian wines available by the glass, bottle and case. Much of the decor can be purchased around the corner at Moss.

column144: Subway: B, D, F, V to Broadway-Lafayette; 6 to Bleecker St.

column7: Essentially a smoker-friendly patio with tackle-shop decor, Trout keeps Cobble Hillbillies swimming in cheap booze and burgers. The Wheel of Death dictates the hourly snack or libation special, such as $3 Coronas, but the $8 Brooklyn Iced Teas—house-brewed tea with Jameson whiskey and honey—are a far better way to meet your maker.
column92: 100-102 Smith St at Pacific St
column144: Subway: F, G to Bergen St

column7: If half-naked go-go boys are your idea of eye candy, then this Washington Heights cubbyhole—among the ’hood’s first gay bars—is for you. The subdued lighting and Lucite tabletops suggest a speakeasy by way of Miami, but the vibe is Chelsea raucous thanks to nightly DJs and a Wednesday night drag show. Those seeking a quieter vibe should visit during the daily two-for-one happy hour (5–10pm), when you can score brews like Stella Artois and basic highballs on the cheap.

column7: This seasonal outdoor lounge (open May through September) offers small plates from Jeffery Chodorow’s Japanese eatery, Ono.

column144: Subway: A, C, E to 14th St; L to Eighth Ave

column7: Though the name suggests Upper East Side swank, this sprawling, 3,000-square-foot watering hole screams sports bar. Maybe it’s the four flat-screen TVs, fratty typessipping pints at the long bar or aromaof nachos wafting from the kitchen. Still, the steady crowd of locals that packs the place is a testament to its appeal; the “more is more” strategy helps too: There are 30 wines by the glass, 15 specialty martinis, 40 varieties of vodka and a DJon weekends.

column7: This sexy, red-walled barroom, decorated with vintage Italian movie posters and miniature scooters, is just the place for Upper East Siders seeking a downtown vibe. Take an expertly mixed Vespa Royale (prosecco, lychee puree, cassis and limoncello) to the year-round garden, into which live DJs pump atmospheric tunes on Thursdays and Fridays. Wine bar purists can go the traditional route: The list features 16 Italian, Spanish and American vinos by the glass and 80 by the bottle, plus a solid selection of digestivi geared toward the spillover crowd from the adjacent Mediterranean restaurant.

column7: You could easily miss this subterranean spot if it weren’t for the sign that says JIMMY’S painted on a doorway over an inconspicuous set of stairs. Once inside, you’ll see burnt-yellow walls displaying taxidermy, mismatched wood tables and medieval-style arched passageways. The focus here is beer; they serve 10 quality European selections on tap (20 in the bottle), many of which also make it into dishes filled with organic ingredients.
column60: Mon–Thu, Sun noon–2am; Fri, Sat noon–4am

column7: This inimitable bar and lounge, with itsarresting blue neon sign, pays homage to the neighborhood’s eclectic cultural mix—where else can you find a mojito sharing the menu with a Manischewitz martini? Locals head to the long oak bar for one of six beers on tap. Behind red velvet curtains that divide the lounge, performers take over the circular stage with a range of literary, comedic and musical acts that change nightly (cover varies). Free bingo on Mondays is a must-see—high-profile drag kings and queens (including TONY’s own Linda Simpson) play host; prizes include X-rated DVDs, booze and cold, hard cash.

column144: Subway: F, V to Lower East Side–Second Ave

column7: This East Village lair was built for romance. The interior is bedecked with a custom glass chandelier and ornate, Louis XIV–style mirrors; apple-red couches are usually crammed with couples; and the food is equally shareable—note the gooey fondues. The international selection of vino is half off on Mondays and Tuesdays, and though liquor is verboten, champagne, beer and wine cocktails—such as the thick Marin Port Flip featuring port, espresso and egg yolk—pick up the slack.

column7: Local college kids downing cheap beer converge on dumpy couches at this Union Square bar, which proclaims itself “the last dive bar in NYC.” While this certainly is not the case, rock blaring from the speakers and brawls erupting over the lone pool table do imply that 119 Bar is a quintessential hole.

column7: Like a well-stocked corner deli, a good neighborhood Irish bar doesn’t need imagination if it provides standard-issue comforts within crawling distance of your apartment. Cheap booze, televised sports, hot wings—what else could Murray Hill residents need?

column7: This East Village wine bar offers meat and cheese plates, plus live Jazz every Wednesday night.

column7: This Murray Hill bar aims for casual elegance with candles and leather banquettes. Some might find the loud, tinny music and sugar-rimmed Chill-a-tinis (one house special is spiked with Tang) more ill than chill. But the place draws a thick crowd of paraprofessionals, happily hanging in the latest styles from J.Crew. A few blocks from Grand Central, it’s perfectly situated for an after-work drink between the office and Metro-North.

column7: Every hour is happy hour at this predominantly Irish pub. Much of the wood-paneled interior has been given over to a dining area, but the close-knit regulars prefer to sip their beer at the bar. Thursday through Sunday nights bring free live pop and rock music, and a DJ on Saturday night spins house.

column7: Modern kitsch meets old-world chic in a funky fusion of couches and candlelight at this boudoir-themed bar. Potent cocktails sport red-light monikers—Tie Me to the Bedpost (amaretto, coconut rum, peach schnapps with Sprite, orange and pineapple juices), 1-900-F*CK-MEUP (raspberry vodka, triple sec, amaretto and coconut rum with fresh lemon and raspberries) and Sex on the Sofa (raspberry vodka and peach schnapps with orange and cranberry juices). The young and flirtatious crowd gathers for regular theme nights, like $5 martini Mondays.

column7: This train-themed Sunnyside spot features three bars with 14 beers on tap, including some fine Irish selections like Harp and Guinness. For recreation, there is off-track betting and enough TV screens to give a small child seizures. Weekend evenings play host to the lively locals, though a calmer mood prevails at Sunday’s brunch.

column7: Sand in Your Pants never felt so good. The cheekily named drink, made with mango vodka, melon liqueur and fresh pineapple juice, is just one of many muddled-fresh-fruit cocktails served at the forever jam-packed bar of this fish-and-chips joint. Opened by the owners of another popular Aussie place, the Sunburnt Cow, this LES bar has a laid-back vibe enhanced by floor-to-ceiling photomontages of Australia’s famous Bondi beach and expats sipping on imported beers like Tooney’s Lager and Blue Tongue pilsner.

Like its East Village sibling (on East 7th St between First and Second Avenues), the venue also offers a connoisseur’s collection of wine, port and beer.

Jardi means “garden” in Catalan, and the name is embodied by the vine-laced trellises and hanging plants that drape the bar’s brick-walled interior. Garlicky tapas perfume the room, and house music spurs spontaneous partying after 11pm on weekends.
