Downstairs, spectators are treated to a rotating roster of live talent, such as blaring bands, comedians and a monthly science night.

Inside, at the shiny wooden bar, tranquility gives way to collegiate mayhem: A massive Irish flag and sports-favoring flat-screen TVs provide the backdrop to beer-bong fests. Fittingly, a Jägermeister machine sits beside a chalkboard listing the bar’s Top 10 drunks.

We prefer the cavernous, mahogany-and-brick room on chill weeknights; weekends find this hive positively buzzing. You’ve been warned.

It’s no wonder Wine and Roses is a hit with couples—the beret-wearing owner, Todd Klein, bought it as an anniversary gift for his wife. Here’s to husbands raising the bar.

Tasty burgers served late into the evening fill another hunger.

Late afternoons and early evenings are ideal for serious sippers enjoying plates of Murray’s Cheese, while the after-dark set veers dangerously close to Phi Kappa territory.

Look past the surfer crossing sign, however, and you’ll see this place for what it is: a rowdy sports bar with flirtatious bar vixens, where dudes slam “Jäger Bombs”—Jägermeister submerged in a glass of Red Bull, $7—to the sounds of Top 40 tunes. Far out indeed.

column7: This underground lounge, hidden in Barneys and Bloomies land, features sumptuous touches like a see-through bar, red velvet banquettes and tobacco-colored faux-croc-leather wall panels. The presence of a shooting-hoops game is just as befuddling, but it doesn’t prevent the martini-sipping crowd from resembling those at most UES after-work hangs.

column7: When Cary Grant made North by Northwest, drinking was a pastime for grown-ups. This bar, named for the 1959 film, embodies bygone sophistication with classic drinks intended for savoring, not pounding. One of the martinis, for example, is made with delicate saffron-infused gin, and the Century mixes fresh blueberries and raspberries with muddled lime, vodka and Chambord. Like the white-aproned waiters, the clean decor is no-fuss: just cherrywood flooring, white walls and chocolate leather seating.

The bar offers a decent choice of bottled beers, as well as wines by the glass or bottle—including a broad international selection. Hungry? Try the terrific focaccia-like pizza topped with sliced meatballs and caramelized onions.

Prime yourself with a racy Red Light Green Light (coconut rum, sour apple schnapps, vodka, triple sec and grenadine) before taking to the dance floor. On wilder nights, the stripper pole is put...um...to good use.

Locals gobble Aussie eats like burgers topped with beets, pineapples and fried eggs, but the real lure is the international beer: New Zealand’s Steinlager is on tap, as is California’s Lagunitas IPA. Brews are dispensed in small, medium and large, helping you to pick a properly sized poison during happy hour (Mon–Fri 4–7pm).

column7: Sorry, Virginia, there is no Santa Claus at Harlem’s half-century-old jazz haunt, where Miles Davis tippled and tooted and Billie Holiday first belted tunes. Descend into this low-ceilinged, underground lair (illuminated by Christmas lights and bare bulbs), grab a stiff drink at the rickety bar and plant your roots. Chatty jazz aficionados sip brews and watch lively musicians wail onstage; a pic of sax saint Charlie Parker hangs in reverence.

column7: There’s no taxidermy here and the space doesn’t double as a general store, but this Park Slope restaurant-pub cultivates the same quasicolonial vibe pioneered by Freemans and Marlow & Sons. The place has the look of an old photo: Booths are black, walls are white, and lighting comes from filament bulbs. Primo bar treats include fries with herbed mayo and the very French radish-and-butter baguette. But it’s best to come for the drinking. Old-timey cocktails are quite good, and the beer list, with alternating Six Point brews on tap and several domestic organic beers, is far more original than the place’s vintage conceit.

Chitchatty locals sit at low tables to tipple during the daily 4 to 8pm happy hour, when the drinks are two-for-one.

Join them to snack on spiced nuts, admire the stamped-tin ceilings, and listen while bartenders explain the menu of 35 suds (including five on tap) and their tastiest possible grub pairings. Then consider pairing a pint of Bear Republic Racer 5 IPA with flaky pastry-wrapped chorizo.

column7: The AvroKO-designed restaurant Public now has a teeny-weeny wine-bar sidekick. The upscale den features tufted black banquettes and exposed brick. Sip from 60 vinos in various sizes, such as a 2005 Soave Classico in a half glass, glass, half bottle or bottle. Wine flights ($19–$40 for four three-ounce tastes) are a fine way to sample your way through the list; there’s no standing room here and it gets packed, so reserve ahead.

column7: This rockabilly dive’s drinks rival the nearby Gowanus Canal for sheer toxicity. Surly, busty bartenders serve domestic brews and Herculean shots of cheap whiskey to rocker types, locals and pool sharks who are as colorful as the kitschy, chaotic decor. Deer heads share space with vintage beer signage and a black-and-white TV broadcasting JFK-era ads, while a jukebox spins funk, soul and punk mix-CDs compiled by regulars.

Pre- and postshow, couples congregate on low gray banquettes, sip craft brews such as $9 Allagash White or $7 Blue Point, or enjoy a glass of vino. Locals emerge for Friday’s $15 all-you-can-drink sangria night.

column7: Weary commuters need only stumble off the 7-train platform to find this restorative vino refuge. The intimate room, with its vintage lights and leather-topped stools, is an ideal setting for sipping from a selection of more than 40 wines by the glass (stored in antique wooden cabinets). In addition to nibbling from free plates of olives and splurging on iced oysters, customers can take in live jazz twice a week.

column7: Ditch the dingy Chucks and slip on classier kicks before setting out to sip a pomegranate martini at this upmarket Williamsburg spot. Sixteen-foot ceilings, a handsome mahogany bar and tropical plants aplenty serve as the backdrop for a nightly lineup of live DJs and bluegrass bands. The decor is mismatched (woven leather seating pairs oddly with a sports-spewing television), but salvation lies in the all-season patio, where alfresco drinkers and smokers can mingle beneath the starry sky.

Chattering businessmen and time-killing tourists enjoy tuxedo-sporting mixologists’ $15 martinis, both classic (olives in Bombay Sapphire) and current (“Gingerbread” with vanilla vodka, orange juice and Captain Morgan).

There, black-clad bartenders muddle fruity and herbed cocktails—like the citrus-mint martini and mellow cucumber Cosmo—to order. The cut-rate happy hour (Mon–Fri 5–9pm) finds drinks discounted to $4, fostering a loquacious, toasting crowd.

Black walls and cushy booths combine with chandeliers to set the luxuriously somber mood. Patrons bored by shot-and-beer bars can sample the inventive cocktails, including a fiery Fresa Brava (strawberries and jalapeño-infused tequila), as well as top-notch grub including bacon-swaddled filet mignon bites.

column7: Buxom ’50s pinups—not doctors—rule at this coffeeshop-turned-bar named for the notorious Bettie Page. Inside, swivel stools and slouchworthy couches are taken over by jeans-sporting Lower East Siders sipping frosty brews and bubble-gum martinis. The attentive bartenders’ modern iPod playlists never crush conversations, and the weekend hordes mercifully leave Bettie to the locals.

Candle-topped tables are ideal for canoodlers and voyeurs alike (floor-to-ceiling windows offer a fine view of passersby).

column7: In a space-optimizing transformation, EN Japanese Brasserie turned its foyer into an airy lounge. Walls of windows make for a light-suffused room, decorated with rice-paper scrims, Far Eastern sconces and communal tables. A well-heeled downtown set can choose from two dozen varieties of EN’s namesake Japanese vodka, and cocktails like the $12 Showa—Maker’s Mark bourbon mixed with ginger-infused honey and ginger ale.

column7: This Lilliputian dive, marked by scuffed vinyl floors, sticker-dotted, wood-paneled walls and a classic juke, is the definition of no-frills. Daily shot deals ($3.75 a pop) and the ’hood’s cheapest pints draw a dude-heavy throng of early-afternoon tipplers and nine-to-fivers. Barstools are prized commodities, so prepare to stand. When nature beckons, the bathrooms’ graffiti provides extra entertainment.

column7: Probably the closest thing the seaport has to a Williamsburg vibe, this cozy, nautical-themed spot fosters a robust bar scene. Locals have made it a headquarters, downing suds and fancy cocktails in equal proportions. The raised seating area has rough-hewn pews and comfy booths where you can pick at bar snacks (salads, sandwiches) and get a bird’s-eye view of the evening’s shenanigans.

column7: An ocean-fresh raw bar and icy microbrews, not Styrofoam buckets of suds, rule at this upscale offshoot of nearby dive Jeremy’s. Lunching businessmen pack the upstairs lounge to munch half-pound burgers, oysters and po’ boys at paper-topped tables, which are equipped with crayons for sudden inspiration. After dark, easygoing locals rule the slender downstairs bar, downing Dogfish Head and Lone Star brew and playing Connect Four beneath lazily spinning ceiling fans.

column7: Over the years, this old-timey bar and restaurant, established in 1873, has become home to a motley group of locals who plant themselves on the stools at the U-shaped mahogany bar. Big-screen TVs, cheery barkeeps, a kick-ass jukebox and eighteen beers on tap, including Boddingtons and Blue Moon, make up for the overly bright lighting and minuscule bathrooms.

column7: Sail away to Latin America at this airy Seaport-area tapas spot, bedecked with whitewashed walls and oversize dark-wood seats. While Cuban jazz musicians strum tropical tunes and paella perfumes the bi-level room, adventurous tourists and unwinding Wall Streeters relax in high-backed chairs at the snug, tiled bar. Cordial bartenders serve hefty carafes of fruit-stocked sangria, expertly mixed minty mojitos and rum-packed caipirinhas embellished with raw-sugarcane swizzle sticks.

column7: Brokers’ fresh-pressed shirts and shiny leather shoes rule at this downtown alehouse, located on a quaint cobblestone block in the Financial District. After the markets close, the weathered wood floors get further scuffed by martini sippers and Coors Light chuggers, whose boisterous gabbing competes with a circa-1996 soundtrack (hello, Cranberries!). Later on, the bar evolves into a serene spot to grab a pint or lofty pub eats like Parmesan-crusted fries and a beer-battered grouper sandwich with tartar sauce.

column7: Despite it’s proximity to P.S.1, this modest Irish pub decorated with gnomes, sports-favoring TVs and abundant neon is an unaffected hangout. Museumgoers rub elbows with graffiti artists (the legal taggers’ haven 5 Pointz is next door), workaday joes and suits, who order properly poured Guinness pints and sweet Shannon Pot Shamrock Ales. Teetotalers sit at paper-covered tables and munch burgers and fish-and-chips to the sounds of rock and roll and the rattling 7 train.

column7: Sepia images of jazz, funk and soul legends line the walls at this warm, earth-toned cocktail emporium. Waitresses dressed in retro outfits glide amid crescent-shaped leather booths, and it’s likely that you’ll hear Coltrane oozing from the speakers. Given the old-fashioned aesthetic, a classic cocktail is the way to go: Try a well-crafted Negroni or a bracing Dark & Stormy (dark rum, ginger beer and lime juice).

column7: Amsterdam Billiards and Bar at Union Square Blazing red neon adorns the legendary Upper West Side pool hall’s downtown locale, situated in Corner Billiards’ formerly dingy digs. The $2 million face-lift bought pressed tin, oak paneling, Oriental rugs and 26 pro-quality tables. The scene is crammed with hustlers, league players and NYU students alike. The billiards-averse appropriate the curvaceous zinc bar and maroon couches for potent Long Island iced teas before shooting darts or eyeballing sports on flat-screen TVs.

The snug woodsy environs, decorated with brew labels and ESPN-tuned plasma-screen tellys, attracts a Jekyll-and-Hyde crowd: Beer nerds arguing about hops bump shoulders with office refugees eager to power-chug Heineken Light ($3) and slam Patrón ($6).

Conversation-minded drinkers head for the copper-barred main taproom, with ample seating and reasonably pitched house music spun live on weekends. The higher-decibel Moroccan Lounge hosts a mix of dressed-for-clubbing partyers and private-event guests. Both bars serve Asian appetizers and not-too-sweet, amply poured cocktails. Exotica rules here: Tokyo Rose is made with Grey Goose, yet smacks of perfume.

Attractive waitresses serve French-fusion fare to a clearly nonneighborhood cast of well-off uptowners and out-of-towners, who are partial to the strong, tropical-flavored potions emphasizing fresh fruit, like the Passion St. Germain (champagne, passion-fruit puree and Chambord). If this scene sounds too stuffy, escape to the upstairs deck; it’s crowned with a roof that opens, Mother Nature willing.

World beats set the tone for the blissed-out crowd, and cocktails, like the Azzamore (strawberry vodka, triple sec, pomegranate juice and strawberry puree) or the Mint Tease (Citrus vodka, Cointreau, lemon-mint simple syrup and green tea) keep everyone friendly. Sporting types should head to the game room for gentlemanly pursuits such as pool, chess, poker...and PlayStation 3.

Weeknights, A&K is mellow; weekends welcome velvet ropes and camera-phone–wielding TRL groupies hoping for glimpses of Ashlee Simpson and sipping suitably named cocktails like White Guilt (peach vodka and vanilla soy milk).

column7: The entrance to this taxidermy-strewn saloon is hidden behind an old phone booth inside Crif Dogs. Pick up the receiver and a hostess opens the back wall of the booth. Inside, mixologist Jim Meehan offers elite cocktail creations like the frothy Judgment Day, a pleasing mix of citrus, allspice and floral St. Germain. The old-fashioned—made with smoky, bacon-infused bourbon and maple syrup—has become the joint’s best-known drink. The staff is happy to talk you through any libation on the menu, or suggest an haute dog brought in from next door. It’s that kind of dedication that makes getting in worth the effort.

The Spartan, square ,wood-floored room is ringed with de rigueur brick walls (painted purple, naturally), while a disco ball sparkles willy-nilly. Gawk at their see-through shakers as they pour drinks like the Groovy (shiso-infused vodka and yuzu juice) or the Giant Steps (wasabi-infused vodka and sake). Still peckish? Head upstairs to Tokyo Bar, where Japanese comfort food is served late.

column7: Patois and Pacifico owner Jim Mamary strikes again at this corner wine bar, a 2008 Eat Out Award nominee. On sunny days, patrons sink into Adirondack chairs on the rustic front deck. On chilly nights, they settle by the fireplace inside the white, farmhouse-chic main room. Dozens of international small-production vintages are on offer by the glass, matched to charcuterie and served charmingly on a stone slab. A good bet is “Shane’s Pick”—a $6.50 daily-rotating selection chosen by the manager.

column7: An enoteca on a Village strip known for discount footwear transcends its surroundings with low lighting, tiny wooden tables and great service. An expertly curated wine list rotates weekly, and the 18 wines by the glass might include a full-bodied Cotes de Bourg Bordeaux. Bottled suds and basic cocktails (the owners are former Union Square Cafe barkeeps) are on offer for nonvinophiles.

Nine-to-fivers sit at the 50-foot bar to down Brooklyn Lager pints ($4 until 8pm) and Julius Caesars (vodka, Grand Marnier, blood-orange puree and lime). An indie dance track lures the recently diplomaed set after dark; those who prefer to leave their dorm-room escapades in the past should plan to take their nightcap elsewhere.

column7: Insane rent sent this Gramercy-area Irish pub scuttling to Red Hook’s former Liberty Heights Tap Room space, a sprawling, roof-decked haunt with a view of the waterfront. While Rocky’s still serves brick-oven pizzas, also offered at Liberty, and brewed-next-door Sixpoint Ales, Irish touches such as draft Guinness and Celtic hip-hoppers on Friday nights turn this distant destination into a Gaelic roadhouse worth the journey.

Retro pinball machines and a solid rock & roll jukebox are on tap for those requiring added stimulation.

column7: Visit Finland by way of Billyburg at this eco-friendly lounge. Bare-filament lightbulbs cast a dim glow, and long benches make a fine place to sip designer cocktails. Try the Victorian (Bombay Sapphire, Earl Grey syrup and apple juice) and breathe deeply: Oulu’s plant-covered wall allegedly provides enough oxygen for 46 people per year.

Classic cocktails (think Pimm’s cups) mingle with signature drinks like the Michael Derry (Stella Artois, vodka and lemon juice). Randolph will feature weekly theme nights, but Prohibition buffs shouldn’t hold their breath—parties, like the Sunday evening tribute to Prince, tend toward the latter half of the century.

Those who can’t afford a room can hang in one of two lounges: Rose Bar and Jade Bar (reservations required).

column7: Hidden behind a glowing neon sign that reads empanadas eat late sits this speakeasy-style LES lounge. Stroll past the mirrored wall, commandeer a coal-colored banquette and order a potent, freshly prepared caipirinha ($8; two for one from 7 to 9pm). A late-twenties crowd of stylish singles prowls to thebeat of a nightly DJ dropping funk, house and soul. If you’re hungry, grab one of those flaky golden pies—yes, they really do sell them.

column7: Restaurateur John McDonald (Lever House, Lure Fishbar) tapped onetime Hollywood set designers Roman and Williams for the dramatic overhaul of Brasserie 44, the restaurant of design hall-of famer the Royalton Hotel, in 2007. The eatery’s buzzed-about lounge, Bar 44, takes late-night reservations if you want a guaranteed spot to sip your cocktail. House specialties include the Runway, which contains Don Julio Silver tequila, agave nectar syrup and blood orange puree, and the Recess Is On (named after our current economic state—get it?), made with Bulleit bourbon, ginger, fresh orange and a Campari rinse. To satisfy your postshow munchies, graze at the raw bar or crunch on fresh popcorn with white-truffle butter.

In fairer weather, join the after-work crowd—no trendoids here (yet)—in the smoker-friendly backyard to sip 12 drafts such as Guinness ($6) and devour bulging burgers, before retreating to the expansive, honey-hued main room. Plentiful, padded banquettes create a comfy refuge from LES weekend madness.

Near the distressed-wood bar, a largely single crew crowds around tall bar tables, snacking on panini and artisanal cheeses. In the adjoining lounge, DJs spin pulse-quickening tunes while waitresses flit between low banquettes, delivering glasses of Italian and Spanish wines—more than 100 of them include a spicy, light red schiava from the Alto Adige region in Northern Italy.

Order a longneck of Texas’ Lone Star beer, then another, and join the hooting, hollering throngs for a bucking ride on the bovine.

The formidable beer list—40 ever-rotating drafts—includes Bear Republic’s fragrant Racer 5 IPA. Mull over your selection, complete with appetizing tasting notes, at the wide communal tables. The gastro end of things is manifest in the menu of top notch pub grub (foie-stuffed prunes, panko-encrusted asparagus) designed by Wayne Nish (March).

column7: Visit South Africa via Hell’s Kitchen at this urban-rustic wine bar (the name’s pronounced “shai shai”). High wood-beam ceilings held aloft by thick cypress-tree logs shelter a bustling pre- and posttheater crowd. Pick from about 100 South African wines served in beakerlike carafes (we like the Tumara Malbec with notes of vanilla), and explore a menu that ranges from the familiar (oysters) to the outré (ostrich tartare).

column7: This roomy, Austro-Hungarian biergarten, an Eat Out Award winner for best new authentic beer hall, attracts young families in addition to the expected Billyburg revelers. The former take to the woodsy dining room, where flame-grilled sausages plucked from the grill can be enjoyed under towering ceilings and iron chandeliers. The heated, retractable-roof beer garden, meanwhile, welcomes a rowdier set, which commandeers colossal communal tables and clinks steins of more than a dozen foamy drafts, like crisp Radeberger Pilsner or dark Weihenstephaner Dunkel Weisse.

Climb into a chest-height chair in the company of stylish downtowners, and select from more than two dozen French reds and whites by the glass poured by tie-clad waiters. Hungry? The late-night kitchen turns out buttery, offbeat eats like truffle-topped quiche and a beef Wellington “éclair.”

Suds and vinos hail almost exclusively from the Eastern Bloc, but don’t be intimidated by their tough-to-say names: Go ahead and tip back a bottle of Zywiec, a hoppy Polish lager.

Unwind with postwork patrons to the sounds of techno and world music while sampling dozens of New World, French and Spanish vintages served by the glass (and more than 100 bottles). If you get peckish, graze on panini such as ham and Brie.

Park your keister beside fellow suds enthusiasts and order rare microbrews (read about upcoming kegs at bargreatharry.com), such as the palate-punching Great Divide Hercules Double IPA.

column7: European suds get the speakeasy treatment at this murky, unmarked cellar that could double as an S&M dungeon. Coarse brick walls and votives sheathed in broken bottles welcome serious beer geeks whom you’ll elbow aside for a seat at the brass bar. Once there, you can sample 60-odd imported quaffs, such as the tart Belgian ale Rodenbach ($5), or devour a pretzel-bread sandwich (try it with ham and Camembert). Visit the loo before you leave: Appropriately, it features a re-creation of Brussels’ legendary peeing-boy statue.

Linger over a smooth, full-bodied Ripasso di Valpolicella and its perfect match: a sweet-salty goat-cheese, caramelized-onion and mushroom flatbread.

A dozen killer microbrews on tap include spicy Allagash White poured by the pint ($6) or pitcher ($21).

Choose from 18 wines by the glass (including a bubbling, $11 lambrusco), paired with antipasti and lush homemade pastas from chef Simone Parisotto (Sant Ambroeus).

Downstairs, booths salvaged from the Godfather set are prime perches for sipping a Miller High Life or Truck-Stop Tea—a sweet mix of Jack Daniel’s, iced tea and Country Time Lemonade.

column7: The mood is akin to a wine bar (minus the hauteur) at this brew enthusiast’s dream. The friendly staff can guide you, sommelier-like, through the menu of rare and obscure beers, including Hanssens Kriek—a tart, bright red lambic fermented from sour cherries and served from the cask. The Swiss Brasserie Des Franches-Montagnes’ La Meule, meanwhile, goes down like a spice box of sage and thyme. Many of these beers shock on first gulp, and you may wonder whether your curious quaff was worth the price. But after the last taste-bud-teasing sip, you’ll leave convinced that your pennies were well spent.

The tattooed barkeeps serve Fizzy Presbyterians (rye, ginger syrup, lime juice and soda) and bourbon-drenched old-fashioneds over ice slabs. column7: Joining a recent glut of bar openings in Prospect Heights is this sports den that boasts an 800-square-foot garden. The ten beers on tap include summery Honey Moon and Hoegaarden, and an extensive pub-grub menu features a signature “inside-out” burger (a cheese-stuffed patty). Those not content to loiter in front of one of four flat-screen TVs can participate in organized “sports”: A Tuesday night Nintendo Wii bowling league should gear up in the coming weeks.

column7: This East Village bar owes its atmosphere to co-owner and Tony–award-winning set designer William Ivey Long, who filled the cozy pub with stained-glass flourishes, an abundance of orchids, cherrywood-paneled walls and Louise Bourgeois lithographs. Despite frat bait like well-priced beer (the house ale goes for just $5 a pint), there’s little spillover from the area’s college-friendly bars. Instead you’ll find low-key tipplers conversing over fresh-squeezed screwdrivers and greyhounds, made to order with an old-fashioned citrus press on the bar.

The superknowledgeable waitstaff aptly helps patrons navigate the 36 by-the-glass options. Equally compelling is the lineup of wine and beer cocktails, including the frothy Abby Flip (Ommegang Abbey Ale, coriander syrup, pomegranate molasses and egg) and restaurant-caliber small plates (sage-wrapped lamb sausages). Stellar sips and a menu to match: Hallelujah!

Significant others and bored accomplices can find refuge from the racks at a fully stocked bar, where daily happy-hour specials include a buck off all drinks—including a sweet, deep red pomegranate martini—until 8:30pm. If the tab becomes stratospheric, visit the downstairs clothing exchange to trade in vintage threads for bar credit.

Cheese and charcuterie culled from Stinky make for fine accompaniments to 120 whiskeys and 50-plus wines by the glass (starting at $5). Those prowling for a mixed drink should request the namesake cocktail—the Jakewalk is a stiff, balanced blend of St. Germain, tequila, rum and ginger liqueur.

column7: Greenpoint’s luxurifaction accelerates with this Chelsea-sleek lounge in a converted warehouse. The cavernous space embodies minimalism, with modular brown and blue furniture, cinder-block walls and a long, lacquered-cement bar, where condo owners and bike messengers alike sip three-buck Brooklyn and Sixpoint pints (daily 4–7pm). Enjoy both high- and lowbrow booze—specialty spirits like absinthe are available, as is a $15 “bucket of crap,” containing an assortment of canned swill such as Keystone and Schlitz.

When not wiggling their rumps to nightly DJs (such as Sweatshop Labor), revelers scoot into wooden booths to suck back two-for-one drinks (daily 4–9pm). Dark and stormies are appropriately rummy, and a whiskey-fueled Lower Manhattan is a serious attitude adjuster.

column7: This Hudson River–hugging nautical “dive bar” from Taavo Somer (Freemans) and Ken Friedman (the Spotted Pig) is a confusing—but successful—high-low hybrid. Faux Tiffany lamps and neon beer signs clash with the elaborate tiki cocktails (devised by Milk and Honey vet Toby Maloney), and with the foppish hordes who queue up outside the place. You’d never find the eponymous Rusty Knot—a refreshing, blender-whirred mix of rum, ice and mint—or eats like a luxe bacon–chicken liver sandwich at a grimy pub. But you would find three-buck pints of Busch and 50¢ rounds of pool. Happily the Knot has those bases covered, too.

column7: There’s no bar at this burgundy-draped lounge from owners Larry Kramer and Craig Koenig (also of R&R and Retreat). Instead, cocktail servers transport drinks—like the Hi Ho (gin, white port and bitters)—from the back of the house to marble-topped tables. The goal is prohibition-era formality, a surprising endgame for a pair of nightlife impresarios whose previous projects adhered to the B&T-friendly Meatpacking and West Chelsea mold.

column7: It was once the target of “die, yuppie scum” protests, but now that the conflict has cooled, we can appreciate this innocuous, dimly lit lounge for what it is: a garden-variety wine bar. The affordable, American-leaning selection is trim—about two dozen whites and reds, with a few sparklers and sweet wines thrown in. But the list is carefully assembled, offering a quality example of most varietals. Better still is BWC’s homemade sangria (we tried the red): easy, fruity and take-the-edge-off refreshing. Not genius; just good. A bit like the bar itself.

column7: The latest in a series of bar openings along the Bowery includes this 2,000-square-foot drinkery from nightlife entrepreneurs Johnny T (Black & White), Mike Stuto (HiFi) and Jesse Malin (Niagara). Located in the former Remote Lounge space, TBE features a wenge (dark African wood) bar, custom-made mohair couches and vintage trunks that serve as extra seating. Old Speckled Hen and Sapporo are among the dozen beers on tap, and house cocktails include the eponymous Bowery Electric (vodka, Midori and lemon juice) that ought to be a hit with the ladies.

column7: Chef Neil Ganic (La Bouillabaisse, Petite Crevette) took over the former Lillie’s space to open this Red Hook bar named for his daughter. An interior restoration of the waterside spot uncovered original tiling and a 30-foot mahogany bar. Six beers are on tap (including the requisite Sixpoint selections, brewed nearby), and cocktails include the Big Apple manhattan—Maker’s Mark with Berentzen (German apple schnapps). True to Ganic’s kitchen background, the full menu transcends typical pub grub. Expect mini po’ boys, ratatouille gratinée and freshly shucked oysters. A back garden, featuring a blue-crab steamer and enough room for 50 landlubbers, is in the works.

Inside you’ll find a handsome oak bar, but the real scene is outdoors, where picnic tables are packed with grateful locals. Join them to sip one of a dozen pricey-for-the-’hood drafts, like He’Brew’s crisp Coney Island Lager.

There are 12 local microbrews on tap, and excellent cocktails include a sweet and woodsy blood-orange margarita. Grub like crispy buffalo wings brings in the locals, who lay claim to the booths and low-slung tables. If you can’t score a seat, grab a 40 and perch upon Brooklyn’s real answer to a country porch—someone’s stoop.

column7: You’ll need a magnifying glass to navigate the chalk-drawn wine list at this dimly lit vino depot, oddly named for Jack the Ripper’s hunting grounds. Happily, knowledgeable servers are there to help, and the collection of global organic wines—16 glasses, most for less than $10, and 50 bottles—rewards your troubles. Standouts include Morocco’s fruit-forward Syrocco syrah or a floral Austrian Grüner Veltliner. Snacks are basic but tasty—stick to cold plates like oysters and tartares.

Cocktails are the focus: Order up a Gin & Sin (Bombay Sapphire, Chambord, lemon and lime juice) to pair with a housemade pizza.

Two terraces—one providing a Fifth Avenue vista, the other a view of the Hudson to the west—are outfitted with daybeds fashioned from ornately carved timber. Eastern-tinged cocktails like the Ning Sling (mandarin vodka, lychee liqueur, mint, and lychee and passion fruit juices) and spirits like Chinese Baojing vodka and Tyku, an infused sake, keep with the theme. Ditto the abbreviated menu: Try tea-dusted shrimp or avocado maki.

Owner Trevor Budd’s beer-bar pedigree (he is a Ginger Man vet) translates to 30-plus affordable brews, from the $2 Carling Black Label to chocolaty Aventinus from Germany (a $7 steal). For those missing Pioneer, the same smoker still pumps out excellent barbecue—pulled pork piled on soft buns (two for $5) is a delicious reminder of the departed haunt.

column7: Read a book, paint your nails, do whatever—the waitstaff has your comfort in mind at this friendly candlelit bar. If you can’t decide among the 43 wines by the glass, Pudding Stones (which gets its name from the smooth, wide pebbles that cover grounds of many vineyards) offers generous three-pour flights of red, white or sparkling for $11–$15—delicious with a pot of garlicky, wine-soaked mussels. If you seem particularly oenophilic, the server just might take you for a spin around the joint’s pride and joy: a temperature-controlled closet stocked with 87 bottles.

column7: This loud, loutish saloon, a successor to the beloved Mo’s Caribbean, is a rec room for the wrecked. Mo’s palm trees and reggae bands have been replaced with a Circuit City’s worth of sports-tuned TVs and a party-hard ethos fueled by 14 drafts. The collection mixes class (Blue Moon, Red Hook IPA) with crap (expected domestics). If it’s liquor you’re after, don’t order anything more exotic than two-ingredient cocktails like whiskey-and-Cokes—an appropriately lowbrow match for eats like hot dogs and deep-fried Oreos.

column7: This Victorian-styled cocktail parlor from mixology matriarch Julie Reiner (Flatiron Lounge) joins Brooklyn’s spate of newly opened serious drinkeries. Classic cocktails are the thing: Sours, fizzes, mules, swizzles and smashes all get their latter-day due at the 19th-century mahogany bar. Highbrow snacks (fried oysters, steak tartare) and tipples, like a Market Street Julep (pisco, pineapple and mint) or the ginger-packed Pimms Punch, should absolve you of the folly of your appletini days.

column7: This bar in Sunset Park features an outdoor space complete with grill, but you have to bring the meat.

column92: 676 Fifth Ave at 20th St
column144: Subway: M, R to Prospect Ave (M weekdays only)

column7: Visit Hoboken’s leisure paradise—just two blocks from the PATH train—the circa-1956 Irish saloon that offers dartboards, pool, foosball, Big Buck Hunter and Monday Wii Sports home-run-derby contests.
column60: Mon–Thu 4pm–2am; Fri 4pm–3am; Sat noon–3am; Sun noon–2am

column7: The offspring of the beloved adjoining wineshop Harlem Vintage, sleek, chic Nectar continues the store’s legacy with hands-on service and a well-curated wine list. Europe- and California-heavy selections (36 by the glass) are mercifully priced at around $10 (try the vibrant, wild-berry-powered Ukiah Cellars cabernet sauvignon) and an oft-rotating list of about 40 bottles ($24–$40) is just as inviting. Servers ably match the wines to charcuterie and cheese—a chichi detail, gentrification be damned.
column92: 2235 Frederick Douglass Blvd (Eighth Ave) between 120th and 121st Sts
column144: Subway: A, C, B, D to 125th St

column7: This “lightship”—a floating lighthouse once used by the Coast Guard—sank while docked in Maryland and spent three years underwater. Later salvaged, she is now a floating bar near Chelsea Piers.
column92: Pier 66a, West Side Highway at 26th St
column144: Subway: C, E to 23rd St

column7: Though this Red Hook bar is still a work-in-progress (note the tough-to-spot entrance), the easy vibe and inventive drinks list are, thankfully, fully formed. Fresh fruit can be found in cocktails like the blueberry gimlet (muddled berries, vodka and lime juice), and absinthe makes an appearance along with champagne in the sparkling Death in the Afternoon. As for food, the small-plates program has yet to arrive. Brooklyn Botanica may still be evolving, but the bones are there for a beautiful local bar.
column92: 220 Conover St at Coffey St
column144: Travel: F, G to Smith–9th Sts, then take the B77 bus to Conover St

column7: This futuristic spot is what we imagine a wine bar aboard the Starship Enterprise might look like. The mechanized setup is challenging at first, but ultimately liberating: Wine is dispensed from metal spigots at the push of a button, and a touch screen displays tasting notes for each selection. The tech doesn’t come cheap. Prizes such as Vieux Telegraphe Chateauneuf du Pape go for $26 a glass, but you won’t feel robbed by more affordable pleasures, like the flowery Miolo Vale dos Vinhedos pinot noir ($9). Compounding the otherworldly vibe: the sweeping Columbus Circle views.
column8: Wine barAfter-work crowdExtensive wine listGreat viewsNYCVisit: Culture buff
column92: Time Warner Center, 10 Columbus Circle at Broadway, fourth floor
column144: Subway: A, C, B, D, 1 to 59th St–Columbus Circle

column7: Mixology maestro Sasha Petraske has abandoned his opening concept—focusing on sipping spirits, not cocktails—but this narrow, lamp-lit spot is all the better for it. The bar now cranks out expertly rendered classics such as brawny Sazeracs and aromatic old-fashioneds anchored by hand-cracked ice. Absinthe is still the bar’s centerpiece, but the liquor’s snail-pace preparation (a bartender dribbles icy water over a slotted, sugar-topped spoon) slows down service. Stick with mixed drinks instead.
column92: 21 Essex St between Canal and Hester Sts
column144: Subway: F to Delancey St; J, M, Z to Delancey–Essex Sts

column7: Ellis offers creative tapas along with its drink selection.
column92: 627 Fifth Ave between 17th and 18th Sts
column144: Subway: M, R to Prospect Ave (M weekdays only)

column7: This unmarked boîte is the sort of contrived hideout that might be cooked up by an overgrown kid with a chemistry set. The bar is littered with old vials, the cocktails are referred to as “prescriptions,” and the bartenders-cum-mad-scientists are in rare form—note the cinnamon-flambéed Himalayan salt that rims a margarita. But all of this hocus-pocus doesn’t translate to better drinks: An off-putting, gin-fueled Seven Herbs tasted exactly like alcoholic gazpacho. Apothéke’s $35 pyromaniacal absinthe—set aflame and passed between cups à la a blue blazer—yields a syrupy-sweet elixir. Some may revel in such silly tricks, but we’d rather take the cash and buy three less ludicrous drinks elsewhere.
column92: 9 Doyers St at Pell St
column144: Subway: J, M, Z, N, Q, R, W, 6 to Canal St

column7: Couldn’t be bothered to figure out PDT’s “secret” entrance? Then the Eldridge ain’t for you. This plush lounge is hidden behind a faux-bookstore front. Make it past the doorman and you’ll find Chesterfield banquettes and luxe ($20 on average) cocktails from the Hideaway’s Charlotte Voisey. (For an easier in, e-mail reservations@theeldridge.com.)
column92: 247 Eldridge St between E Houston and Stanton Sts
column144: Subway: F, V to Lower East Side–Second Ave

column7: Now that Hamptons season is over, Dune Southampton owner Matt Shendell brings his nightlife savvy to Murray Hill. The upmarket lounge features 30 TVs and booze that’s suited to both the typical (four-buck cans of Pabst) and atypical (strawberry-lychee punch) sports-bar clientele. Ditto the food, which includes fondue—a throwback to the spot’s previous life as Dip.
column92: 416 Third Ave between 29th and 30th Sts
column144: Subway: 6 to 28th St

column7: Bolstering the quirky-cool factor at this Ditmas Park watering hole is a unique mercantile marriage: The spot is a flower shop by day and a tavern by night. Observe the Cheers-brand chill at the long, illuminated, resin-topped bar. Choose from more than two-dozen bourbons, and beers on tap ranging from comforting standbys like Bud and Guinness to microbrews, like the fruity, hop-heavy Goose Island Honker’s Ale. Add a cozy (unheated) patio and a free jukebox, and you’d be hard-pressed to find a better backdrop for a round of cold ones—or an occasional bouquet.
column92: 1118 Cortelyou Rd between Stratford and Westminster Rds
column144: Subway: Q to Cortelyou Rd

column7: For night owls who equate clubs on desolate streets with hipness, the Bell House has your number. But this Gowanus bar and music venue is worth the bleak trek. The sprawling spot’s two bars—one nestled in an ornate front room, the other in the rear performance space—provide plenty of drinking options. Skip toxic cocktails in favor of one of 12 beers on tap—from Anchor Steam to Smutty Nose—or a taste of more than 20 bourbons. A can’t-miss drinking destination the Bell House is not. But if a band draws you in, stick to a Booker’s and you’ll do fine.
column8: Live DJLive musicNYCVisit: Culture buffNYCVisit: ExplorerSpecialty spirits

column144: Subway: F, G, M, R to Fourth Ave–9th St

column7: Playfully adapting a sign left over from previous tenants (the Black United Foundation), the Shrine deems itself a “Black United Fun Plaza.” True enough. The interior is tricked out with African art and vintage album covers (the actual vinyl adorns the ceiling). Harlemites and downtowners pack the Shrine for nightly concerts, which might feature indie rock, jazz, reggae or DJ sets. The cocktail menu aspires to similar diversity: Drinks range from a smooth mango mojito to signature tipples like a snappy Afro Trip (a lime and ginger concoction enhanced by Jamaican or Brazilian rum), and a sweet vodka-and-Bailey’s-driven Muslim Jew.
column92: 2271 Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Blvd (Seventh Ave) between 133rd and 134th Sts
column144: Subway: B, C, 2, 3 to 135th St

column7: As is customary for contemporary New York lounges, Haven merges old-world details like clubby leather seating and baroque chandeliers with modern ones—check out the ceiling, paneled in faux alligator skin. The 4,000-square-foot bi-level space straddles the line between food and drink destination, but the thoughtful cocktail program tilts the scales toward the latter. High-end tipples include the Jezebel (rose-infused gin with strawberries, basil and Meyer lemon) and Pears and Herbs (cognac, lemon, and pear puree with sage and thyme). Global bites feature ceviches, beef tartare and dumplings.
column92: 244 E 51st St between Second and Third Aves
column144: Subway: E, V to Lexington Ave–53rd St; 6 to 51st St

column7: This wood-adorned sports bar also serves contemporary American food.

column7: In addition to the American and traditional Irish food menu, 13 plasma televisions broadcast all major sporting events at this eclectic bar, while on the weekend a clubby vibe takes over.
column8: FoodLive DJ
column92: 43-06 43rd st between Queens Blvd and 43rd Ave
column144: Subway: 7 to 46th St

column7: When Joshua and Jordan Boyd and Darren Rubell (cousin to Studio 54’s Steve Rubell) created this East Village lounge, their ambition was to wrap a 21st-century drink emporium in Jazz Age glamour. But the garish decor is more cheesy (a red-and-black Vegas aesthetic) than chic,and the drinks are duds. The Ella is a characterless mix of vodka, elderflower liqueur, lemon juice and fresh watermelon. A gloppy Rye Smash—raspberries and lemon muddled with whiskey and simple syrup, then shaken and served in the same glass—is unsightly and bitter. When the DJ kicks in, the energy of the sexy twentysomething clientele is infectious. But it’s not enough to overlook tacky trappings and sloppy drinks.

column7: The notoriously extravagant Japanese eatery has reinvented its second-level lounge: What was once Kimono Bar is now M. Unfinished motorcycle parts reside next to the ornate silk robes that were part of the original décor, while the bar has been sliced in half to make way for a dance floor. The menus have been upgraded too: Cocktails include the Tokyo Celebrity (sugarcane shochu and champagne with lemon juice), and a menu of designer nibbles features kobe beef croquettes and a variety of maki.

column7: The website, featuring snapshots of wince-inducing 1940s headlines (“atom bomb hits japs”), is the first glimpse of bar-branding gone berserk at this new Flatiron spot. The theme is World War II, and it’s emblazoned all over the menu: You’ll find an Allied cheese plate (English, Swiss) and an Axis one (Italian, French) to complement classic drinks like a Moscow mule and an old-fashioned. We wish it were a hoax, but it’s not. Joseph Heller must be turning in his grave.
column92: 4 W 22nd St between Fifth and Sixth Aves
column144: Subway: F, V, N, R, W to 23rd St

column7: Owner Michael Connolly spent 25 years as a wine and spirits dealer before opening his popular Carroll Gardens eatery, Chestnut, five years ago. So itmakes sense that he would unveil this companion bar next door.You’ll find well-curated spirits such as genever—the Netherlands’ whiskeylike equivalent of dry gin—in his negroni, and Picon, a rare brand of French bitters, in the Brooklyn (a rye-based cocktail). Small plates from chef Daniel Eardley include “cheese on horseback” (Swiss tête de moine cheese balanced on candied pecans) and sardine toasts with grapes and olives. They should go nicely with the neat wine list, which features esoteric by-the-glass selections.
column92: 271 Smith St between DeGraw and Sackett Sts
column144: Subway: F, G to Carroll St

column7: The same-named Upper East Side wine bar gets a midtown sibling. Explore the 40 old- and new-world selections by the glass in the heated sidewalk café.

column7: Sharing space with Double Crown, this bar specializes in gin and vodka cocktails, and also offers a small-plates menu with creations that combine pub grub with Asian street food.

column144: Subway: B, D, F, V to Broadway–Lafayette St; 6 to Bleecker St

column7: Driftwood-framed mirrors and palm trees lend a beachy feel to this Park Slope tiki hut. Owner Spencer Rothschild, also behind Barrio and the forthcoming Playa, offers Mexican and Brazilian beers, along with snacks like rum-glazed shrimp skewers and oyster empanadas. Polynesian staples such as tropical rum punch are also available, although Cabana’s take on it—the flaming Bonfire Bowl—might have you fearing for your eyebrows.

column144: Subway: B, Q, 2, 3, 4, 5 to Atlantic Ave; 2, 3 to Bergen St

column7: This stylish saloon hosts a bespoke tailor in its anteroom two days a week—not surprising for a bar named after 20th-century fashion priestess Elsa Schiaparelli. The clean, airy space is echoed in the minimalist drinks list: ten international wines by the glass and a worthy selection of beers—drafts are funneled through an ancient sewing machine. But the real draw here is the ten affordable cocktails, including an austere old-fashioned and a smooth Jaszek (applejack, Falernum, lime juice, Angostura and orange bitters). Call Elsa the new cocktail culture’s calmer, quieter cousin—one with a dapper wardrobe.

column7: The third location of this lounge and cigar bar has opened in midtown. Semicircular leather banquettes and dark-wood flourishes give BB&B an appropriately clubby vibe. Though whiskey may be the natural choice in these opulent environs (there are 150 of them), classic cocktails are also available. James Bond films flicker on flat-screen TVs, and on Monday nights, ladies can puff on gratis stogies. Who ever said a cigar is just a cigar?

column7: This stylish sports lounge in Gramercy offers a weekend special of unlimited 25¢ wings (mild, hot and BBQ) paired with $10 pitchers of Bud and Bud Light all day on Saturdays and Sundays.

column7: The ritzy reboot of what was previously Bella’s aims for a British Colonial look, with bamboo wainscoting and faded palm-tree wallpaper. The cocktail list has also been upgraded, with nips like the Autumn Strawberry (bourbon, clover honey and strawberries).
column92: 1 Cleveland Pl at Broome St
column144: Subway: J, M, Z to Bowery; 6 to Spring St

column7: The Gowanus beer hall offers “anything you can’t get in your local deli,” said our tight-lipped server of Draft Barn’s 250 brews. We enjoyed specialty suds such as Pauwel’s Kwak—a rich Belgian amber with a fruit-and-berries bouquet, served in a foot-long, thermometer-shaped vessel. Food, like the faux-Euro beer hall decor, skews Eastern Bloc: Bracing pickled herring and onions complemented our silky, chocolaty Sri Lankan Lion Stout. The staff is knowledgeable, but a bit taciturn— if they could muster more enthusiasm than a Duane Reade clerk, this so-far-uncrowded hall might pack them in.

column7: Nineteenth-century nostalgia rules this Harlem lounge, inspired by Almack’s Dance Hall, the erstwhile Five Points saloon. Owner Karl Franz Williams, also of Harlem’s Society Coffee, has outfitted the cozy vintage space with purple velvet curtains, distressed mirrors and filament lightbulbs. But he took some liberties with the recipes: The Ol’ Fashionista blends Grand Marnier with bourbon, the house sidecar gets a splash of green chartreuse, and the New York Sazerac features a dose of cognac.
column92: 2082 Frederick Douglass Blvd (Eighth Ave) between 112th and 113th Sts
column144: Subway: 2, 3 to 116th St

column7: More than just a novelty act, this otherwise nondescript, Yankee-focused wine bar has one of the smartest, most thoughtful selections of American wine we’ve seen in town. In addition to the expected California and Finger Lakes options, the rotating list of 25 to 30 wines by the glass includes four unusual selections from Virginia producer Kluge (try the succulent viognier, which pits pear and tropical fruits against a commanding acidity). Informed and attentive servers and fine nibbles—including a $5 pickle plate—compensate for the bar’s main drawback: a remote location.

column7: This throwback cocktail spot joins classy joints like Hotel Delmano in shaping Williamsburg’s new breed of bar. Inside, cordial barkeeps craft spot-on drinks. The smoky Scottish Dew (Scotch with muddled cucumbers, orange bitters and maraschino liqueur) is distinctly vegetal, and the blood-hued Higgins’ sarsaparilla blends spicy ginger beer, club soda and amaro, with a dose of fruity red wine. Beers are well curated too: Fourteen $5 drafts include Troegs’ pleasingly caramel Hopback Amber. There are serviceable small plates, but you’d do well to fill your belly before you arrive.

column7: The Blue Ribbon empire strikes again: The storefront across from Blue Ribbon Bakery has been transformed into this tiny small-plates joint. Patrons can dine at the white-oak bar or at the back counter. Food and wine are served until 2am nightly.

column7: What this by-the-numbers wine bar lacks in personality, it makes up for in its smart, compact list. Roughly a dozen reds and whites by the glass include choices like a 2007 Shooting Star Aligoté, full of almond, grass and white peach notes; and the enjoyably leathery 2005 Château de Caladroy “Les Schistes.” Brook-vin does cocktails, too—patrons can match a house-infused vodka with a homemade flavored syrup and seltzer. It’s a fun idea, but not likely to produce drinks of any great quality. A much savvier gimmick is the wine list’s emphasis on half bottles. Sometimes it’s better to stick to what you know.

column7: Knitting Factory founder Michael Dorf shifts his love of large-scale venues to the world of wine with this multi-faceted center devoted to the grape. While a membership program allows those who can afford it the opportunity to make their own wine on the premises (the annual fee starts at $5,000), a restaurant and wine bar are open to the public. At the latter, the list of pours includes more than 500 international bottles—50 available by the glass—and snacks include selections from Murray’s Cheese, as well as a full menu designed for seamless pairing with the vino (see this week’s restaurant openings, page 20). The Knitting Factory origins aren’t completely lost: The space also features a stage for live music.

column7: The sumptuous dark-wood aesthetic, collection of costly spirits and classed-up grub make the tremendous value found at Cornelius’s tile-topped bar come as a pleasant surprise. Weekday happy hours featuring discounted drafts (try Kelso’s orange-kissed St. Gowanus Belgian ale) and one-buck oysters are popular. But the real draw here is the 200-plus library of boutique liquors. The drink menu’s omission of descriptions can be maddening, but the bartenders will eagerly offer input or mix dead-on cocktails like the warming bourbon-and-bitters Steamboat—a maple-syrup-spiked riff on the Manhattan.

column7: Despite its name, this East Village wine bar does not serve absinthe or any other hard liquors (the name actually comes from the space’s wallpaper, which features images in the style of 19th-century painter Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, who often worked under the influence of the wormwood-based tipple). The wine list includes roughly 100 different bottles from around the world; you’re welcome to try any of them, so long as you are willing to pay for three glasses. Meanwhile, a small-plates menu includes playful creations like beet and apple lollipops with a goat cheese mousse, from chef Matthew Purcell (Gramercy Tavern, Oceana).

column7: This neighborhood tavern has something for everyone: beers, cocktails, wines, food and a rotating roster of entertainment. Stop by on Tuesday nights for an open mike—sometimes music, sometimes poetry—or listen to the DJ’s selection on Friday nights.

column7: The team behind rocker joint Daddy’s has introduced its better half: cozy Mother’s. The best perch is the well-lit oak bar, where it’s quiet enough to read a newspaper while exploring the 16 affordable drafts. There’s a fine mix of local microbrews, like the Coney Island Albino Python, a spicy wheat lager, alongside imports such as Belgium’s refreshing Gaffel Kölsch. Budget-price pub grub includes habit-forming sweet-potato fries—freshly cut with a pleasing crunch. Your mother couldn’t make ’em better.

column7: This historic space—the building did time as a 19th century brothel—is now home to an old-fashioned saloon featuring six beers on tap.

column7: Once this hotel-lounge goes reservation-only in March, you’ll need more than your wits and a nice smile to get past the doorman—like 60 Thompson’s A60, an access card (granted to hotel guests and other privileged folk) will be required for entrance. Get a peek while you can: The glass-enclosed lounge (the roof is retractable during the warmer months) extends over Allen Street, providing a bird’s-eye view of the Lower East Side. Take it in over cocktails like the Forbidden Fruit (citrus vodka, Aperol, lemon juice and honey) and small plates (yellowtail sashimi, crispy taro puffs) dispatched from chef Susur Lee’s kitchen at Shang, also at the Thompson LES.
column92: Thompson LES Hotel, 190 Allen St between E Houston and Stanton Sts
column144: Subway: F, V to Lower East Side–Second Ave

column7: There is no bar to belly up to at this louche lounge. Drinks are prepared in a beautiful but half-hidden back room surrounded by gleaming examples of every tool and gizmo a barkeep could wish for. From this gorgeous tableau comes an austere cocktail list, which includes classics like the Manhattan and Negroni, and variations thereof. The Old Cuban (rum, champagne, mint and bitters) smacks of a mojito with something to celebrate. And the velvety Japanese, powered by brandy and orgeat (almond-and-rosewater syrup), is so strong it could serve itself. Who needs a barstool anyway?

column144: Subway: F, V to 14th St; L to Sixth Ave

column7: New York’s sipping set may be currently captivated by old-school gin joints, but some spots are still keeping it simple. Bar 108’s spartan name echoes its straightforward concept: comfy leather banquettes, eight TVs showing anything from ESPN to CNN and more than 30 international beers. Until the kitchen opens in March, the grub is equally everyman: panini, wings and salads. The one courtly concession: specialty cocktails like the brow-raising 4 Godfathers (Jack Daniel’s, Johnnie Walker Black, Jim Beam and Jose Cuervo).
column60: Mon–Wed 4pm–midnight; Thu 4pm–2am; Fri 2pm–4am; Sat noon–4am; Sun noon–midnight

column7: Like a starlet with beauty but no talent, this refined tavern offers lots of flash (see the requisite old-timey trappings) and little substance. Beer is the drink of choice, but the 16 drafts are mostly static, with warhorses (Blue Moon) trotted out alongside treats (Belhaven’s gently hopped Thistle IPA). The wine selection, meanwhile, is sparse, with just a handful of offerings that read better than they taste. Ditto the food: The haddock in the fish-and-chips was the picture of golden-fried perfection, but quickly disintegrated into greasy lumps. In pub grub as in pubs, looks can be deceiving.
column8: Conversation-friendlyFoodNeighborhood barPub

column7: In the space that once housed lesbian sanctum Meow Mix (and later Vasmay Lounge) comes this Irish-tinged bar and music venue. The live bands appearing two nights a week are curated by co-owner Bill Snodgrass, who doubles as a guitarist in indie emo-rock band Ouijipig. Eight taps dominate the bar (look for Brooklyn Lager, Stella and Guinness, naturally), but management promises they’ve got a handle on cocktails, too—they serve them “good, strong and large.” A two-for-one happy hour lasts from 2 to 9pm, and grilled cheese will be doled out on the house this month.

column7: Just a block from the gleaming mess of Times Square sits this completely un-Disneyfied Port Authority holdout. A cast of rowdy workmen eye the bikini-clad bartenders every time they bend over; those tired of staring can try their hand at the punching-bag boxing simulator.

column7: Perhaps New York’s diviest dive, the Navy Yard “lounge” is where you can mingle with late-night strippers while getting dirt-cheap beer and well drinks ($3 before 9pm)—and the serious suspicion that you might get knifed. The building is up for sale, so drop by soon before it goes bistro.

column7: Dive doesn’t begin to describe the grimy sleaze achieved by this Queens bikini bar. Barely dressed barmaids exchange flashes of skin for tips, while hard-drinking locals slam $3 Buds and play pool in the back.

column7: Puerto Rico-USA is a five-year-old local with plastic chairs, a corner TV and a friendly owner who grew up in the neighborhood. A domino table pleases East Harlem long-timers, but most patrons are happy just downing beer and Bacardi.

The $6.50 pitchers of Pabst ensure well-lubricated indiscretions, especially when aided by the busty bartenders’ copious pours of Wild Turkey.

column7: In 2000, this nautically themed Port Authority dive ignited a political firestorm when cops took security guard Patrick Dorismond for a drug dealer, mistakenly shooting and killing him. Mayor Giuliani made matters worse, releasing Dorismond’s sealed records and saying he was no altar boy—when, in fact, he once had been—at Rudy’s very own Catholic alma mater.

column7: Food plays a significantly bigger role here than it does next door at Frederick Twomey’s wine bar, Bar Veloce. The Basque menu lists tasty bites such as serrano-ham sandwiches on mini brioches and slices of pork belly with juniper-accented chickpea puree, priced at $3.50 apiece. In keeping with the theme, the wine list highlights obscure favorites from the Iberian Peninsula. The decor is Spanish-influenced too: mosaic tiles, cement bar and pans dangling from the ceiling.

column7: Despite the presence of serious brew bars like Spuyten Duyvil, PBR still reigns supreme in North Brooklyn. Puncturing that barbaric benchmark: beer importer Ed Raven,who has applied his decade of hoppy intelligence to this new retail store, located (in true Greenpoint fashion) in a onetime auto-body shop. Raven favors but doesn’t limit his inventory to his own imports—like herbaceous Jever Pilsener and the Belgian refresher Gruut. More than 200 selections available include ten drafts that can be transported home in 64-ounce growlers ($10). Of interest to noncommittal types: Patrons can mix and match six-packs andcases.

column144: Subway: G to Greenpoint Ave

column7: Let’s say the Mets lost. (Just being realistic here...) If there’s anyone as bummed as you are, it’s John O’Leary, manager of the Roosevelt Sports Bar, about a 12-minute walk east of Citi Field stadium. And hey, if there’s anything that’ll cheer up a depressed Mets fan, it’s free beer: Show the staff proof that you were just at a game—a brochure suffices—and your first drink is on the house; down three more and your fifth one is also free. With drink specials like these, you’ll forget your favorite team blew it—and quite possibly that you were at the game in the first place.
column92: 133-45 Roosevelt Ave between Lawrence and Prince Sts
column144: Subway: 7 to Flushing–Main St

column7: By now, bar pioneer Sasha Petraske’s formula is pretty familiar: natty bartenders, precise drinks and little (if any) signage. What separates Dutch Kills from the rest is space. The plentiful elbow room makes it a comfortable place to enjoy cocktails like the rye-based Garibaldi, made with lime juice, Campari and mellow white grapes. The Infante takes the familiar pairing of tequila and lime, and lightens it up with homemade orgeat (rosewater and almond syrup) and nutmeg. The cocktail price tag of $9 is a welcome break from the $13-a-drink norm. And if you go on a weekday, you can escape the city crowds as well.

column7: This 80-year-old Greenpoint staple is the epitome of a neighborhood bar. “Nothing has changed,” says coowner Tracy O’Sullivan, “except we got older.” Then she calls down to a regular seated at the bar: “Right, Norm?” It would seem the prices haven’t changed much over the years either: Draft beers are still $1.50 and bottles are $3.25.

column7: We bet Bobby Fischer wouldn’t have approved of mixing alcohol with chess, but it sounds like a good idea to us. Show up early at Sputnik to take advantage of happy-hour deals ($3 well drinks and drafts from 4 to 7pm), and sign up for chess night every Tuesday. Boozed-up brainiacs go rook to rook starting at 8pm.

column7: This Prospect Heights watering hole is a contrived sequel to Tracy Westmoreland’s now-closed cult bar, Siberia. The dive’s clandestine look—newspaper-covered windows, buzzer entry—is covert to a fault, and the interior recalls a fratboy’s dream house. The booze is as negligible as the decor: Pabst on tap, Miller High Life in bottles and cheap Jameson. None of this purposeful grime has attracted the old Siberia clientele—instead, it’s been embraced by indifferent locals thirsty for a last-call beer at any cost.

column7: The Plaza’s restored, 102-year-old Oak Bar is a hit with status-hungry locals and thrill-seeking tourists. But for the shrewd New Yorkers who expect a good drink and service to match, the place can’t cut it. A lackluster Cherry Blossom, made with gin, lemon juice, cherry bitters and a brandied cherry, arrived severely undericed and without the promised fruit; the Apricot Sidecar was a one-dimensionally sweet libation dominated by apricot liqueur. At $18 a drink, one should expect something more than a nice view of the park, but the surest way to enjoy the Oak Bar might be by taking in the glorious decor over a glass of water. With ice, please.

column7: You’ve seen it before—an attractive bar with a thoughtful booze selection spoiled by an annoying clientele. So it is at beautiful Flatiron spot Lillie’s. An oblivious, dude-heavy crowd undermines the ornate 19th-century interior and the tasteful beverage list, which includes an easy-drinking proprietary wine, rare whiskeys (look out for the nine Glenmorangie Scotches) and a broad collection of craft beers. But once the sun sets and the suits vacate their barstools, Lillie’s is easy to enjoy. Call it an after after-work spot.
column92: 13 E 17th St between Fifth Ave and Broadway
column144: Subway: L, N, Q, R, W, 4, 5, 6 to 14th St–Union Sq

column7: Barkeep Phil Ward focuses on tequila and its cousin, mescal, at this East Village haute cantina. His wonderful menu features a cool-as-marble Cinquenta Cinquenta—a pairing of chamomile-infused reposado tequila and white vermouth that goes down like iced tea. The Slynx cocktail is a liquid campfire of aged tequila, applejack, bitters and a smoky rinse of mescal. The craftsmanship in the drinks is equaled in the bar menu, featuring juicy pork bellies. Despite its many strengths, Mayahuel wears its ambitions lightly. With so many of today’s top-tier cocktail bars lousy with vanity, that humility is a welcome departure.

column7: Hell’s Kitchen has long been a dead zone for civilized bars, but this sunny paean to American microbrews is an oasis. There are 20 beers on tap and two cask ales artfully listed on signboards according to provenance and potency. The thoughtful selections include Dogfish Head’s peachy Festina Pêche Berliner Weisse and Victory’s Bags Packed Porter, a toasty treat rich with coffee and chocolate. The low prices (all 14-ounce servings cost $5) and expert curation suggest that the ’hood’s notorious bar drought may finally be easing.

column7: Shunning by-the-books trendiness, Tandem is an original: Sister owners Jane and Cathy Virga either sourced or crafted nearly every piece of the interior, and the quirky drinks are just as special. The herbaceous Masten Lake is a highlight of the seasonal cocktail list, combining gin, seltzer, lemon and basil plucked from the rooftop garden. The mostly local drafts, meanwhile, are siphoned into homemade ceramic pint glasses. Tandem’s many charms have drawn in the ’hood’s ultrahip, who take to the rear dance floor on Fridays and Saturdays. We might join them too.

There are no private rooms: The brave have to perform in front of everyone, but after a few drinks (beer, wine, sake, cocktails), it should be easy to get the nerve up.

column7: A night at this marble-walled, chandeliered venue can be a comedy of errors. When we visited the bar lacked the ingredients to execute the fruity, overthought cocktails that populate its specialty list. Bar snacks include atrocities like a cardboard pizza with congealed cheddar and funky barbecued pork, and veiny skewers of beef—not even an electric-green apple martini (a cocktail the bar was actually able to make) could wash them down. The Gates might not be a viable venue for dinner, but it’s certainly a contender to jump-start bulimia.

column7: This subdued lounge attempts to bring back some dignity to the Meatpacking District with pedigreed cocktails and uncomplicated entertainment like foosball and Ms. Pac-Man. The cocktails alone almost pull it off: The Karzai blends Hennessy, egg white and poppy-seed puree; the Sommerwind juxtaposes lychee and cucumber in riesling in a fruity, fragrant melange. Unfortunately, the forced quirkiness of the snack menu (chocolate-covered bacon?) undermines the terrific drinks. MePa definitely needs a makeover, but 675 isn’t its saving grace.

column7: We’re used to battling for seats at Astoria’s Bohemian Hall. But nearby Studio Square—a sleek outdoor biergarten—is just as majestic, with plentiful perches. Studio’s party-hearty ambience is fueledby DJs, live bands and one of the city’s best tap selections. Eighteen drafts include American microbrews like Bear Republic’s piney Racer Five. Bohemian Hall may have gotten all the details right (Studio’s grub was seriously lacking), but it’s had 100 years to perfect the formula. Eventually, this welcome newcomer might be a cherished institution too.

column7: In a city where 19th-century saloon style has a choke hold on bar design, the Slab’s spare, industrial look is refreshing. And while latter-day cocktail wizardry tends to hinge on liquors like gin and whiskey, here the spirit of choice is near-flavorless Scandinavian aquavit, which makes an appearance in the Berzerker, a sensory challenge with flavors like caraway, cucumber and dill. Other cocktails—like the overwhelmingly salty, anchovy-garnished, vodka-and-Sambuca-based Moby Dick—make it clear why the hipster crowd favors the beer menu: a well-curated list of 46 foreign and domestic microbrews.

column7: The Ravel Hotel, which opened last June in Long Island City, debuts a rooftop lounge this week. The 6,000-square-foot, candlelit garden terrace, furnished with plush orange chairs, features clear views of the Manhattan skyline and the Queensboro Bridge. The 40-foot bar serves draft beers such as Blue Moon and Sam Adams, along with cocktails like a Caribbean punch (white and dark rum, guava and pineapple juices, Coco Lopez and grenadine). Each night of the week will have its own theme, including Wednesday’s “Noche en la Terraza” featuring mojito and sangria pitchers.

column7: Three hundred tons of trucked-in sand approximate an urban seashore at this location of WTB. Family-friendly trappings like minigolf can make for an awkward scene during busy afternoons, with hipsters queued up while grade-schoolers monopolize the games. But the grown-ups do have cocktails (sangria, daiquiris) and summery beers. Deejayed weekend parties are meant to draw a hipper crowd, but the cover charges seem to deter locals. Still, the beach’s few missteps don’t soil the singular experience of sipping a drink at the river’s edge.

column7: This hipster sports bar “serves” a number of conflicting constituencies. Caught up in a big game, the after-work schlubs may not even notice the eclectic mishmash of sports memorabilia (including an authentic Wayne Gretzky portrait by Andy Warhol). But the younger group that arrives later is far more focused on drinking (and flirting) than keeping up with the score. The booze speaks to both crowds: Bud Light and imported draft beers for the sports fans, and deadly Maker’s Mark Sazeracs for the rest of us. Still, in the end Warren 77 is too schizophrenic for our taste.

Fortunately, you don’t have to be a fashionista teenager to enjoy the space, where original cocktails like the Mariposa (mescal, fresh lime, candied violets) and classics, such as the Pimm’s cup, can be enjoyed alongside casual dishes from executive chef Justin Bogle, including suckling-pig tacos. Wine director Patrick Cappiello offers a list of 20 half bottles that will be available only outside, in addition to the restaurant’s wider selection.

column7: Fort Greene’s first beer garden has a few things down pat. There are 18 German brews on tap (crisp Radeberger pilsner, bitter Oktoberfest Hofbräu lager) and many more by the bottle. And there are plenty of affordable, satisfying small plates—like Berlin’s classic currywurst. Where Der Schwarze falls short is its appearance: Despite a prime corner location and huge wrap-around windows, the space suffers from a sparse and generic design. A cosmetic improvement might make it a more inviting place to drink. Until then, we’re sticking with Radegast.

Still, thetri-level space is suspiciously clublike, with the capacity to hold 300 people, a sound system disguised behind oak and cork wall paneling, and the upper areas reserved for VIPs.

column7: The serious take on tippling offered at Fort Defiance is rare in isolated Red Hook, but the cocktails rank among the best in the borough. The Journalist, made with gin and vermouth, is as clean and crisp as a classic Manhattan. A Prescription Julep is an extra-potent mint julep featuring cognac and rye, poured over hand-crushed ice. If you live in the ’hood, this could be your new local spot (it opens at 7am on weekdays, serving coffee and breakfast). The frontier pricing—most drinks are under $10—helps justify the trek for the rest of us.

column7: This lounge from Sean MacPherson and Eric Goode is home to the most raging midweek party in lower Manhattan. The Ballroom is nearly as stunning as the crowd it attracts, with an offbeat tableau of stuffed beasts and mismatched couches. Though you can easily stake out a seat early on, the real festivities don’t usually get going until after midnight, when the dancing—fueled by cocktails like the cucumber vodka–and-limoncello Punjab—starts migrating onto tables and chairs. Our only complaint about the Jane? How long the line is.

The outdoor area is complemented by a modern penthouse, complete with a working fireplace, which offers refuge from inclement weather. Drinks include fruit-flavored sparklers, and the house punch, a blend of rum, peach liqueur, champagne, and cranberry, pineapple and lemon juices.

column7: This bowling alley and live music venue fully embraces the new mania for local nostalgia. The space takes its design cues from Coney Island with old freak-show posters and carnival-game relics, and all of the beer sold inside—by Sixpoint, Kelso and the Brooklyn Brewery—is made in the borough. This is a great place to kill a few hours with a big rowdy group: You can tackle a pitcher and the stoner-food menu from the Blue Ribbon team (delicious fatty brisket, Old Bay–fried chicken) laneside between frames. The plush tufted couches are the most luxurious alley seating we’ve ever seen.

column7: This East Village watering hole combines old-timey style with frat-house tastes. The loungelike space, complete with parlorworthy wallpaper and a pressed-tin–sided bar, features a menu of Jell-O shots, such as the Jell-O Surfer on Acid: pineapple Jell-O, Malibu Rum, cranberry juice and Jagermeister ($3). The list of specialty cocktails, like the Siberian Kiss made with citron vodka, Fra Angelico liqueur, Bailey’s and crème de cacao with a frozen Hershey’s kiss on the bottom ($10), suggests that you don’t need a password to get in.

column7: There’s much more to running a drinks destination than a great cocktail. Which explains why this austere bar nails all of its drinks but flubs so much else. The drinks list features some inspired creations, like the Singer, combining muddled raspberries and rye, and the Sweeter Heater—a tequila cocktail with white pepper, basil and hot sauce. But only the basic bar snacks—dates wrapped in bacon, flaky spinach-cheese phyllo pockets—are solid food options. It’s just as well that the rest of the grub is so hit-or-miss: The generic setting doesn’t invite settling in, anyway.

column7: This raucous saloon is like a fictional frat house, so packed with an Alpha Beta crowd that you’ll need a reservation on weekends. While you’re securing your spot, you can also reserve a keg. There are more than 750 barreled brews to choose from, including cheap American lagers, craft beers and funky Belgian ales. Frat-friendly perks abound: Fight for your favorite Dave Matthews track at the music station, pound away on piano or drums, or play a round of beer pong. Like it or not, Superdive’s management has achieved what they presumably set out to do: bring pledge-week debauchery to a Manhattan bar.

column7: Sprung from humble Long Island City origins, Water Taxi Beach has expanded to increasingly valuable riverside real estate: first South Street Seaport, and now this 20,000-plus-square-foot Governors Island locale. Drinks are similar to those at the other locations, including draft beers and cocktails. The Beach Grill—one of three minirestaurants on the site—sells familiar fare like the Motz Burger; by the end of the month, the Backstage Cafe is expected to open, offering dishes made from local produce, including some grown on the island. Music fans, take note: The beach doubles as a concert venue, with stars like Mos Def and the B-52’s set to perform this summer.

Small and large plates—mostly Italian and French—from Connecticut chef Andrea Tiberi will include items like lasagna filled with porcino mushrooms and black truffles, and flatbread with prosciutto and mozzarella.

The chef will also serve brew-friendly foods, including Vietnamese versions of fried fish and barbecue ribs, but for those tiring of the sandwich trend, rest assured: There will be no banh mi.

This retro space features three mod rooms, where customers can sip beer, wine or cocktails, which come in “mini” (regular) or “regular” (jumbo) sizes. column7: Despite the lavish setting and expense-account menu, this extravagant cocktail lounge is so surprisingly welcoming, it’s easy to forget you can’t afford it. The drinks deliver: A sugar-free Steve Collins is pleasantly bitter (though it is stevia-sweetened), combining Bombay Sapphire, citrus juices and ginger over crushed ice. The French Forty Eight defies its froufrou fixings (Hendrick’s gin, ginger liqueur, Roederer champagne and strawberries), adding up to a balanced treat. While there’s plenty here to make us skeptical—the prices, the buttoned-up crowd—the place turns out to be a New York paradox: a destination cocktail lounge in midtown.

The bar’s smartly curated array of reasonably priced suds includes strong selections from craft brewerieslike Kelso, Fire Island and Captain Lawrence, but the unpretentious bartender will just as happily crack open a cheap bottle or can of everyman ale like Amstel or Miller. Cocktails are ambitious, but many of them fall flat. Stick to a brew and a bite from the satisfying food menu: Beer-battered McClure’s pickles are an epic bar snack.

column7: It wasn’t long ago that tequila was mostly thought of as something to shoot with a lick of salt and bite of lemon. But thanks to its serious treatment at bars like Mayahuel, it’s now becoming the spirit of the moment. Joining the trend is this speakeasy-themed lounge. While the cocktail list spans the full liquor shelf, the Mexican distillate is the star player in many of the drinks, including the El Diablo (habanero peppers, hot sauce, tequila and lime juice), which the owners claim is so spicy that they will make customers sign a release before drinking it. Also expect a Mexican-heavy beer selection and small plates, including tacos and quesadillas.

column7: Hotel maven André Balazs unveils the first of a series of upper-level venues in his trendy Meatpacking hotel, the Standard. Why bother with the theme if it’s not going to up your game?

column7: Designer Lauren Rottet crafted this deco beauty as a nod to Coco Chanel, an homage that’s quite appropriate in the heart of the Upper East Side. The bar, owned by Daniel Boulud and located across the Surrey lobby from Café Boulud, is framed in black lacquered panels that recall an elegant makeup compact. If you’re used to sipping serious cocktails in neo-speakeasies, the luxe setting and monied, buttoned-up crowd might seem a little stiff. But the drinks, crafted by Cameron Bogue (from DB Bistro Moderne in Vancouver), are so exquisitely executed and downright delicious, you won’t mind sharing your banquette with a suit. As at Café Boulud, the menu is divided into four categories: “la tradition” (classics), “la saison” (seasonal), “le potager” (vegetal), and “le voyage” (global). Among the three traditional tipples was a gorgeous Sloe Gin Fizz ($16), an easy-sipping stunner that combined tart Plymouth sloe gin with lemon juice and homemade rhubarb bitters, crowned with a silky egg-white head. The aptly named La Terre ($15, from le potager) is an earthy, complex blend of red vermouth, Aperol, grapefruit juice and beet-infused gin (made in-house, as are many of the tinctures, bitters and infusions). Bogue’s mixology finds a fine complement in a selection of canapés from Café Boulud. Arriving on a tiered silver platter are savory mouthfuls like flaky gougères and arancini with flecks of black truffle. All of this refinement will cost you: Canapés for four is $28, and cocktails top out at $19. It’s well worth the price.

Sixteen taps, dispensing international brews like Radeberger and Monty Python’s Holy Grail Ale, plus a menu of pub grub, including a traditional Sunday-night roast, suggest that low-key can be a very good thing.

column7: Harry Poulakakos (Harry’s Café) has been collecting wines for more than 50 years, with a particular interest in Burgundy. column7: The Bowery Hotel’s ornate lobby bar, from veteran hoteliers Eric Goode and Sean MacPherson (both of the Maritime Hotel), is among the city’s most inviting settings for a drink. Plush velvet couches and chairs, Middle Eastern tilework, Turkish rugs and the green sprays of palm leaves share space with dark, wood-paneled walls sporting antlers and paintings of hounds. The combined effect falls between an officer’s club in the colonial Far East and an aristocrat’s hunting lodge in the British countryside. The luxurious decor is a throwback to the grand hotel bars of yesteryear, except unlike many of those stalwarts still operating in New York today, the bartenders here can mix a decent (albeit pricey) drink. We were especially partial to the namesake Bowery Cocktail ($18), an aromatic concoction that layered Bulldog gin with the sweet-spiced flavor of Dubonnet and a splash of celebratory champagne. The absinthe-based Dutch Courage ($16), meanwhile, is sure to please licorice lovers with its anise notes and fresh muddled mint. Unfortunately, only hotel guests can order food from the adjacent Gemma restaurant in the bar area, though perhaps a skilled negotiator can convince someone to bend the rules—a tactic you may have to employ to score seats on the lovely heated back patio, also reserved for guests only.
